story:
Hello.
We are two students from Syria and Egypt, currently attending Memorial University of Newfoundland. We created this campaign to help raise money for Syrian refugees through The UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR).

We are fundraising for UNHCR to support and invest in Syrian refugees who need life-saving help!

The Syrian conflict has resulted in the biggest humanitarian crisis of our time. It's been five years since the onset of the civil war in Syria and there is no end in sight. Over 300,000 people have been killed and over half the population has been displaced.

The UNHCR is the best equipped and experienced organization in dealing with such a crisis, and are able to leverage your contribution and maximize its benefit to the refugees. They offer a fully integrated approach to managing the refugee crisis. Their activities include providing humanitarian aid like food, shelter, water, medical attention, sanitation and safety to the refugees. They also perform security and background checks to incoming refugees to ensure that relief is reaching those in actual need.

When we learned that there were 4 million registered Syrian refugees who need help, we knew we had to take action. With your contributions, we can help people who have lost everything restart their lives and make their own living.

Remember, those refugees are not a liability to the world economy, they are in fact and investment opportunity. The refugees include many people with past education and experience who are able to work and share in economic growth and societal well being. The sooner we get them on their feet, the better for everyone.

What We Need

We created this campaign to raise $20,000. All the donations will go to the UNHCR to help Syrian refugees. Even if we don't reach our goal by the deadline, all the money raised would still go to the UNHCR as we can't wait for another minute. Any refugee is threatened to die of cold, hunger, thirst, or potential diseases due to lack of food, clean water, medication, proper healthcare and many other necessities for life.

The Impact

Raising money will not only help the refugees to survive during the current crisis, but each and everyone of them will thank you and pray for you deep in their hearts to show their gratefulness. It will also make you feel better to know that you are donating to help the people of your community by showing mercy and affection to those who need it the most. remember every single coin or bill can make a difference.

Challenges

Imagine eating, drinking, wearing and medicating only 37% of what you need!

The Syrian refugee crisis is one of the world's most underfunded humanitarian causes. The United Nations requested $4.5 billion for year 2015 alone to be able to handle this crisis (http://data.unhcr.org/syrianrefugees/regional.php#). Till date, only 37% of the funding requirement was met! This massive funding gap can lead to disasters with the exacerbating situation, and delaying help will surely cause the cost to handle this crisis to rise.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, you can still make a difference by sharing the campaign's link to your network through social media. Remember, we need your help, we need everyone's help for those refugees to make it. Please do whatever you can to help us fulfill this goal as it's very important to let those people know that humanity has not given up on them and that there is still a ray of hope.

story:
On March 18th, yet another unarmed black person was shot and killed by police. He was in his grandmother's backyard. Police claim they thought he was holding a weapon. It was a cellphone. NOT A GUN. All proceeds will be donated to organizations that fight police brutality and fight for human rights: BLM-Sacramento and VOY Inc. (non-profit in Sacramento).

People of color are disproportionately affected by violence at the hands of law enforcement. Around the country, people are working hard towards increasing police accountability.

This campaign has been ignited by the senseless murder of Stephon Clark. Join us in spreading the message. We encourage everyone to join local movements in your area, organize, donate, and spread awareness about these issues which affect all Americans.

Note: Please choose the correct case for your phone. We support almost all phone types!

story:
As a national non-partisan grassroots organization, our mission is to end inequality for women without regard to gender, race, ethnicity, socio-economic class, marital status, age, sexual orientation, disability or national origin. We will accomplish this by providing voter education and facilitating the mobilization of a nationwide voice, through our membership, to protect and advance women's rights.

UniteWomen WA would like to interact with voters at the many summer festivals that happen around Washington State.  Our next event will be SpokanePride where our handouts will highlight the Violence Against Women Act, why the House version (supported by Spokane Rep.McMorrisRodgers) is unacceptable for leaving out protections for LGBTQ and immigrants, and educate people on how to volunteer or donate to Women's Shelters.  

We need to cover the cost of printing and table fees, as well as some fun and creative handouts to really get people's attention.  It is our goal to raise awareness about the impact of violence and discrimination and give voters and activists ways to get involved.

UniteWomen WA intends to impact the coming elections and build the foundation for a long-term movement.  We will get more women (and men!) involved in building equality and show both our state and federal government that we will not stand to be ignored or treated like second-class citizens.  We will create unity between all the causes that affect women.

Let others know about our campaign!  We are always grateful for donations of time and social media support.  Check out our pages:

www.UniteWomen.org   http://www.facebook.com/groups/361735717208117/

story:
On January 12th, 2010 Haiti was devastated with a 7.0 earthquake that killed over 300,000 and injured an estimated 300,000 more. Over 2,000,000 people were left homeless and without shelter. The people of Haiti need help now more than ever.

 

The vision of Firme Foundation is to provide 100,000 homes made from recyclable materials for the people of Haiti. Our goal is to create strong and permanent housing equipped with electricity and clean water. These homes will provide shelter from the elements, as well as a sense of safety and security. Integrated into these houses will be the message of life and strength upon which the principles of Firme Foundation are grounded.

 

Haitians are living in the streets afraid to go back inside damaged homes. Tarps are used as a refuge, thousands congregate to make tent cities. Disease spreads rampant as rain floods these make-shift shelters. Firme Foundation is working to help put survivors in safe new homes.

 

This page is geared towards raising awareness and bringing people together to help the nation of Haiti by providing shelter to those who lost their homes in the 2010 Earthquake.

 

Your donations make a difference. Thank you for your support

story:
OPEN HEARTS & CLEAN HANDS: A LOCAL FOOD INITIATIVE


WHY

Here at Dundurn Market, we believe strongly in community.  Since the WHO declared
Covid 19 a pandemic on March 11 and the lock-down followed in Canada, we have tried
to use our business as a way to help our community.  We are grateful to be busy
providing doorstep delivery of local food during these trying times, and recognize that
our food and services are not financially viable for everyone. Our goal is to support
vulnerable individuals and families by providing healthy, fresh food.


We are also concerned with the rise in xenophobia brought on by Covid-19.
In early March, Dr. Abdu Sharkawy, a doctor and infectious disease specialist from
Toronto wrote an open letter describing his feelings on the disease and the irrational
fears that it was causing, spreading faster than the disease itself.  His conclusions:
"Facts, not fear. Clean hands. Open hearts."


You can read his open letter here.


With that, we have created this T-shirt initiative to raise funds (and awareness) to
provide locally grown produce to families and individuals in need.


The idea is simple: Buy a shirt, feed a family.


All profits of every shirt sold will go directly to fund one produce box for families and
individuals in need.  We have partnered with Mission Services, who will be in charge of
administering which families and individuals will receive the boxes.

ADDITIONAL BENEFITS


All produce will be purchased from local farms in the Hamilton area, keeping money in
our local economy and helping local farmers that could use a boost right now!  These
farms include:
 Backyard Harvest, Hamilton, Ontario.
 Manorun Organic Farm, Copetown, Ontario.
 Paradise Fields, Hamilton, Ontario.
 Branching Path, Simcoe, Ontario.

Additionally, all shirts will be printed from a local print shop: Start Famous which will keep more money in our local economy.

 

Our Goal

$5000.  This will fund more than 250 local produce boxes!

 

Distribution of Shirts

This is strictly a pre-order.  The shirts are not made yet and we will only be making shirts based on how many we sell.  We will offer shirts for pickup at the Dundurn Market which will be available at the end of June, beginning of July.  We will keep you posted on the timeline throughout the campaign.

Shirt Sources

All of the shirts are sourced via Start Famous; a local print shop here in Hamilton.  All shirts are sweat shop free, WRAP Certified and made in the USA.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand buying a shirt might not be for you!  Other ways you can help:

Share this campaign on social media.

Share this campaign with your friends, family and neighbours!

 

Questions?  Please email us at openheartscleanhands@gmail.com

story:
As always, it is the children who suffer most from conflict. 

Operation “Protective Shield” took the lives of many children and wounded physically countless more, but wounded all of the children of Gaza with trauma.
There is a dire need of help for the Children of Gaza, of which this is one small humble effort. We are a small group of people from around the world working together as a team to bring aid to the children who need it most.

All the basic necessities of life are hard to get in Gaza now, and prices on many basic staples have doubled. 

The money we raise is used to purchase food, and diapers, and necessities that are purchased in Gaza then distributed by our team members there. 

What we are doing can best be expressed by our team member in Gaza:

"I am Maha Abu alkas from Gaza Strip, working as a reporter for France 24
and work in the field of social work as a volunteer in Gaza.

On this page we try to collect the largest share of contributions through which we will be able to help hundreds of children in Gaza who have lost their families, their homes and lost their most basic rights to live in peace in the besieged Gaza Strip for years.

During my field visit to the schools which housing thousands of Palestinians, the kids need important things , games, clothes and medicines and essential items at this time.

We try to bring them life again without the sounds of the bombs and drones, the sound of death children lives the worst war ever in Gaza we want at least to make them forget what they have seen and live in this war.

Why we help the children? More than 400 children have been killed , and more than 2000 have been wounded. they don't know the meaning of war but lived the war instead of playing and thinking in the future In the beautiful Gaza, is not a place to think about the future, but the of looks these innocent children will give others life We try to give them life, life just Give them life..."

story:
Join me in my fight for dignity!

I escaped over the Berlin wall in East Germany being shot and almost dying. I came to America to be free of political abuse, physical/sexual abuse and transgender abuse for being born different-something that was not my fault! I have tried hard to hide this and to fit in socially. 

" Baby I was born this way! "

 I want to live my life with dignity as a whole person not as an “hermaphrodite freak” or “he/she/it.”  

Every person in America deserves to have human rights and to live with dignity!

Just six years ago, I was in a head-on collision/car accident. The driver was drunk and was not looking where he was going. Almost every bone in my face was shattered. I remember the flashing lights of an ambulance and was taken to the hospital where I was humiliated by the nurses-the whole staff made me a laughing stock.

While there I received the bare minimum of treatment, was ridiculed constantly, and even had others come down to point and laugh at me. I was scared to go to the bathroom for fear of being made fun of and feeling afraid that the hospital was not going to care for me at all.

My current doctor has said that the surgeon at that hospital hacked me up because they did not care and that it is “mandatory to redo the surgery in my face because that doctor had done such a bad job.”

I live in constant pain everyday in my face but I am also in pain worried about the future.  I am so afraid of getting turned away at another hospital in case of emergency or when needing treatment. I am afraid of being bullied and beaten up again because of being born different. 

I am NOT the only one that has been mistreated by hospitals and especially the nursing staff through verbal abuses. 

In my case I was very lucky to get treatment at all. The whole time I was there I was made fun of and the doctor did not care about the quality of surgery to my face (shattered bones) because he did not even treat me with dignity as a human with rights.  In Muncie, Indiana (very close to where I live) there is another story that also confirms my experience is part of a larger social problem.  For more information visit “Trans talk” via the following link: 

http://destrantalk.blogspot.com/2010/07/update-to-transgender-woman-denied.html

or http://www.wishtv.com/dpp/news/local/north_central/transgender-controversy-sparks-change-at-muncie-hospital

Something has to be done (not just for me) but to ensure that gays, lesbians, and the transgender community will be treated fairly at hospitals and not abused. Even though I am different I am still a human being and deserve to be treated with dignity and with human rights.

Please help support my cause and send a message to the world that this will no longer be tolerated! Please help restore my dignity!

I am trying to have female reconstructive surgery so that I can just live the rest of my life without fear of being transgender and I am trying to raise money to have my face reconstructed so that I will not have to live each day in constant pain.

I am asking for help personally because I have not been able to get back on my feet after the crisis from the car accident and after a person in a powerful position conned me out of my property which was my life savings. I was desperate to get the money for the surgery so I was going to lease out my property per the counsel of someone whom I thought I could trust.  I ended up losing everything I had worked for my whole life, on top of the intense pain from the car accident, and was even homeless for a time.  

Please share my story and fight with others http://www.indiegogo.com/nbloom0415 

The Impact

Your gift will help restore my dignity to live fully as a whole person and as a woman, and also reduce my fear of social settings and public humiliation. I am also hoping that it has a larger impact to be a voice against the oppression and to stand up for the rights and dignity of the transgender community especially at hospitals where every human should have the right to quality treatment FREE from emotional abuse.

story:
Short Summary

The liberty movement has a number of allies in public office but it isn't enough. We need individuals walking the halls of Utah's legislature doing those things that even our best legislators cannot.

Utah's legislature passes an average of 500 bills each 45 day legislative session. They are wasting our money and creating more laws than could possibly be needed to protect our life, liberty and property.

We have a right to petition our government but few of us have the time or the resources to spend our days at the Capitol working to advance our common cause. By pooling our resources, we will be able to hire professionals to represent us and work toward our goals, we can ensure that our voice is truly heard by every lawmaker in Utah.

Finding committed bill sponsors, attending committee meetings, building coalitions and organizing public support/opposition are just a few of the critical functions that can be performed by a well trained, full time liberty advocate.

The vast majority of lobbyists are hired by relatively small, well funded organizations whose interests are promoted at the expense of the rest of us. Ours will be funded by, and accountable to, those of us who want nothing more than a government that respects our lives, liberties and property.

This is the first step in many toward a freer, more prosperous Utah. 

What We Need & What You Get

The more money we are able to raise, the more professional advocates we can afford to hire. The more representation we have, the greater success we are likely to have in reaching our goals.

The Impact

We want all residents of Utah to be free to live, work and play in whatever peaceful way they choose. We do not want smaller government, we want small government. We do not want freer markets, we want free markets. We do not want government planning and regulation of our personal lives, we want the freedom to be responsible for our ownselves.
 
If you share these principles and goals, consider making a donation, or a series of donations, to our cause. None of us can do this alone but all of us can do it together.

This is the first step in many toward a freer, more prosperous Utah. 

What We Need & What You Get
The more money we are able to raise, the more professional advocates we can afford to hire. The more representation we have, the greater success we are likely to have in reaching our goals.

The Impact
We want all residents of Utah to be free to live, work and play in whatever peaceful way they choose. We do not want smaller government, we want small government. We do not want freer markets, we want free markets. We do not want government planning and regulation of our personal lives, we want the freedom to be responsible for our ownselves.
 
If you share these principles and goals, consider making a donation, or a series of donations, to our cause. None of us can do this alone but all of us can do it together.

story:
Hi, my name is Betsy and I am the CEO of the Centre for Creativity and Enterprise, a charity and collective of over 250 artists and crafters. 

Here at the Centre, we work with women with mental and physical health issues who live with multiple and complex disadvantages. 

  • We teach our ladies new creative skills. 
  • We help them create networks.
  • We teach them about starting their own businesses

And our ladies learn how to combat poverty and disadvantage through creative entrepreneurship. The result is social inclusion, self sufficiency and an enormous amount of self-respect.

We have a beautiful new gallery space and showroom and big plans for really enhancing the courses and support we bring to our community. 

We need your help to make our space fit to carry out our ambitious new plans.

We need to build a partition in our large gallery/showroom that will give us a dedicated room for our training courses & meeting space.

Training Courses=Income=Continued Support For Our Vulnerable Ladies.

The equation is simple. We need £3000 to build the partition and make it fit for purpose with all the things that a 21st Century meeting room/training space should provide (e.g. projector and Wi-Fi).

We are one of a kind in our community and home to work by over 250 artists, makers and photographers.  We deliver ferocious festivals and events in our town. We are a community and work hard together to improve creativity and to enhance the cultural capital of Ashford.   

Our partition means that more than 500 women per year and over 100 children and young people will be able to use the space and learn new creative skills.

Please be part of our equation! We are grateful for all contributions including those of donated materials and time. If you think that you can support us in another way, give us a shout!

story:
HVALA VAM!

Od srca zahvaljujemo svima na (strpljivom) sudjelovanju u projektu izrade i tiskanja slikovnice "Roda kojoj je trebala pomoć"!

Svaki pojedinačni doprinos je omogućio da se ovaj projekt realizira i slikovnica ugleda svjetlost dana.  Sigurni smo da će slikovnica doprinijeti u razbijanju tabua i predrasuda u našem društvu. 

Hvala što ste uvijek uz nas!

Želimo vam ugodno čitanje u društvu najmlađih <3  
Tvoja udruga Roda

 

***********************************************************************

PLEASE SCROLL DOWN FOR ENGLISH

 

PRIČA O RODI KOJOJ JE TREBALA POMOĆ

Najčešće pitanje koje čujemo od MPO roditelja je:
Kako objasniti djeci, na njima razumljiv način, što je MPO?

 

Neplodnost i tema medicinski potpomognute oplodnje sadrže mnoštvo kompliciranih i novih pojmova, medicinskih postupaka i dijagnoza pa se i sami roditelji jedva snalaze u toj temi. Već duže vrijeme gajimo ideju o slikovnici za najmlađe pomoću koje će roditelji djetetu moći, na veseo i djeci razumljiv i prihvatljiv način, ispričati svoj MPO put, svoje odluke i svoju borbu da dođu do čarobnog trenutka.

U Hrvatskoj je preko 30 000 djece rođeno nakon MPO postupaka
te smatramo da je vrijeme da i ona dobiju svoju slikovnicu! 

 

PRVA SLIKOVNICA U HRVATSKOJ I REGIJI
NAMIJENJENA DJECI ROĐENOJ
NAKON POSTUPAKA MPO

 

Slikovnicom želimo djeci rođenoj nakon postupaka medicinski potpomognute oplodnje približiti njihov put na ovaj svijet. Kada djecu od malih nogu učimo da postoje različiti načini da postanemo roditelji, ta činjenica postaje dio njih, time ih osnažujemo da se nose s mogućim izazovima i situacijama koje MPO teme mogu donijeti.

Učeći ih da može drugačije, a da je zapravo isto, učimo ih i da samo zato što je netko drugačiji ne znači da se s njim treba drugačije i ophoditi. Dijete koje prihvaća svoje različitosti, lakše će prihvatiti različitosti drugih i uvažavati ih.

 

"KAKO SI STAO U EPRUVETU?!"

Jedno od nadahnuća za kretanje u ovakav projekt nam je i naš Robert Veriga, prva IVF beba u Hrvatskoj, koji je ove godine napunio 35.godina te njegovi hrabri roditelji - Dragica i Josip. Robert je odrastao sa informacijom da je IVF beba i rado je odgovarao na sva pitanja svojih vršnjaka. 

 

Zahvaljujući trudu svojih roditelja da mu objasne MPO,
znao je odgovore čak i na ona samo djeci svojstvena pitanja: 
“ A kako si ti to 9 mjeseci rastao u epruveti? ” :)

 

TO ŽELIMO ZA SVAKU MPO OBITELJ!

Dijete koje odrasta oboružano znanjem koje će ga osnaživati i pomoći
u kontaktu s predrasudama i stigmom u daljnjem životu.

 

 

 

PODRŽI KAMPANJU I DONIRAJ!

Za tiskanje 500 komada slikovnica s tvrdim uvezom,
potrebno nam je 4850$!

 

Većinu slikovnica tiskamo za donacije u knjižnice i vrtiće koji su izrazili interes za našom slikovnicom, a dio će se podijeliti kao nagrada za donacije (perk) u ovoj kampanji.  Sve preostale slikovnice će biti na raspolaganju svima koji u Rodi potraže pomoć i informacije o neplodnosti.

 

KAKO NAS JOŠ MOŽETE PODRŽATI

I najmanji iznos je velika pomoć, no razumijemo da nisu svi u situaciji da financijski doprinesu našoj kampanji. Pozivamo vas da ovaj projekt podržite i na druge načine:

  • Podijelite link na kampanju s drugim MPO obiteljima

  • Podijelite kampanju na svojim društvenim mrežama jer svaki share širi priču o ovom lijepom i pozitivnom projektu

  • Ostavite nam komentar potpore na stranici kampanje ili Facebook stranici

Bit ćemo vam zahvalni za svaki način kojim doprinesete većem uspjehu ove kampanje! <3

 

 

Mi smo volonterke programa Reproduktivna prava, područje NEPLODNOST - medicinski potpomognuta oplodnja, u udruzi Roda - Roditelji u akciji.

Jedina smo udruga koja se aktivno bavi zastupanjem prava neplodnih osoba u Hrvatskoj. U svom volonterskom radu, često se susrećemo s predrasudama i netočnim informacijama o neplodnosti i o načinima liječenja neplodnosti. No, ono što nas svaki put najviše zaboli su predrasude i netočne informacije o najmlađima - djeci rođenoj nakon postupaka medicinski potpomognute oplodnje - a nada nam je da s vremenom takve predrasude nestanu, a čemu će, uvjerene smo, i ova slikovnica pomoći.

Naša područja rada u udruzi: Senzibiliziranje javnosti na problem medicinski potpomognute oplodnje, informiranje i educiranje osoba s problemom neplodnosti, pritisak na mjerodavne institucije za proširenje prava pacijenata i pacijentica suočenih s problemom neplodnosti, pritisak na zakonodavce i aktivnosti za mijenjanje i donošenje kvalitetnog Zakona o medicinski potpomognutoj oplodnji, te rješavanje ostalih problema vezanih uz neplodnost.

 

**************

Help a Stork Out - Crowdfunding Campaign

for MAR (IVF) Families

 

 

Since July, a team of volunteers from the Medically Assisted Fertility project at Roda - Parents in Action have been working on first ever storybook on medically assisted fertility in Croatia and the region, written for children who were born after MAR and their friends. The story has been written, and it's time to share it with MAR families and their loved ones.

To produce and print 500 copies of The Stork Who Needed Help, a portion of which will be donated to libraries and kindergartens, we need to raise 4850 USD in our Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign.

Support our volunteers' hard work by contributing to the campaign to create the first Croatian children's book that describes how MAR babies came into this world to children in a fun and relatable way.

When we teach children that there are many ways to become a parent, they understand and accept it early on. In doing this we empower them to deal with challenges they may encounter when discussing MAR with friends. By teaching them that they came into this world in a different, but equally miraculous way, we also teach them that it is ok to be different and to accept the difference we experience in others.

This campaign was prepared by Roda's volunteers, BLANK-incubator and Maja Benčić aka Fritula. We are especially proud that Robert Veriga, the first IVF baby in Croatia (and 7th in the world!) is a campaign supporter.

 

The Stork Who Needed Help - a storybook for families who have experienced MAR and their friends!

 

You can help support this project in a number of ways:

  • Financially, by choosing one of the perks or donating the amount of your choice to the campaign through Indiegogo
  • By sharing the campaign with MAR families and their loved ones
  • By sharing the campaign on your own social media channels - every share helps raise awareness about MAR and our storybook
  • By leaving a supportive comment for our volunteers on the campaign's page

 

Please keep in mind that Roda will not accept donations from manufacturers and distributors of products that are included in the International Code on the Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes. If we receive such a donation, it will be returned to the account the payment originated from.

 

For any additional info about Roda or this campaign, please contact us at ured@roda.hr or via telephone +385 1 6177500

story:
Who Is Patrick McCollum?

Reverend Patrick McCollum is for now one of the best kept secrets in our world. Very few know that not only is he an interfaith chaplain and Wiccan Priest who carries the knowledge of the "Old Way," he has also been honored by spiritual leaders in many spiritual circles around the world.

Patrick has been named the "World Inner Peace Ambassador" by Buddhist spiritual leaders in Thailand. He was an honored guest speaker at the World Culture Forum in Kazakstan 2010 where he spoke to political and spiritual leaders from over 80 countries on the importance of our harmonious connection with Nature and with each other. He has been recognized as a Saint in India and given the name 'Babaji', meaning 'Revered Father.' He has also been honored as the 'King of Peace' by renowned Tibetan Buddhist Rinpoche's in our world. He is known by Native Americans as, "He Who Speaks With the Mother" due to his work to secure indigenous sacred sites and his advocacy on behalf of native populations. In 2011 he was honored with receiving the Mahatma Gandhi Award for Religious Pluralism. He hand constructed a violin, which has been declared by the United Nations to be the 'World Peace Violin' and he has been invited to share it at the UN's International Peace Day next fall. Last January, Patrick was invited to lead the opening prayer at the Maha Kumba Mela in India, a spiritual gathering that attracted over 100 million people. 

Patrick is quickly becoming one of the foremost voices in our world on the topics of creating world peace and sustaining all people. His message inspires audiences to recognize our inherent interconnection through a common narrative, which gives us greater access to envisioning and creating a common goal: a world that works for everyone. He is changing the world by creating peace bridges between countries and people, inspiring youth, working to support women's rights, and religious equality around the world.

What is this opportunity?

Sri Tathata, a great spiritual leader in India, has asked Patrick to be one of the primary facilitators at the MahaYaha, a 6-day event of rituals and prayers designed to create world peace. The intention of this ritual is to shift the course and consciousness of our planet.

This is a revival of an ancient and sacred Hindu ritual called the MahaYaga, which is written about in the Vedas and goes back many thousands of years. This ritual was stopped a couple thousand years ago and is only now being re-created.

In addition to facilitating the ritual itself, Patrick has been asked to be a keynote speaker both as an individual and at a round table with some of the foremost religious and political leaders from around the world where the topic is world peace, women's issues and planetary sustainability.

The MahaYaga is expected to draw 4 to 10 million people as well as the BBC, the World Press and many other similar organizations. Learn more here http://www.mahayaga.org/mahayaga/

Why are we asking for financial support?

While Patrick's service and presence at this powerful event is clearly of high value, the organizers of the MahaYaga do not have the financial means to provide for his airfare or for his team of assistants, security and videography during his stay in India. Our desire is not only to get him there, but to insure his safe travels and maximize the outreach of the important messages he has to share.

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $10,800 for this trip. What this would afford us are 4 round-trip tickets to India for Patrick and his support staff at approximately $1800 to $2000 per ticket, and a remaining $2800- $3600 budget to hire security, a translator, a videographer, and have some money for other travel expenses. If we receive more than our funding needs, the extra money will go towards the cost of editing the audio, video and photos that are captures in this trip to make them available to all of you!

Everyone who gives at any level will receive a letter of thanks hand-signed by Patrick McCollum. They will also have their name included in the credits of any digital product made out of this trip, and they will receive a recording of the live conference call where they will be among the first to hear the highlights of the trip.

Everyone who gives $100 or more will have their names included in the credits on any digital product made out of this trip and will be invited to participate in a live conference call with Patrick to hear about the highlights of the trip.

Everyone who gives $500 or more will be highlighted in the credits associated with digital products made out of this trip and will be given the opportunity to speak directly with Patrick on the live conference call.

Everyone who gives $1000 or more will receive everything above plus a personal Skype session with Patrick (lasting 30-45 minutes) to receive spiritual guidance and blessings.

We have special gifts designed by Patrick McCollum (who is also an award-winning professional leather and jewelry designer) for people who wish to give at a level of $5000 or more. For more information, please contact Patrick's Executive Assistant, Katrina Vaillancourt, at katrina@patrickmccollumfoundation.org.

The Impact

Your donation to this project is a donation to history in the making. We are at a critical time on our planet where every effort towards peace is critical to the outcome that we so desperately desire.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have money to share, but you've got friends, please spread the word! Join our email list at www.patrickmccollum.org. If you've got skills or other kinds of resources, please let us know. We are all in this together! All forms of support are received with gratitude!

We are aiming to raise $10,800 for this trip. What this would afford us are 4 round-trip tickets to India for Patrick and his support staff at approximately $1800 to $2000 per ticket, and a remaining $2800- $3600 budget to hire security, a translator, a videographer, and have some money for other travel expenses. If we receive more than our funding needs, the extra money will go towards the cost of editing the audio, video and photos that are captures in this trip to make them available to all of you!
Everyone who gives at any level will receive a letter of thanks hand-signed by Patrick McCollum. They will also have their name included in the credits of any digital product made out of this trip, and they will receive a recording of the live conference call where they will be among the first to hear the highlights of the trip.
Everyone who gives $100 or more will have their names included in the credits on any digital product made out of this trip and will be invited to participate in a live conference call with Patrick to hear about the highlights of the trip.
Everyone who gives $500 or more will be highlighted in the credits associated with digital products made out of this trip and will be given the opportunity to speak directly with Patrick on the live conference call.
Everyone who gives $1000 or more will receive everything above plus a personal Skype session with Patrick (lasting 30-45 minutes) to receive spiritual guidance and blessings.
We have special gifts designed by Patrick McCollum (who is also an award-winning professional leather and jewelry designer) for people who wish to give at a level of $5000 or more. For more information, please contact Patrick's Executive Assistant, Katrina Vaillancourt, at katrina@patrickmccollumfoundation.org.


The ImpactYour donation to this project is a donation to history in the making. We are at a critical time on our planet where every effort towards peace is critical to the outcome that we so desperately desire. 

Other Ways You Can HelpIf you don't have money to share, but you've got friends, please spread the word! Join our email list at www.patrickmccollum.org. If you've got skills or other kinds of resources, please let us know. We are all in this together! All forms of support are received with gratitude!

JUSTICE FOR LEVI account # 14629
 
WE WANT JUSTICE FOR OUR COMMUNITIES, NOT POLICE IMPUNITY.

This is a story about people deciding to take action to make sure that governments and that police are accountable to the people in Canada.

Summary

 The Coalition was formed after the police killing of Levi Schaeffer to create a supportive personal and political network of solidarity for the Schaeffer family as they joined forces with the Minty family.  The families asked Ontario’s Courts to look at whether the systemic police actions of lawyer note vetting and joint lawyer retainers pursued as internal policy by the O.P.P. during S.I.U. investigations were -or were not permitted within the law laid out in Police Services Act and legislation regarding police and oversight.  The families won a unanimous decision at Ontario’s highest court in November, 2011.  The decision laid out with great clarity that the police actions in question were not permitted by law and could not be permitted without greatly jeopardizing the legitimacy of investigations, breaching necessary segregation laws and threatening the sanctity of police notes used by police in courts as they appear for the crown as state witnesses.  Unhappy with the decision that they must follow the law, the police are now taking the families to the Supreme Court of Canada. We need support so that we can support by helping to pay off family legal bills and to pay logistical costs involved with going to Supreme Court.

 

The Story

Maybe it’s hard to imagine… but Imagine living in a country where police can do anything- even kill you or your loved ones, but do not bear appropriate consequences because they are impune. Imagine living in a country where police can function outside of the laws that bind the common people, outside of the scope of independent oversight or outside the reach of the courts of our justice system.  Imagine, just for a moment, a Canada where police live by special, extrajudicial, internal laws, paid by the public but operating outside the realm of civilian law, much as the military does.

Police officers are public employees- paid to serve and protect- to enforce laws, to keep the public peace, and to safeguard against criminality.  They have special responsibilities- such as acting as state witnesses in our courts of law and special rights- such as the right to bear arms and use force- including lethal force- on members of the public. These special rights and responsibilities given to police officers must be subjected to a very high level of oversight, inquiry and transparency to ensure the Canadian public that its police and its justice system are functioning responsibly, accountably and to the standards of a proud democracy.

Perhaps the most important thing police officers do is complete their notes by the end of their shift.   Though this might sound trivial compared to chasing robbers and saving lives- it is an officer’s notes that lay the foundation of evidence, investigation and witnessing as members of the public come into contact with police and are brought through the Canadian justice system.  Legislation and acts related to police make it clear that police notes must be written independently (without consulting with anyone else) and contemporaneously (as soon as possible after an occurrence).

In September 2009, an Ontario family whose son was killed by police that June came to realized the incredible importance of police notes. The director of the Special Investigations Unit, Ontario’s independent police oversight body- revealed that officers involved in the death of Levi Schaeffer completed their notes days after his death and all officers involved in the case submitted notes to the S.I.U. which had been reviewed and vetted by a singular lawyer for the Ontario Provincial Police Association. The Schaeffer family combined efforts with Minty family who also lost their son Douglas to police action and went, with their lawyers to asked Ontario’s courts to interpret the Police Services Act and other relevant legislation and to determine whether police lawyer note vetting was or was not  permitted within the law. 

  On November 15th, 2011- The Ontario Superior Court of Appeal released its unanimous decision in which it clarified that police officers could, of course, contact their lawyer for general legal advice but that they could not postpone writing their notes or handing them in for the S.I.U. until after their lawyer has checked and approved them.  The decision spelled out that the personal interests of an officer for self protection or protection of another member of the force, or of the force- must be understood as secondary to the sworn duty that an officer has as a public employee and professional state witness. Lawyer vetting of police notes could obstruct the well functioning of all levels of our justice system.

 Unsatisfied with the courts decision, police interests now take these matters and these grieving families to the Supreme Court of Canada where police lawyers are prepared to argue that the decision laid out by Ontario’s highest court is ‘unworkable’.

 On April 19th, 2013  Canada’s highest court will hear arguments and in the months that follow- render a decision- that will establish once and for all whether police in Canada- will be allowed to function from a special law- unfettered by accountability standards, legislation or the will of the public.

It is both absurd and obscene it has been left to the efforts and the pocket books of two Ontario families to insist that enormous systemic problems of impunity and lacking accountability be resolved. They continue, knowing that there can be no justice for their dead, but that there can be justice for the living… if we act fearlessly to insist that we want justice for our communities, not police impunity.

 

JUSTICE FOR LEVI IN THE NEWS!!!!

An article about this case publshed in the Toronto Star, the Calgary Herald and others.

By: Colin Perkel The Canadian Press, Published on Fri Apr 19

Only two weeks left for our Indiegogo fundraising campaign... Help crowd source a thank you to the families by helping to pay off one small chunk of the legal bills... Let's Stop Police Impunity.
Supreme Court to hear arguments about whether police under investigation can have lawyers vet notes.
www.thestar.com
Whether police officers under investigation by a civilian watchdog can have a lawyer help them prepare their notes finds its way to the Supreme Court of Canada.

 

The Fundraising Campaign

Along with lending support to the families and coordinating education and solidarity efforts, the Coalition Justice For Levi exists in order to help raise legal funds.  It is absurd that it has been left to the efforts and to the pocket books of two grieving Ontario families to bring a widespread, systemic, governmental mess to light and to seek firm resolution through the courts.   For many, many long years, the Office of the Attorney General of Ontario, the Special Investigations Unit, police associations, Ontario’s courts and Ontario’s justices have all been embrangled in a dispute and conflict.  Each of the aforementioned parties is funded by taxpayers and each is, in fact, a public employee.  Each of these parties has a substantial budget and each one has an obligation to meet their mandates as funded by the public and to assure the greatest level of transparency, efficiency and accountability possible.  Where the resources and responsibility to address these matters do exist within the mechanism of the state, the cohesive political will necessary to finally and clearly resolve this systemic mess does not. 

The Coalition Justice For Levi is helping with fundraising efforts because grieving families should not be forced into the poorhouse as they seek the courts’ assistance to resolve these systemic matters.   The Coalition Justice For Levi is helping to raise legal funds, as well, because the outcomes of this historic court case are of great impact and relevance to the greater public interest.

Who is the Coalition Justice For Levi?

The Coalition Justice for Levi is a small group of family members, friends and community members who have directly lost loved ones to unaccountable police violence with a support circle of grassroots prison, policing and mental health organizers and media activists who work to help ensure not only that this particular story gets out but that it functions as a platform for directly linking problems of systemic police lack of accountability to struggles across communities particularly affected by unaccountable or abusive policing.  

Like so many others killed by police, Levi Schaeffer and Douglas Minty were both men who suffered their whole lives from extreme mental health challenges and the associated poverty, stigmatization and criminalization.  An overwhelming number of police killings relate to low income victims and their adjoining low income families who often spend all savings to bury their dead. And the links between poverty and race and gender and sexuality and ability and age… are all too clear.   The Coalition works to empower an opportunity for the people most directly affected- the mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers and lovers of those killed to lead a struggle to affirm the right of all peoples to insist that legal frameworks exist to ensure police do not have unfettered powers. The long history of police targeting of low income, racialized, stigmatized communities reveals a particular necessity to ensure that it is those very voices receiving support to come together and say NO MORE.

What is this funding for?

The Coalition Justice For Levi is hoping to offer direct logistical needs funding to family members as they go to Ottawa for the Supreme Court of Canada.   We are hoping to relieve the stress of self-funding bus trips, hotel stays, food, in city travel and incidentals for family members by taking on the bill.

All funding, aside from these logistical costs, will go towards helping to pay off a portion of owing and accruing legal bills.  

 It has been a long and arduous battle since the deaths of their sons, and the Schaeffer and Minty families have paid dearly.  Help repay them for their efforts and determination by making a donation or by sharing this campaign so that they do not have to bare the costs alone of daring to insist that police be held to account.

 

Other ways you can help

*Indy-go-go campaign.  Help to share and highlight this campaign

*Help to share our new 2 minute fundraising video created for this campaign

*Publish the J4L story/fundraising appeal on your website (and put up link to www.justiceforlevi.org), in newsletters, in community publications… and ask your allies to do so as well

*Pass on info about this campaign to any friendly media sources

*SAVE THE DATE:  APRIL 19th 2013 ….we will need people writing, tweeting and posting on the day that we go to Supreme Court to make sure that this important day does not go unnoticed

*Link this campaign each time that you deal with police-related issues… Help us make it very clear that we are dealing with issues of systemic police impunity, not a series of bad apple scenarios

*Screen “We Want Justice for Our Communities, Not Police Impunity”, our 15 minute educational youtube video at a meeting, an event etc…  or play the audio on radio shows

*Learn more and share what you learn by checking our www.justiceforlevi.org

*Send words of encouragement to info@justiceforlevi.org

story:
Overview

BlockChain Development Community and New Cyber Frontier Announce a Public Blockchain to Increase Individual Privacy

The BlockChain Development Community (BCDC), is a group of blockchain experts, cybersecurity experts, computer science experts, mathematicians, PhD researchers, and many other brilliant minds that are collaborating on a new technology breakthrough. We have built solutions for distributed ledger technology that combine many strengths of existing technologies and other platforms. Many of the blockchain platforms that are popular and well-adopted today, have huge weaknesses, and limitations, such as Bitcoin consuming more energy than the entire nation of Switzerland every day. We have built a framework that solves all the current limiting factors that blockchains are facing, and will be facing in the future. This will also enable a marketplace that can range from an average Joe participating from his home computer, all the way to businesses, pre-existing blockchain apps, government uses, and even artificial intelligence.

Colorado Senate Bill SB18-086 was signed into law in May 2018, with broad bi-partisan support, to apply blockchain technologies for better security to state records. Since then, more than 220 group members, and 30+ software developers have been building a blockchain/distributed ledger to meet Colorado requirements. It resolves many limiting design issues present on early technology public blockchains, and supports secure, indefinitely-scalable global marketplace.  The platform developed by this effort is now ready for initial public release. 

BCDC members have volunteered thousands of hours of development time, often with their own facilities, computers, and money to produce an open platform without large corporate sponsorship.  Now it's time to speed up the delivery process to release  a secure service for individuals' digital privacy rights. Internet users are often the prey for predators and highly funded cyber-attacks from sources such as criminals, hackers, and nation states, which have billions of dollars at their disposal to exploit you. BCDC is seeking $500,000 from crowd-source funding to support the completion of its next development phase. We are seeking funding from the community, in order to support digital privacy rights for everybody.

Further information can be found on our website:

www.privacyforthepeople.org

www.bc-dc.org.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking your help to allow us to fund the continued development of the BCDC public marketplace blockchain. Currently, BCDC has been operating on volunteer work, and with the funding donated by you, we will be able to expedite the process of protecting your privacy, PRIVACY IS EVERYTHING!

This next step of delivery will enable development to move from our prototyping environment to the open marketplace. The world needs this technology.

While the first perk is a way to show support, and we are thrilled to have it, the higher tiers have more tangible value to the project, and would bring more to the project. With higher tiers of funding, rewards range from public branding and partnership status, to worldwide promotions on our partner's show, "New Cyber Frontier."

The funds will go directly into building marketplace infrastructure, refining the platform where businesses and individuals are empowered to thrive. This will have great impact to the economic development within the security and privacy industries, allowing for many new technologies, startups, and streamlining of existing businesses. All of these new types of solutions will be in high-demand, high-paying technology industry jobs. These benefits will ripple across the ecosystem, increasing needs for education, training, and many other supporting industries.

The Impact

If you value your privacy and the privacy of your loved ones in the digital world, then you will want to get involved, please donate. Every dollar will move the world closer to the goal of a privacy empowered online landscape. With each donation, you make your voice heard. You are saying: "We are taking back control of our own privacy online. We are the owners and controllers of our own digital content. We are tired of our digital identity being traded like a commodity. We are tired of big companies disrespecting our basic human rights. We are tired of not having a voice. This ends now."


We are offering a solution to those willing to stand up for the people. We need the funding support from the people, to provide a marketplace to be governed by the people.


Make your voice heard.

Risks & Challenges

The BCDC team is dedicated, and willing to tackle any challenges or leap over any hurdles. For over two years now, brilliant minds from various backgrounds have collaborated, all sharing a vision for a system that will allow the people to work together as a trusting community. We are doctorates, developers, economists, scientists, but most importantly, we are people.

With a new data breach seemingly every other week, it is only a matter of time before you are exposed, if you haven't been already. This is affecting everyone, not just the layman, but even celebrities, leaders, and CEOs. Your information is out there on some database, just ready and willing to be compromised at any second. 

Our largest challenge that we face is the adoption of a platform globally. However, we are aware that starting with something small and effective, will gain ground by its own merits. Our challenge will be the awareness, and building the community of trust, which starts with you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people may not be able to afford to contribute, and we get that! We know that money isn't everything. You can still help us out by sharing our page and spreading the word of our cause! Please utilize the share tools provided by Indiegogo to make our audience as large as possible. The simple act of sharing and spreading news of our effort, is far more valuable than money, and the premise of how we began in the first place.

The BlockChain Development Community thanks you!

The BlockChain Development Community thanks you!

story:
We are a group of Americans and Haitian Americans who have lived and worked in Haiti for over 20+ years, and are committed to Haiti becoming a developed nation.  We have seen billions of dollars donated to Haiti over the years and yet Haiti remains the poorest nation in the western hemisphere. 80% of Haiti’s people live in poverty and 54% in abject poverty. Our programs provide the training and coaching essential to formulating and executing projects for community and business groups that call people forth to committed action. Develop Haiti empowers people to produce extraordinary results and accomplish remarkable leadership skills.

Since January 2012, nearly five-hundred Haitian citizens have been trained through Develop Haiti’s transformational programs.  This new core of leaders is poised to start transforming Haiti by taking responsibility for their own lives, their communities and their country.  They are now providing great leadership in their communities.

But more trained leaders are needed.  Our next leadership course in December, 2013, will train community leaders, business leaders, and government officials in responsibility, integrity and leadership.

A few of the projects taken on by participants after completing our leadership courses:

One project was formed by a group of 25 women for what they called commerce.  They met weekly and each week these woman brought $4.  Each week, one woman got all of this money to do commerce.  Commerce means they might buy a product in bulk and then resell it in smaller quantities for a profit.  This was so successful that they have started new groups for other women and men.  This first group of women started a tree nursery after someone gave them 1000 bags to plant trees.

One man wanted a road between two villages.  In his words:  “ We initially enrolled 69 people to volunteer to work on the road and now there are a total of 85.  We have made progress in widening the road and we are continuing to work.  We lack the tools to do more.  Through working with Neil (A Develop Haiti person on the ground in Haiti) we  learned about the Leadership Program.  Before this Program, I would not know how to enroll 69 much less 85 people.  Before, I used to make empty promises to get people to participate and to come along.  Now I can talk to them and not promise anything and the work gets done. Then, when we are done for the day, what we have is not that lie I said but we have the satisfaction of a job well done and pride in our work.”  This project was successful, it was noticed by the local authorities, and the government joined in to complete the project.

We are raising funds for scholarships for our next program to be held on the central plateau in Haiti.  We are committed that people are able to participate even if they don't have the means to pay

We appreciate everyone’s generous donations for the training of the future leaders of Haiti.  For your donations, you will receive unique crafts made in Haiti.

If you are unable to contribute now, you can still help. Share our link on Facebook at our Develop Haiti site.  Share us with your friends and family. Thank you for reading our campaign.

story:
Make a direct impact in Silicon Valley workers.

Do you know Michael Johnson? Like many hard working security officers in Silicon Valley, Michael struggled for years to get by on the wages he earned at Universal Protection Service (UPS). Choosing between life's basic necessities has been a daily dilemma, despite working for a security contractor in the heart of the Silicon Valley That's why he stood up alongside his fellow security officers to raise standards at his worksite and in his community. But last month, UPS removed Michael from his post and “offered” him a job that would havecut his wages by 32 percent. Now Michael is on-call, and UPS hasn’t been calling. 

Michael and his co-workers need your support to continue the fight for Silicon Valley service workers.

Help organize:

  • Every dime raised will directly support workers like Michael, who have been the victim of workplace retaliation and loss of income.
  • For every $3,000 raised, we can support the organizing efforts for two months, and Michael can talk to more workers.
This will help all Silicon Valley workers rise up for a better future, for all of us.

story:
CORELUV'S DREAM

Coreluv’s dream is to bring the hope of Jesus Christ to orphans by partnering with communities and orphanages around the world to provide 6 basic needs: clean water, proper food, healthcare, education, job skills and a loving home.

Why do we take orphan care so seriously? James 1:27 reads, “Pure and genuine religion in the sight of God the Father means caring for orphans and widows.”  We believe this scripture is not merely a suggestion but a commandment; something the Church must rise up and do.  Unless someone defends the orphan, they are defenseless.  Unless someone speaks for them they will not be heard.  We choose to defend them, speak for them, and challenge others to do the same.

THE GROWTH OF CORELUV

June 2011: After 15 years of full time pastoral ministry Mandy and myself (Mike, Coreluv founders) were in transition, yet we had no idea what God would have us do next.  While we had been asking God for direction for over a year; in a Spirit led night of prayer He in turn asked us, “will you spend your lives defending the orphan” and “do you know the name of an orphan?”

The question then became, how do we defend the orphan?  The next day I called a spiritual mentor, Doug Stringer, where I told him about my breakthrough and asked what he thought?  Doug was encouraged and said, “you are a day late, you better get going.”  He then asked, “are there any places on your mind?” I replied, “I have a couple places on my heart, one being Haiti.”  Doug said, “I have a trip scheduled in two weeks, would you like to go?”  I said, “yes.”

June 2011: On that initial trip to the disaster-stricken country of Haiti, we visited seven orphanages and met with several pastors who were desperately seeking help in providing for fatherless children. At one of the orphanages we met MyLove, a beautiful young girl who Mandy and I are in the process of adopting!  One orphanage that broke my heart could only provide one meal of a handful of rice a day.  After meeting these children who were literally fighting for their lives, it became clear God’s mandate to defend the orphan.  We felt led by the Lord to partner with our first orphanage in Gonaives, Haiti, that at the time was struggling to provide for 12 children.  Since that initial partnership we have leased a home for them and are now providing the six basic needs for 29 orphans!  We decided to forsake the American Dream and leave our comfortable career in order for Coreluv to be birthed! 

MyLove, our daughter that we are in the process of adopting

While in Haiti a couple months later, God asked me to find land and build an orphanage.  At first I was in disbelief, we had just partnered with an orphanage and a feeding center, and by faith were providing for their needs; where was the money going to come from to buy a piece of land and build an orphanage?

March 2012: On the next trip, I was sitting with an individual who said he would match any donations to Coreluv up to $50,000.  The miracles continued when I met a Haitian pastor, Nathan, who felt led to give me 12 acres of land to help further Coreluv’s vision.  After a 30 minute truck ride we found ourselves on the land of Myan worshiping and giving thanks to God for the property He had provided. Words cannot describe as Heaven met earth, and we began to dream of all the orphans we could rescue.

May 2012: We launched our $50,000 match campaign where all funds raised in May were matched dollar-for-dollar.  Our team of volunteers worked tirelessly as we organized fundraising events and speaking engagements.  We were blessed to raise the $50,000 and have it matched to $100,000 which allowed us to continue to provide for our orphanage in Gonaives and start to dream in Myan.

July 2012: After acquiring the land in Myan we began to build relationships with the community of Myan by digging a water well, the well is an oasis of hope as people were walking three miles one way to get drinking water.  

The water well being dug at Myan, Haiti

August 2012: After the well, we built a community center for children to come together, learn about the Bible, play, and have community fellowship.  Once relationships were developed and we had the initial finances in place we moved straight into building the Myan Orphanage for 80 children!

Playing duck-duck-goose at the community center in Myan, Haiti 

March 2013: God said start building the Myan Orphanage!  But we did not have the needed funds, resources, or people, yet God said to build so we broke ground in faith.

May 2013: Similar to our May match in 2012, we had another match in May 2013.  This time we had matching funds of $70,000.  Through fundraising events, speaking engagements, and faithful donors we not only hit our goal of $70,000 but raised an additional $60,000!  Our total for May 2013 was $200,000 enough to finance phase 1 of the Myan Orphanage, a home for 80 orphans!

September 2013: We are launching our first Indiegogo campaign, The Nehemiah Project, to finish the Myan Orphanage by raising funds to help build a security wall.  We have a call to build the wall in order to begin bringing in children who need a loving home.

December 2013: By faith we will be able to start rescuing children as the orphanage will be complete and the wall will be built!

Soon to be home for 80 children in Myan, Haiti

THE NEHEMIAH PROJECT

The Myan Orphanage cannot be completed until we have built a security wall.  Our call is to build a wall so we can rescue children in Haiti.  We are calling our campaign The Nehemiah Project because just as Nehemiah took less than two months to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem, we believe we can raise the money needed to build our wall in Myan in less than two months!  We echo Nehemiah by declaring that we are doing a great work and cannot come down.  We must build this wall together to defend the orphan!

OUR INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN 

We are only two short months away from rescuing children and have to build a security wall.  It is the last barrier before we are able to make a home for 80 children that are in need of a family.  Our Indiegogo campaign is to raise $25,000 to build half of the wall once we raise $50,000 we can finish the wall and begin to start taking in orphans.  Simply put we have to build a wall!  Will you help us? 

We are encouraging you to help us build a wall in Myan!  With your help we can finish building a home for 80 children!  100% of what is raised will go to The Nehemiah Project.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

There are two ways to help us build a wall and start rescuing children in Haiti.

  1. Contribute to The Nehemiah Project, any amount gets us closer to finishing a home for 80 children.
  2. Share our campaign with everyone you know!  Use social media to help speak for orphans; if nobody speaks for them they won't be heard.

story:
Help Raise 30k For Kayella to get a Wheelchair Van

Kayella was born with Arthrogryposis, a genetic disorder that has given her limited mobility in her arms and legs. The limited mobility has put her in a Power Chair. It is unfortunate fact that with the Power chair that gives her freedom to get around needs a van that cost upward of $30,000 to go places, like the Zoo, Mall, Sporting events, and of course School. 

Kayella is a beautiful 6 year old girl with a personality to match. She loves Animals, Music, Sports and Her Family. She tries hard at everything that she does. Everyone who meets her falls in love. She lights up a room when she enters. Her life has had a lot of challenges that she has met with a smile and a spunky attitude. She has come up with ideas that help her be independent. She wants to win a gold medal someday. 

 Her Family and friends have come together to raise money and have raised $3,000  so far over the past year, but they need help to get her a van that she can use to get around to the thing that she needs and wants to do. There are ways for you to help besides giving money, tell everyone you know, and have them tell everyone they know. Let's make this global and help Her get the Van She needs.

story:
Who Am I?

I am 13 years old, and recently heard about the humanitarian refugee crisis in Europe. Hundreds and thousands of people are fleeing war torn lands of Syria and Iraq.  Upon hearing and seeing pictures about the crisis, I felt a lot of sadness and wanted to do something to help. 

I live in the U.S. and live a comfortable life, without any worries. Meanwhile, these people are starving, and are without any shelter except for the tents that the Belgian government has provided for them. Winter is already setting in that part of the world. Your contribution would be an extreme help, for these people to get them started on a few basic items like food, diapers.   They will no longer have to worry as much and hopefully can get started on the life they fled for. 

What Do We Need?

I have an aunt who lives in Belgium and she has been helping the refugees firsthand and bringing them what they so direly need. 

100% of the money collected will be used by her towards providing basic necessities such as toiletries, diapers and baby food. 

What is the Impact of Your Contribution?

These refugees fled for a better life. Unfortunately, in Europe they don't have the basic needs to accomplish that self goal. It would be an incredible help to these people if you can donate.

Other Than Just Contributing, How Else Can We Help?

If a donation isn't possible right now, you can also help by spreading the word and telling others to also contribute. 

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help me get the word out so maybe your friends can help contribute.

Lets help humanity TODAY!

story:
Immediate Relief

Puerto Rico faces a massive water crisis in the wake of devastating hurricanes. See more: CNN / PBS / NBC / CBS

The solution is simple and inexpensive. 

Cultivator's Water Distribution system is based on 5-gallon "Jerrycan" water purifiers. Distribution can start immediately. Water carriers go to a site of fresh water, fill the cans and deliver to different sites, exchanging cans there. The cans can be transported by bike, car, or on foot.

Cultivator Project Management

Cultivator has partnered with the Foundation for Puerto Rico for local distribution efforts. The distribution network:

  • Prioritizes Distribution
  • Distributes Jerrycan water purification systems
  • Registers and tracks units for distribution to locations of most urgent need
  • Retrieves and redistributes units

Return on investment

A person uses about 6 liters of water per day to drink and cook. Each unit purifies 15,000 liters of water. 5,000 units would produce 75MM liters, supplying 50,000 people with 6 liters/day for 250 days.

Units cost $200 with shipping and local delivery. Therefore a liter of pure water costs only $0.0125.

vs Bottled Water

  • BOTTLED WATER - Estimated at $0.25 per liter, x 15MM liters = $3,750,000
  • JERRYCANS - Delivered, distributed and re-usable, x 15MM liters = $200,000

Budget Estimate

  • Jerrycan landed cost - $145.00
  • Distribution cost - $55.00
  • Total per unit- $200.00
  • 1,000 UNITS // 15MM LITERS // COST $200k
  • 2,000 UNITS // 30MM LITERS // COST $400k 
  • 3,000 UNITS // 45MM LITERS // COST $600k    
  • 4,000 UNITS // 60MM LITERS // COST $800k
  • 5,000 UNITS // 75MM LITERS // COST $1MM

Lifesaver Jerrycans

All systems have a easy to use, patented, built in pump system that will eliminate 99.9999% of all bacteria and 99.99% of all viruses certified to NSF P231 protocols. These systems have a built in Failsafe in that once the filters have reached end of life, NO water or biologicals will pass through the membranes. To recharge, changing the filter out is easy and can be completed in less than 30 seconds bringing the Jerrycan back to the original 15,000 liter capacity to start producing water again.

inventory is ready for deployment

THANK YOU for your generosity!

story:
Our Story

We are Martine Taylor and Elena Sorre, two intrepid American women who will be participating in Rallye Aïcha des Gazelles, an all women's automotive race across the Moroccan desert. Along the way medical caravans will journey into these remote areas where medical care is urgently needed. In fact, the race course is determined by the location of these remote villages.

This is the rally’s 28th year and we will be among the few Americans who participate. The women who take part in this rally—known as Gazelles—are of all ages, social backgrounds, nationalities and levels of off-road experience who share similar values of tolerance, solidarity and determination.

While researching  philanthropic ideas we came across the non-profit, Cœur de Gazelles. They care for approximately 5000 patients during the 9 day rally. Of those patients 194 are cared for year-round

This rally is unique in the world of motorsports, speed is not the main factor and no GPS is allowed. A manual compass, a 40 year-old topographic map and coordinates is all we will have to navigate from check point to check point. Battling the elements, road/off-road conditions in a race to be completed using the least amount of kilometers or shortest distance possible. Whether in a 4x4, Crossover, Quad, truck or motorbike, all come to take part in a unique competition.

We are looking to raise $ to cover our travel expenses and to acquire a vehicle for the race. The vehicles are obtained locally and are returned after the rally. We will be training here in the US in both navigation and dune driving  as well as acquiring safety gear for the competition. We are committed to the environment, and chose this rally because of its respect for the hosting country and its dedication to the communities in the Sahara.  It is the only women's rally with ISO 14001:2004 certification.

For more event info visit: http://www.rallyeaichadesgazelles.com/en/

For more info on the medical caravan visit: http://www.coeurdegazelles.org

 

The Process

We are raising money to help us get to the rally but we need your help. We need to raise $11,000 to cover expenses for:

  • navigation training
  • off road/desert driving instruction
  • vehicle recovery training
  • rally registration fees

A large portion of the rally’s registration fee goes to support the medical units, the Coer du Gazelles, that distribute healthcare to the desert communities within the rally.

We need to raise an additional $17,000 to cover: 

  • a rally ready vehicle fully insured
  • transportation from the US to Morocco
  • safety gear
  • camping gear
  • additional vehicle supplies/helmets (safety rated)

We will provide the the determination, the dedication, the commitment to the communities our participation helps to support. Coming together and working together we can accomplish great things. But first we need your help.

 

Why We're Doing It

I remember seeing them through the bus window as we were winding up the muddied hillside. At first I thought it was a row of oxen, but as we got closer I could tell that it was about 15 women all walking single file. What was so remarkable was that each woman was carrying several stones on their head, the weight of which I could not imagine carrying up a slippery, wet hill, let alone a dry one. These women were helping to build a road so supplies could get to their village. This was the Philippines in 1996.

Over twenty years later that memory is still fresh, like the smell of the wet grass that coated that hill. The road these women were building was to help their community, a way to bring in goods, and medicine that is often hard to come by in very rural, third world regions.

It is for this reason we are entering the Rallye Aicha des Gazelles. The work of the Coeur de Gazelles is inspiring and selfless. Their mission puts women first knowing that by helping and supporting these local communities everyone benefits.

The Gazelles are carrying the "stones" to ensure those who need help get help. We would be honored to be a part of it.

story:
Most of us living our normal daily lives can tend to forget about those who are less fortunate. It is not hard to imagine this is especially the case during festive seasons.

In the case of Chinese New Year, families typically will gather for a big family reunion dinner. Please consider for a moment the less privileged people among us who are blind.

We would like the welcoming of this Chinese New Year, as the year of the goat, to be shared with the blind members of our society. Malaysian Foundation for the Blind intends to organize a blind people family reunion dinner event to ensure that no one will be left alone.

What We Need 

Our foundation needs donations totaling USD 1000 to make the event successful.

These donations will sponsor 100 blind attendees for a festive dinner. For a mere USD 10 per person, such an event might be a lifetime best experience for some of the participants. These acts of kindness can be expected to bring a BIG smile to their faces, and the event photos uploaded on our foundation’s website will share this happiness with you.

How you can help

You can make a huge impact for a blind person with simple actions such as making a small donation, sharing and re-tweeting our stories, or telling a friend about the campaign. Your contribution will be greatly appreciated by the blind in our community. Please help in any way you can.

Brief Introduction about Malaysian Foundation for the Blind

Malaysian Foundation for the Blind (MFB), known also as Yayasan Orang Buta Malaysia in Bahasa Malaysia, is a registered organization for providing services to the blind community in Malaysia that other blind organizations are unable to reach.

MFB focuses on empowering blind people through fostering an aptitude for technology, holistic growth, and ensuring their basic needs are met. Our ultimate goal is to create a blind community that is independent and contributes to the harmony and prosperity of families and society.

MFB caters for the welfare needs of the blind community by providing financial assistance, which involves promoting fund raising campaigns and channelling donations raised through special projects to the target recipients.

MFB strives to bring technology into the hands of the blind in order to enable them to live independently, yet technology made exclusively for the blind is often financially out of reach. We can only make life-enhancing technology available to blind people through the generosity of the public and corporate organizations. 

Thank you

story:
Short Summary

As three University of Tennessee students, we all did not have a ton of background knowledge about this issue in Knoxville. Only one of us had ever even been to the Volunteer Ministry Center before our first tour. Yet, it was clear from the very beginning why this campaign is so important. 

Homelessness is a major problem in the Knoxville community. Let me help illustrate just how large of a problem it is:

Picture this. On your average college football Saturday, around 9,000 Tennessee students file into the friendly confines of Neyland Stadium. Combined, they fill sections D, E, F, H, I, J, and K. This is certainly a large crowd, right?

For each student in this scenario, there has been a corresponding homeless person in Knoxville in the past year.

Each of these people has a chance to escape this cycle and achieve housing. The first step in that process is getting the identification they need. That's where you come in.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $1,000 for the Volunteer Ministry Center, and all of this money will go straight to our goal of providing identification for homeless persons. It is difficult to estimate how many people this would impact, as the cost varies from state to state. 

While we may not know how many people this will end up helping, the chance to help one person get off the street is more than enough. Getting one person off of the street and into housing means that they have a chance at achieving employment. That can lead to opportunities that would've never been available to them previously. 

One day, they may be able to pay it forward. 

Our goal here doesn't end with these $1,000. Our goal is to create lifelong change for people, from those who donate to those who are impacted by the donations. 

As far as short-term, we have perks for those who donate!

For all of those who donate more than $10, they will receive a shoutout on our Twitter account! @IDandGratify

The first two people who donate $25 or more will be eligible to receive a $10 Starbucks gift card if they claim one!

The first person to donate $50 or more will receive a surprise package if they choose to claim it!

Risks & Challenges

It is difficult to know exactly how many people we will help. In that way, it seems difficult to understand the scope of this campaign. Even we struggle with that. 

There are times when it feels like you are just pushing against the weight of the world and there's nothing you can do. That's how it has felt with this campaign at times, considering the scope of the problem all around us. 

Every journey begins with one single step. This is the first step, but it is not the last. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, that is totally okay! Please head over to vmcinc.org and check our their website to look for other ways to give, such as giving your time! 

As well, please share this campaign with those around you and on social media! The change we want to see can only come from people working together, and the more people that we can reach, the better!
