story:
Long story short, I ended up in Haiti for two weeks over Christmas Break partnering with Haiti Outreach Ministries (HOM) in Port-au-Prince. I expected to love it, but I had no idea that I would leave half of my heart in a third world country when I flew back to the states on January 18. I immediately began strategizing about when I could possibly go back, but had no idea that the opportunity would come so soon. I’ve prayerfully made the decision to lead a team of anyone who was willing to go over spring break and am thrilled out of my mind to be returning to the people and the country that I fell in love with in such a short amount of time. Crazy trust exercise on my end, but I have faith that the Lord will prepare the way for this time and provide what we need.

While I was there in January, I had the opportunity to teach clean water classes to adults in the community and children in one of the schools at HOM. Additionally, I helped a team that was there while I was to build a house and helped organize a new library for one of the elementary schools. When I return over spring break, we will be doing smaller construction work and painting and art projects with the elementary students. The students all attend school for free through a sponsorship program and receive an incredible education because of their sponsors, but have few opportunities for art and other hands-on activities because of a lack of supplies.

We are raising funds for all of these projects, both construction and crafts, and would be grateful for any donation you can offer. The smallest amount truly makes a difference. These donations can be money or art supplies, and will go directly to the construction work and the art projects we will be doing during our trip. While this trip cannot happen without the necessary funds, it also cannot happen without your prayers. Please pray that the Lord works in incredible and unimaginable ways and that everything would come together as He has planned. Pray for each individual on our team and each individual that we encounter in Port-au-Prince and for the relationships we will build. Finally, please pray for our hearts; that we would serve, but more than anything, that we would bow down at Jesus’ feet and listen to what he will teach us. [Luke 10:38-42] If you have taken the time to read this, thank you times a million. Your encouragement, prayer, and donations are making this trip possible.

If you are interested in learning more about HOM and their mission, see their website: http://www.haitioutreachministries.org.

If you are interested in joining me as I return to Haiti on March 22-29 or have questions about anything, please email me at lydcsmith@gmail.com.

story:
Our Story

            Did you watch the video? If so here are those details I promised you. I am currently a Graduate Student at NYU pursuing a Master’s Degree in Global Affairs with a concentration in International Law and Human Rights. This winter I have the opportunity to work with two amazing organizations for three weeks in Kigali, Rwanda. Through Global Youth Connect, an NGO, I will be participating in a Young Leaders Human Rights Delegation. Along with other international representatives I will work in collaboration with Rwandan young adults to raise awareness of and advocate for Human Rights, both regionally and globally. We will be presenting and discussing our work with governmental officials and international organizations with the intention of engaging those “big players” to enact real policy change. (Available upon request is a letter of support from the Executive Director of CYG to authentic these statements)

            My personal area of interest is in Women’s Health and Reproductive Rights. I will be partnering with a local health advocacy NGO named Health Development Initiative, which coincidently was started by a past participant of the Young Leaders Delegation. They currently have several campaigns that I cannot wait to get involved with including improving the current family-planning situation in Rwanda.  In the world of Human Rights, Reproductive Rights can be a hard torch to carry. There are no anti-ending-world-hunger campaigns or organizations that promote the continuation of genocide. Unfortunately, there are powerful forces at work to prevent women from having access to all the available options to protect their bodies and their lives. Contrary to the opposition’s assertions that Reproductive Rights advocates are only concerned with promoting and increasing abortion I am interested in ending the unsafe, unregulated and illegal operations that are happening everyday worldwide by protecting every woman’s sexual sovereignty. How? In part, by decriminalizing abortions but also by promoting female education, increasing male and female contraceptive use, financially empowering women, ending sex trafficking, ending preventable maternal mortality, persecuting and convicting every genre of rapist and sexually based war criminal...for the sake of time I’ll end there but the list of applicable actions is endless. 

            So why do I need you? There is the temptation to ask, “Aren’t you lucky, Colleen? You get to travel to Rwanda AND you want my help doing it?” Yes, the answer is yes. I am incredibly lucky to be pursuing my passion; but like just every talented artist needs an audience, every local coffee shop needs customers and every-start up co. needs investors I need a team, a team of supporters. As a full-time graduate student I have very little available funds and what I did have in my bank account has already been put towards making this a reality. All of the costs are broken down below as well as some great, what I call “purchase perks,” for you to take advantage of. If this speaks to your heart, please see your contribution as an investment in the growing movement that speaks for women worldwide, a movement for which I am eternally grateful to be a member of. If you are unable to contribute but want to be involved please be a part of my PR campaign. Tell your friends, post the links available below on Facebook or your blog, tweet, send smoke signals and stay in touch with me at Colleeninaction@gmail.com. Thank you!  


The Impact

Advocacy work, changing laws and cultural attitudes is not overnight work. I will not pretend to promise you that by January I will have accomplished any of these. However, I will work tirelessly while I am there to have an impact on HDI as an organization and help them make strides towards reaching their goals. I will apply my skills and background into promotion, module writing, education campaigns, legislative re-writes or any work they ask of me. I will broaden their network and continue to promote their work after my return. What I can guarantee you is that this experience will have an impact on me and my future work. My academic studies need to be applied, otherwise I am a theorist not an activist. No matter how informative my graduate program is I cannot achieve the level of expertise that I aspire to without working with women, NGOs, international organization, governments and opposing parties. This work in Rwanda will shape me as an advocate and practitioner. 


What I Need & What You Get

If you haven't already checked them out, my "purchase perks" are conveniently located on the right side of your screen. These are meant to involve you in this campaign since your contributions are so vital to its existence.

Where do your contributions go?

Delegation Tuition: $2,250

                                  -3 weeks of housing and transportation in Rwanda

                                  -All training sessions

                                  -Costs of coordinating with press/gov/IO/NGOs

                                  -Medical insurance

                                  -10% goes towards helping covering the cost of the Rwandan Delegates

                                  -Administrative costs of GYC


This cost I have no control over. Yes, it's pricey but without GYC, I wouldn't have this opportunity. GYC offers one tuition discount based on submitted essays and I will let every know if I am awarded the discount of $200.


Airfare: $1789 (at last check)

                                   -on Lufthansa. It was the cheapest that I could find.


Full Travel insurance: $139


This already adds up to over $4000, not to mention other costs that are bound to come up, like malaria pills for instance. I am only asking to raise $4000 because it is reasonable and achievable if I market my campaign very well. Indiegogo allows me to raise above my allotted amount in the time I have set. So, if I have huge success and contributions keep coming in I will provide a full report of every dollar spent.

Other Ways You Can Help

How else can you help? How nice of you to ask! Talk, gossip, whisper, create buzz! Seriously, talk to your friends, your family and your community. Chances are someone you love has benefited from the national protection of their Reproductive Rights either in the form of education, birth control, family planning or by bringing someone who violated their sexual sovereignty to justice. Hearing about my campaign will hopefully encourage them to check out the website, contribute and continue to spread the word! Bellow are all the links you need to share!

However, I will work tirelessly while I am there to have an impact on HDI as an organization and help them make strides towards reaching their goals. I will apply my skills and background into promotion, module writing, education campaigns, legislative re-writes or any work they ask of me. I will broaden their network and continue to promote their work after my return. What I can guarantee you is that this experience will have an impact on me and my future work. My academic studies need to be applied, otherwise I am a theorist not an activist. No matter how informative my graduate program is I cannot achieve the level of expertise that I aspire to without working with women, NGOs, international organization, governments and opposing parties. This work in Rwanda will shape me as an advocate and practitioner. 


What I Need & What You Get
If you haven't already checked them out, my "purchase perks" are conveniently located on the right side of your screen. These are meant to involve you in this campaign since your contributions are so vital to its existence.

Where do your contributions go?
Delegation Tuition: $2,250
                                  -3 weeks of housing and transportation in Rwanda
                                  -All training sessions
                                  -Costs of coordinating with press/gov/IO/NGOs
                                  -Medical insurance
                                  -10% goes towards helping covering the cost of the Rwandan Delegates
                                  -Administrative costs of GYC

This cost I have no control over. Yes, it's pricey but without GYC, I wouldn't have this opportunity. GYC offers one tuition discount based on submitted essays and I will let every know if I am awarded the discount of $200.

Airfare: $1789 (at last check)
                                   -on Lufthansa. It was the cheapest that I could find.

Full Travel insurance: $139

This already adds up to over $4000, not to mention other costs that are bound to come up, like malaria pills for instance. I am only asking to raise $4000 because it is reasonable and achievable if I market my campaign very well. Indiegogo allows me to raise above my allotted amount in the time I have set. So, if I have huge success and contributions keep coming in I will provide a full report of every dollar spent.

Other Ways You Can Help
How else can you help? How nice of you to ask! Talk, gossip, whisper, create buzz! Seriously, talk to your friends, your family and your community. Chances are someone you love has benefited from the national protection of their Reproductive Rights either in the form of education, birth control, family planning or by bringing someone who violated their sexual sovereignty to justice. Hearing about my campaign will hopefully encourage them to check out the website, contribute and continue to spread the word! Bellow are all the links you need to share!

story:
Now that our campaign is over we are still accepting donations to keep the trailer running, you can visit www.showersforall.org to maximize your contribution!

If you have donated after 12/10/19, your perk delivery may be different than the date listed below. If you donated during our active campaign, don't worry yours will be on your doorstep shortly! Thank you so much for your support!      

 

  

        We are so happy that you are here! At The Dignity Project: Rejuvenation Station we believe that people come first, that every person matters, and that we can do incredible things with great love. We are so excited about bringing a mobile shower and laundry facility to the streets of Denver. 

        As a team we have spent the last ten years with our homeless communities, hearing what their greatest needs are and cheering for their dreams. This campaign is going to provide essential access to showers and laundry for those in need. You can be a part of making that happen with us. The power of clean is boundless. 

        On any given day the Rejuvenation Station will provide over 50 loads of laundry and at least 40 showers.  Your generosity will provide these services seven days a week. Thank you so much for being here and sharing this opportunity with us.

 

What We Need & What You Get

       

     Our goal is $38,000 to build The Rejuvenation Station.  This will cover the cost of the trailer, construction, machines and everything in between.  The trailer will feature 2 full shower suites (ADA accessible) and several sets of washer/dryer combo units.  Our shower rooms feel like a regular bathroom, because they are meant for regular people, just like you. They are private, comfortable, and feature the same amenities you would expect in your own home.

        Due to the cost needed to complete this project and ensure that every donor is able to witness the success of The Rejuvenation Station, we ARE NOT running a flexible funding campaign.  What this means is that if we do not hit our goal, ALL donations will be refunded. So tell your friends, family and anyone else you know that is passionate about meaningful change…We Need Your Help!  

        Additional donations beyond our goal will go directly to keeping The Rejuvenation Station active and serving our community.  While our goal will ensure the successful construction of the trailer, we will still require donations to cover water & energy usage, supplies, etc.  The GREAT NEWS is we are able to provide these our services for very little.

$2 is all is takes to provide a shower and clean set of clothes to someone.  For less than $200, you can ensure someone is clean and happy every week for an ENTIRE YEAR!

        At The Rejuvenation Station we believe everything is a celebration, so we have set up perks to reflect that. From big thank you cards, to stickers you will want to stick all over the place, we want you to know how important your gift is. As the perks grow you will have an opportunity for a new year’s surprise, to have your name on the trailer, or receive a shoutout on social media to tell everyone about the impact your gift has had. Your donation of $500 or more will get your name in our Hall of Fame. Larger donations come with perks like a dinner with our team, so that we can say thank you in person and tell you more about the impact your donation is having in our community. You can cut the ribbon when we launch the trailer for the first time, get some of the best seats in the house at our inaugural event or an early preview of the trailer YOU brought to life. No matter what level you choose to donate at, your generosity is cherished and vital.  

 

Risks & Challenges

        With any project there are always some risks or challenges, but we are confident that we have built a knowledge base to help us overcome anything that stands in our way.

        This project was not created overnight.  Rather, our team has spent the last year visiting shower and laundry units across the country.  We have listened to the stories of others that have come before us and learned from their trials and tribulations.  And most importantly, we have listened to our community. We are very comfortable with all of our construction and operational cost estimates.  And we have designed this trailer with low operating costs in mind. We have seen the challenges others have faced after getting past the build stage.  We will not face these challenges.

        With the successful completion of our campaign you are guaranteed to see our trailer on the road, providing exactly the experience we have promised.  Our next goal will be to secure funding to keep it on the road 7 days a week. But we are confident, based on the outpouring of support we have already received, that this will be a reality for many years to come.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

        If you aren’t sure about the impact of your contribution or aren’t sure you can donate today, we still want you on our team. The best way to do this is for you to share our campaign on your social media or through email. You can do that with our share link on this page or by heading to our facebook, twitter, or instagram pages and giving us a follow and a share. We have discovered that YOU are our best storytellers, our best advocates, and our best cheerleaders. Sharing our project, and encouraging others to do so, is an amazing gift. 

        For those wishing to be more hands on with The Rejuvenation Station, we will be recruiting kind and compassionate volunteers to ensure the continued success after construction.  Contact us at ShowerForAll.org and let us know you are interested.

There are not enough words to express our gratitude and love for all your support.  Thank you, thank you, and thank you. We can’t wait to show you what we build.

You can do that with our share link on this page or by heading to our facebook, twitter, or instagram pages and giving us a follow and a share. We have discovered that YOU are our best storytellers, our best advocates, and our best cheerleaders. Sharing our project, and encouraging others to do so, is an amazing gift.         For those wishing to be more hands on with The Rejuvenation Station, we will be recruiting kind and compassionate volunteers to ensure the continued success after construction.  Contact us at ShowerForAll.org and let us know you are interested.There are not enough words to express our gratitude and love for all your support.  Thank you, thank you, and thank you. story:
Short Summary

We are currently in the process of adopting two wonderful kids from the Democratic Republic of Congo.  Their orphanage is lacking a wall which would vastly improve their quality of life, as well as the safety of all of the kids in care here!  

Thanks to the generosity of friends and strangers...  we have raised $2100+ to:

  • Pay Local Workers to Re-build the decayed wall 
  • Remove some of the very dangerous components on the compound, including two open garbage pits and rusted steel bars that remain in the former foundation
  • Buy materials and have Local artists paint the interior of the wall with a beautiful mural, to really enhance the space for the children
  • Create a new space for garbage disposal
NOW we need the raw materials to build the wall!

What We Need ...

The shopping list includes:

GRAVEL , 30 tons , $540

SAND , 30 tons , $200

WATER , 3,000 liters , $400

CEMENT , 65 sacs , $1,230

METAL BARS , 32 bars , $290

BOARDS , 8 boards , $120

METAL CORD , 6 kilos , $20

NAILS , 3 kilos , $20

HAMMERS , $50

STRING , 2 rolls , $7

TRANSPORT , $300

    The Impact

    With this wall... 

    • The children are protected from the neighboring village
    • The smallest children are safe within the compound
    • The children have increased focus during school and privacy during mealtimes.
    • The children can freely play with toys that have been donated to the orphanage, increasing cooperation and learning stimulation.
    • The garbage is controlled within the compound, increasing hygiene.
    • The children get the security of this beautifully painted wall

      Other Ways You Can Help

        • Tell your friends and families about this campaign!
        • And use the Indiegogo share tools for social media!

story:
With your help, we raised enough funds to purchase and distribute 3,500 sleeping bags to the homeless across King County. And we're back with: Sleepless in Seattle 2015.

As Seen On

Press links at bottom of page.

In Partnership With

Corporate Partnerships:

MM Comfort Systems has made a generous contribution to further their commitment to keeping those on and off the streets warm for the winter. " MM Comfort System will also provide one free furnace to a randomly selected Sleepless in Seattle donor at the end of the campaign!

Exxel Outdoors is providing over 2,000 deeply-discounted sleeping bags, covering the freight costs from Alabama to Seattle, and donating additional sleeping bags.

Columbia Sportswear has donated 200 warm beanies to be distributed alongside sleeping bags. 

PinkaBella Cupcakes will be donating a cupcake with every sleeping bag on the "Big Give" to the homeless throughout our community.

Non-Profit Partnerships:

Partners will receive sleeping bags to be distributed through their facilities.

Sleepless in Seattle is proud to partner with a host of non-profits, companies, and civic groups in our area. If you would like to partner with us, please email us at give@sleeplessinseattle.org.

Vision

A Seattle and King County where every homeless individual has a warm sleeping bag to get them through the winter and beyond.

Problem

On any given winter night, at least 3,100 people in King County sleep directly on the streets bearing with temperatures in the 20s and 30s. This year, let’s do something about it.

Solution

Pool resources as a city to purchase & donate sleeping bags to be distributed through key non-profit partnerships and volunteer groups.

Origins

Sleepless in Seattle is the brainchild of a few Seattleites who simply asked the question, "how can we care for our community?" People from every socioeconomic, religious, and cultural background are invited to participate in this movement.  

While Sleepless in Seattle is not exclusively affiliated with any one organization, donations will be processed through an existing 501(c)(3) non-profit Urban Hands which provides donated meals around the Seattle area.

The Impact

Do people who are homeless need sleeping bags?

Yes. The Sleepless in Seattle team has reached out to over a dozen local non-profits  who work with homeless populations to assess the need. These non-profits have responded with an assessment of significant need with one non-profit estimating that 80% of the homeless on the streets do not have access to sleeping bags.

Seattle has more homeless folks than shelters.  Sleeping outside is the only option for some, meaning that a sleeping bag is a life-changing gift.  The gift of sleep is the single most important way to communicate you care. 

-Kristine Cunningham, Executive Director of ROOTS Young Adult Homeless Shelter

The unfortunate reality is that we do not have the capacity to house all of the homeless youth in our community. Having resources, like sleeping bags, is critical to helping them survive the night and starts the conversation with staff help move young people forward and off the streets.

-Melinda Giovengo, PhD, Executive Director of Youth Care

How You Can Help

Donate to Sleepless in Seattle

100% of funds will be used to purchase sleeping bags for the homeless in Seattle & King County. Crowdsourcing and credit card transaction costs, will be covered by generous supporters. All Sleepless in Seattle coordinating efforts are purely volunteer-based.  

$10,000 = 500 sleeping bags

$50,000 = 2,500 sleeping bags

$75,000 =  3,750 sleeping bags - enough to cover the  homeless population in King County

How will funds be used?

Collected funds will be used to purchase sleeping bags in bulk from online wholesale distributors. Sleeping bags of varying styles and sizes will be purchased at a price range in order to accommodate varying needs. Some prefer warmer, larger bags while others prefer smaller bags that can be carried and concealed easily in a backpack. 

What's in it for me?

For once, let's do something, simply because it's something worth doing.

Are donations tax-deductible?

Yes. Donors can expect to receive an email from payment processor FirstGiving with a tax-deductible receipt from the non-profit Urban Hands. Urban Hands is a local non-profit committed to providing meals to homeless individuals. They have volunteered to serve as the 501(c)(3) non-profit entity through which Sleepless in Seattle funds will be transferred.

Distribute Sleeping Bags

Sleeping bags will be distributed through two channels: 

1) A "Big Give" distribution day will take place on Saturday December 13th, 2014 3pm-9:30pm. 200 volunteers from around the county will gather in Capitol Hill. Exact address will be emailed to volunteers who signup below.

All volunteers will go through street sensitivity training before being broken into teams of four to distribute sleeping bags around the county. Individuals who donate will be given priority access to attend this event.

Leader Registration: If you are 18 years of age or older, have experience serving the homeless, are comfortable leading a team of four, and are willing to commit to serving on 12/13, please RSVP through this link.

General Volunteer Registration: If you are a high school student or older, and are willing to commit to serving on 12/13, please RSVP through this link.

2) Remaining sleeping bags will be given to leading non-profits in King County specializing in work with the homeless and marginalized to be distributed throughout the community.  

Donate Sleeping Bags

Gently used sleeping bags can be donated to any of the following locations around King County. Please see this spreadsheet as a reference for hours of operation. 

An ideal sleeping bag would:
1) Have no natural fibers (helps with rain)
2) Have no bright colors
3) Be rated 20 or 30 degree bags
4) Be easy to pack and carry

Spread the Word

You are personally invited to join the Sleepless in Seattle team and help end sleepless nights in Seattle. Here are some suggestions to rally your community:

  • Share the Indiegogo campaign link over social media and email. Be sure to use the #sleeplessinseattle hashtag.
  • Connect with Sleepless in Seattle on Facebook and Twitter.
  • Lead a showing of the Sleepless in Seattle video.
  • Take advantage of printable & digital marketing resources.
To get in contact with the Sleepless in Seattle team, please email give@sleeplessinseattle.org. 

Risks & Challenges

1. Sleeping Bag Procurement Challenges

Due to the volume of sleeping bags Sleepless in Seattle intends on purchasing, there is a risk that some sleeping bag purchases could be delayed if distributors do not have adequate inventory. 

2. Misuse of Sleeping Bags

We expect a small portion of recipients to misuse or lose their sleeping bags. However, we believe the potential misuse of a few individuals should not discredit the opportunity to serve the many. 

Questions & Contact

Please direct all questions to give@sleeplessinseattle.org.


Press Links

Seattle Times - Showing Seattle's homeless a little warmth

KING 5 / Evening Magazine (TV show) - Seattle man launches campaign to give homeless sleeping bags.

KOMO News (Seattle Refined) - Sleepless in Seattle: The movement not the movie

KOMO 1000 AM - 4 Minute Interview

Mercer Island Reporter - A Warm Place to Sleep

Bellevue Reporter - Group hopes to provide warmer nights for King County homeless

Redmond Reporter - Redmond native Wang's Sleepless in Seattle project helps homeless population

NW Asian Weekly  - COMMENTARY: Sleepless in Seattle – the city gives back (and bags)

story:
Soy un estudiante universitario, participativo de actividades que promueven el desarrollo y crecimiento de oportunidades sociales en nuestro entorno. La oportunidad se me presenta cerrando mi ciclo universitario, y en un contexto sociopolítico en que es difícil costear gastos necesarios sin un empleo y con ingresos familiares que sólo cubren lo necesario.

El South American Bussiness Forum es una gran oportunidad de llevar la realidad del nicaragüense a una plataforma donde sea escuchada, y es una puerta que me ha sido abierta para poder mejorar mi perspectiva de lo que está pasando en la región y poder generar un impacto positivo en algunos ámbitos, compartiendo conocimientos con otros jóvenes con que me desarrollo o jóvenes que tengan el deseo de crear ese cambio.

La temática del evento es "Perspectivas que incomodan", tocando subtemas como el Tribalismo, la Gobernanza Efectiva, y la Economía de la Atención, que son relevantes para todos y mucho más para un joven de nuestro país.

La campaña de recaudación de fondos tiene como objetivo la cobertura de mi boleto de avión (ida y regreso) a Buenos Aires. El valor del boleto ronda los $1,250.00 y los $1,350.00 a la fecha. En caso de no lograr alcanzar la meta, tomaría lo recogido y lo juntaria con otros fondos que pueda conseguir de empresas o personas.

Gastos extras en los que se deba incurrir estoy tratando de cubrirlos, para realizar también mi aporte a la causa. La organización del evento cubre la mayoría de los gastos durante las fechas de realización (hospedaje y alimentación).

Me siento honrado de haber sido seleccionado de entre muchos aplicantes de todo el mundo, y espero poder llevar a cabo la representación de Nicaragua para crear una expectativa de lo que tenemos para decir y hacer.

story:
WHAT ARE YOU RUNNING FOR?

In TWO WEEKS on February 1, 2015, Four AWESOME COMMUNITY ORGANIZERS  (Johnny Rodriguez, Alex Montances, Pastor Nestor Gerente, and Romeo Hebron) are taking a shot at running the SURF CITY MARATHON and HALF MARATHON in Huntington Beach, CA.  

They are not only running for health, fitness, and finishing a race but also to RAISE FUNDS for three really great  SOCIAL JUSTICE and HUMAN RIGHTS CAUSES!  

Romeo Hebron and Johnny Rodriguez of Anakbayan Long Beach will run for: Save Our Schools (SOS) / Salugpongan Community Learning Centers

SOS is a network of child focused NGOs, church groups, and concerned advocates for children's education. Salugpongan is a community built and operated educational system set up for the indigenous people in southern Mindanao, Philippines. The school aims to educate the children in general education (reading, writing, math) while also fostering the skills and knowledge to ensure the livelihood of indigenous communities. 

Alex Montances of NAFCON Southern California will run for : The 5th Annual Interfaith Advocacy Medical Mission to the Talaingod-Manobo Tribes of Mindanao, Philippines.      

The health and advocacy mission (July-August 2015) provides humanitarian and medical assistance to the Talaingod-Manobo indigenous communities, such as medical check ups and minor surgeries.  In addition, the missioners learn about and support the Talaingod-Manobo as they resist environmental destruction by logging and mining corporations and human rights violations by the Philippine military. 

Pastor Nestor Gerente of Grace United Methodist Church will run for : 

The Filipino Migrant Center and its End Human Trafficking Campaign

The Filipino Migrant Center (FMC) is a non-profit organization and ministry partner of Grace United Methodist Church in Long Beach.  The FMC provides community education, direct services, and legal advocacy for Filipino survivors of human trafficking (especially labor trafficking).   Many survivors are Filipino workers  trafficked from the Philippines to the United States by dubious/fraudulent recruitment agencies who trick, coerce, and force them into involuntary servitude, debt bondage, and slavery.

What We Need

These THREE CAUSES need your gifts and material support!  Your financial contributions whether it's $1, $5, or $100 can contribute to these amazing things:
  • The Salugpongan schools need new books, pencils/paper, school supplies, and enough financial support to administer the school all-year-round.  
  • The interfaith health mission needs help buying and shipping medicine, bandages, and other supplies to the Philippines.  These supplies are vital for the missioners to provide quality healthcare to the indigenous communities.  Some of the Talaingod-Manobo peoples may only see a health professional once or twice in their entire lives!
  • The Filipino Migrant Center uses monetary donations to assist Filipino trafficking survivors for social services, basic groceries, temporary shelter, and transportation costs (bus passes).  All of these donations help survivors of human trafficking get back on their feet- and helps provide them with the stability and support they need to prosecute their traffickers and win justice for themselves and their families!

You can help Johnny, Romeo, Pastor Nestor, and Alex "RUN for HUMAN RIGHTS" when you donate to their cause!  

WHEN YOU DONATE: Please make sure you SPECIFY and indicate which CAUSE/PERSON you are donating to! Romeo, Johnny, Pastor Nestor, and Alex have been training for this race for months- and its involved a lot of sweat, blood, and tears!  We may not WIN THE RACE but we will FLY, RUN, WALK, and CRAWL to make sure we finish it and raise the funds to RUN FOR HUMAN RIGHTS!  

Other Ways You Can Help

You can LEARN MORE, VOLUNTEER, and GET INVOLVED by clicking on these organization's links below:

  • Grace United Methodist Church in Long Beach: https://www.facebook.com/grace.umclongbeach/about
  • Filipino Migrant Center website: www.filipinomigrantcenter.com
  •  Interfaith Health Mission at the Panaghiusa website:  http://panaghiusa.org/category/events/
  • Salugpongan Schools Facebook page:  https://www.facebook.com/pages/Salugpongan-International/763765110332245
  • Anakbayan Los Angeles/Long Beach: http://anakbayanla.org

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!  MARAMING SALAMAT PO SA INYONG LAHAT! LETS RUN FOR HUMAN RIGHTS!!!

story:
This Campaign Has Closed, But You Can Still Donate!

We are proud to announce that we have surpassed our $100,000 goal. While this Indiegogo campaign has closed, we are still accepting donations directly through our website. Please visit: http://www.palestineadvocacyproject.org/donate

We Want To Bring Our Ads To More Americans

Palestine Advocacy Project (formerly Ads Against Apartheid) is working for Palestinian freedom and independence and an end to Israel’s violent military occupation. We launched our first campaign in June, 2014 with three prominently placed billboards in a Boston Massachusetts’ subway station. It was a major success, and we want to take it national! 

Our "One Word" advertisements feature powerful images and large, direct text that expose Israel’s continued human rights abuses against the Palestinian people from Nablus to Jerusalem to Gaza. 

Help us bring our ads to more Americans! Recent events in Gaza compel us to educate as many people as possible about Israel's abuses of Palestinian human rights. We want to cover subway stations, airports, billboards, and other public spaces with our message! 

We Will Run The Ads in Major Cities

With your support, we hope to have advertisements running for one month in 8-10 major American cities. They include:

  • New York
  • Washington, DC
  • San Francisco
  • Boston
  • Many More!

We Want Americans to Understand

Peace is about justice. This conflict will only end when everyone in the region - including both Jews and Palestinians - have equal rights. We want more Americans to understand that: 

  • Israel is building homes and businesses for its own citizens on land it continues to steal from Palestinians.
  • The Israeli military regularly kills Palestinians, including more than 1,300 children since 2000
  • That Israel demolishes Palestinian homes. 
  • That the United States provides Israel with more than $3 billion in military aid while Israel violates Palestinians' human rights on a daily basis. 

Our Team

Our management team includes creative and experienced organizers and academics:
  • Thomas Abowd: Tom teaches at Tufts and UMass-Amherst. He is an urban anthropologist and historian who received his Ph.D. in Cultural Anthropology from Columbia University in 2003. His book on spatial politics in contemporary Jerusalem, "Colonial Jerusalem: the Spatial Construction of Identity and Difference," was published this year by Syracuse University Press.
  • Richard Colbath-Hess: Rick founded the first state-wide living wage campaign for human services in the country. His father became a refugee after fleeing the Nazi Holocaust in 1938. The City of Cambridge awarded him with the Peace and Justice award. He currently serves as faculty adjunct at the University of Massachusetts, Boston.
  • Sofia Wolman: Sofia developed a campaign to divest Earlham’s holdings companies profiting from Israeli violations of human rights and international law. Additionally, she served as an organizer for the Cambridge office of the American Friends Service Committee, where her work included activism for economic justice and organizing against militarism and nuclear weapons.
  • Paul Normandia: Paul Normandia is a graphic designer, illustrator and printing industry professional in Boston, MA. He is a worker­-owner at Red Sun Press, a cooperatively ­run printing and graphic design shop. Paul is involved in a number of local activist groups. 
  • Jake Chase-Lubitz: Jake has provided marketing and communications consulting for a number of Palestinian, private, and public organizations operating in the areas of tourism, public relations, and diplomacy.  

Our Advisory Board

Our advisory board is made up of established members of the struggle for Palestinian human rights. They include:
  • Sami Awad, Holy Land Trust, Palestine
  • Diana Buttu, International Human Rights Lawyer
  • Elaine Hagopian, nationally renown activist and scholar and Professor Emerita at Simmons College
  • Nancy Murray, Gaza Mental Health Foundation
  • Mazin Qumsiyeh, Bethlehem and Birzeit Universities
  • Pam Rogers, Jewish Voice for Peace

Risks & Challenges

Different cities have different policies for public advertising, and we anticipate that a few will resist putting up our ads. While we always fight for our freedom of speech, we cannot guarantee that we will always win. Fortunately, some of our most promising cities, like New York and Washington, DC, have some of the most liberal guidelines, and so we are confident that, whatever happens, our campaign will have real impact. 

Remember, all money contributed through this campaign will be spent on public advertising, so your support will help to educate Americans. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share this campaign as widely as possible.
  • Explain to your friends and family how important this issue is, and ask them if they would be willing to contribute.
  • Like Palestine Advocacy Project on Facebook
  • Visit www.palestineadvocacyproject.org and sign up for our email list

Note: All money donated through this campaign is tax-deductible in the United States, and will be received by Palestine Advocacy Project's 501C-3 charitable sponsor, ItIsApartheid, Inc.

story: The funds for this campaign were used in the defense of this lawsuit. While insurance covered a portion of the expense, I was left with a lot of exposure and had to deal with multiple lawyers.

story:
Lava Mae, a San Francisco-based mobile shower and sanitation service for the homeless, is at it again.   We ran a very successful IndieGoGo campaign last year that raised funds to retrofit our first mobile hygiene bus.

It wasn't corporate dollars, it wasn't a wealthy philanthropist that made that possible.  It was a community of IndieGoGo supporters - like you - that brought our bus to life.   And we're asking you to help us do it again!

Help us raise $75,000* for a second bus, and we'll be able to give 25,000 showers next year!       

We convert retired public transportation buses into bathrooms on wheels because we believe that for the thousands of men, women, and children living on our streets, a shower can be the first step towards transformation.

"If you're homeless, living on the streets and filthy, you're trying to improve your circumstances, but you can't interview for a job, you can't apply for housing and you become disconnected from your humanity. So a shower, just in itself, can be amazing for people."

                                                                                   ~Doniece Sandoval, founder, Lava Mae

  • There are 7,350+ people without homes in San Francisco.  Over half live on the street yet there are only 7 places where they can drop in to take a shower.
  • It's not just San Francisco that has this problem.  Communities across this country are failing to provide access to hygiene for their citizens.  We hear from someone just about every day in some city or town in the US who asks us to bring Lava Mae to their community.  The need is huge.


"I've been trying to take a shower for two weeks, and I finally got in here today. To be able to take a shower at least once or twice a week is probably the best thing ever. This makes it a lot more convenient. You just have no idea how serious this is for a person to be able to wash themselves. At least that much dignity."  ~ Windell R.

Our first bus launched at the end of June 2014, and it's already a huge success. We've given over 500 showers to lots of people like Windell, and this is just the beginning.  With a second bus, we can provide 25,000 showers in 2015.

We need $75,000 to retrofit Bus 2 and create more mobile showers and toilets for the thousands of men, women and children who so desperately need them.  Join us; become part of the "village" that's making this imaginative and innovative dream possible - one shower (bus) at a time.

To thank you for helping us realize this dream, here are the great perks we've put together:

                                                                                                                                                

                                

        

We're not even halfway through our 6 month pilot program, and we've already given over 500 showers!

Our most surprising findings?

1. A huge proportion of our guests have jobs, families, and degrees, and, like so many of us, were just one unfortunate incident away from homelessness.  

2. The power of a shower.  After just 15 minutes, we see people emerge with big smiles, new attitudes, and most humbling of all, gratitude. 

3. We're touching more lives than we expected.  From our volunteers, to passersby on the street, to those reading about us on the Internet across the world, Lava Mae is reconnecting many more than just the homeless to our shared humanity. 

Here are a few stories:

  • Monte, a machinist from Detroit, moved to San Francisco in search for a job.  Unable to afford rent without opportunities for work, he's been living on the streets for the last few months.  After a local TV broadcast aired an interview with him about our service, Lava Mae received an email from an employee at Tesla who saw his story and wants to connect him to employment.
  • Emily and her family of five visit us every Saturday morning.  The parents work, and their three children are in school.  With the addition of Lava Mae's Saturday stop, they are now able to take 2 showers per week. Limited shower availability in San Francisco is even more challenging for young families who don't want to put their children at risk in unsafe environments that lack privacy and supervision.

  • Homeless for one-year, Silas (below) is a charming, middle-aged man who is dying of liver cancer. Being clean is vital to him, especially as his medication makes his skin sensitive and prone to sores.  He says that Lava Mae is helping to keep him healthy, and is the bright spot in his weekend.

                 

What started as a simple - and crazy - idea over two years ago has become a remarkable reality. We've built our prototype, launched our pilot, and set off a wave of inquiries from dozens of communities as close as Silicon Valley and Los Angeles and as far as Ghana, Mongolia, Sydney, and San Paolo - all inspired by Lava Mae to create their own mobile hygiene service.


 

We're all about collaboration.  Our partners - local government, corporations and other nonprofits - make what we do possible.

  • Each day we partner with different local nonprofits providing services to the homeless.  We pull up outside, plug into the nearest fire hydrant for our water, and start a sign-up sheet in their drop-in centers.  This allows us to expand their services while leveraging the support of staff experienced in this field.

  • City government is integral to our ability to deliver our service. Here are the agencies we're working with: SF Mayor’s Office of HOPE, SF Municipal Transportation Agency, SF Public Utilities Commission, and SF Department of Public Works, and the SF Department of Health, which has given us their good housekeeping seal of approval!

  • The private sector - companies like Google, Dr. Bronner’s, Kohler and Laundry Locker - has provided us with essential goods and services, in addition to other support and funding that makes our service possible.

    Read all the great press Lava Mae has been getting HERE!

               

                          

    Here's how you can help:

    Donate, now!  Not only will you feel showered in the good feelings of helping people in need, but you'll also cash in on some sweet perks!  You can also:

  • Tell your friends!  Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, carrier pigeon - whatever it takes to get the word out.

  • Post a comment or ask us a question on our campaign page; we're obsessive about responding and we love a good conversation!

It always seems impossible until it's done. ~Nelson Mandela

*While Lava Mae/Tides goal is to purchase and retrofit another bus to be used for showers for the San Francisco homeless population, these funds may be used as general support for Lava Mae’s mission of providing such showers if enough money is not raised or operations require using the funds raised for general operations.

need them.  Join us; become part of the "village" that's making this 
imaginative and innovative dream possible - one shower (bus) at a time. 


To thank you for helping us realize this dream, here are the great perks we've put together:


                                                                                                                                                

                                
        
We're not even halfway through our 6 month pilot program, and we've already given over 500 showers!
Our most surprising findings? 
1. A huge proportion of our guests have jobs, families, and degrees, and, 
like so many of us, were just one unfortunate incident away from 
homelessness.  
2. The power of a shower.  After just 15 minutes, 
we see people emerge with big smiles, new attitudes, and most humbling 
of all, gratitude. 
3. We're touching more lives than we expected.  From our volunteers, to passersby on the street, to those reading about us on the Internet across the world, Lava Mae is reconnecting many more than just the homeless to our shared humanity. 
Here are a few stories:

Monte, a machinist from Detroit, moved to San Francisco in search 
for a job.  Unable to afford rent without opportunities for work, he's 
been living on the streets for the last few months.  After a local TV 
broadcast aired an interview with him about our service, Lava Mae 
received an email from an employee at Tesla who saw his story and wants 
to connect him to employment.
Emily and her family of five visit us every Saturday morning.
  The parents work, and their three children are in school.  With the 
addition of Lava Mae's Saturday stop, they are now able to take 2 
showers per week. Limited shower availability in San Francisco is even 
more challenging for young families who don't want to put their children at risk 
in unsafe environments that lack privacy and supervision.
Homeless for one-year, Silas (below) is a charming, middle-aged man who 
is dying of liver cancer. Being clean is vital to him, especially as his
 medication makes his skin sensitive and prone to sores.  He says that 
Lava Mae is helping to keep him healthy, and is the bright spot in his 
weekend.







                  

What
 started as a simple - and crazy - idea over two years ago has become
 a remarkable reality. We've built our prototype, launched our pilot, 
and set off a wave of inquiries from dozens of communities as close as 
Silicon Valley and Los Angeles and as far as Ghana, Mongolia, Sydney, 
and San Paolo - all inspired by Lava Mae to create their own mobile 
hygiene service.



 



We're all about collaboration.  Our partners - local government, corporations and other nonprofits - make what we do possible.


Each day we partner with different local nonprofits providing 
services to the homeless.  We pull up outside, plug into the nearest 
fire hydrant for our water, and start a sign-up sheet in their drop-in
 centers.  This allows us to expand their services while 
leveraging the support of staff experienced in this field.
City government is integral to our ability to deliver our 
service. Here are the agencies we're working with: SF Mayor’s Office of 
HOPE, SF Municipal Transportation Agency, SF Public Utilities 
Commission, and SF Department of Public Works, and the SF Department of 
Health, which has given us their good housekeeping seal of approval!

The private sector - companies like Google, Dr. Bronner’s, Kohler
and Laundry Locker - has provided us with essential goods and
 services, in addition to other support and funding that makes our 
service possible.


Read all the great press Lava Mae has been getting HERE!


            

                       

Here's how you can help:
Donate, now!  Not only will you feel showered in the good 
feelings of helping people in need, but you'll also cash in on some 
sweet perks!  You can also: 



Tell your friends!  Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, carrier pigeon - whatever it takes to get the word out.
Post a comment or ask us a question on our campaign page; we're obsessive about responding and we love a good conversation!



It always seems impossible until it's done. ~Nelson Mandela
*While Lava Mae/Tides goal is to purchase and retrofit another bus to be used for showers for the San Francisco homeless population, these funds may be used as general support for Lava Mae’s mission of providing such showers if enough money is not raised or operations require using the funds raised for general operations.

story:
Mercy29 is an anti-profit organization that rescues child slaves and feeds hungry people.

The organization began in 2009. It was founded by Lyle Phillips, an Iris Ministries missionary.

After just three years in India, Mercy29 has grown to more than 1600 children, with 400 of those children being rescued directly from human trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

Our founder, Lyle, with children rescued from human trafficking by Mercy29.

This Christmas..

One of our Mercy29 missionaries, Emily Yeatman, will be leading a team to Andhra Pradesh, India. While there, she and the team will visit our eight homes for rescued children, and personally give each child an amazing Christmas present!

The Children Need.. $10,000.

$10,000 will provide one $10 gift for each one of our children this Christmas. By partnering with us, you will receive an array of rewards for your contribution, as well as a HUGE BLESSINGS from our children in India.

One of our beloved children, Pandu.

Jesus teaches us..

"Truly I tell you, whatever you did for one of the least of these brothers and sisters of mine, you did for me."

Our Christmas Trip Team Leader, Emily Yeatman.

Let's celebrate Jesus together, by adopting a rescued child into your family this Christmas. It only takes $10 to change one life forever!

Help us get the word out!

Share this project with others using the Indiegogo share tools!

*Photos by Logan Z. Hunt

story:
Hola friends!


I have a room free in my apartment and I decided to use the opportunity and get some karma points back (lost to the Hungarian government). Now you can be a part of it!!! 

Eid (but everyone calls him Lulu) is a lovely 26 years old guy from Chad, looking for refuge in German. Since his situation is not cleared yet (he is here for over a year now), he is not allowed to work here. I'd like to help him out by giving the extra room in my WG to him in the next months. However, I'm not the most overpaid person either - and this is where we need you! For the next 4 months we need 1400 euro to pay the rent. Please donate for us to be able to cover the rent for the room! 

Peace&Luv!

story:
Jujitio is a website dedicated to harnessing the power of mobile technology to raise public awareness about excessive force and police misconduct and improve police and community relations.


The Jujitio app enables Users to protect their civil rights and safely and securely record and share video of police misconduct and excessive force.


  • Users record their interactions with law enforcement using our mobile app 
  • Recordings are instantly streamed to our servers rather than stored on the device.
  • The recording is available to the User to download, publish, delete, or report, and after a while, it's available to their Trusted Contacts too.
  • The User or one of their Trusted Contacts may publish the recording, making it publicly available for viewing on our website.
  • The recording is never stored on the User's device unless the User downloads it, protecting them from the possibility that police will destroy the recording or use it as evidence against them.


No matter how much we receive from this campaign, all funds will help us protect civil rights and liberties by enabling us to build the website, expose and write about video recordings and incidents of excessive force and police misconduct, and raise awareness about these problems in our nation's law enforcement culture. 


If we do reach our funding goal, we'll also be able to begin building the app and make it available for free early next year.


The Detailed Explanation of the App



A more detailed explanation of Jujitio. Pretty much tells you everything you'd want to know about the campaign.

Police misconduct and excessive force have become far too common.

Americans file as many as 27,000 complaints a year against police for using excessive force. These incidents cost states and cities billions of dollars, not to mention the damage they do to police and community relations. They also mean that many for many Americans, civil rights are still just an unfulfilled promise.

Out of the half million people police threaten or use force against each year, 60% are never arrested or charged with a crime. And 15% were actually getting "help" from the police!

And on top of that, in recent years police have used civil asset seizure laws to wrongfully take millions of dollars from people who have never been charged with a crime using it to buy things elected officials won't put in the budget, like armored cars and $300 coffee machines. A large portion of the seized funds are used to buy military equipment that make police forces look and act more like military occupiers than fellow citizens.

Police agencies have used hundreds of millions of dollars taken from Americans under federal civil forfeiture law in recent years to buy guns, armored cars and electronic surveillance gear. They have also spent money on luxury vehicles, travel and a clown named Sparkles. -Washington Post special report on civil asset seizure


When you couple this militarization of law enforcement with an erosion of civil liberties and due process  . . . we begin to have a very serious problem on our hands. - U.S. Senator Rand Paul, writing in Time magazine.

And let's be honest, if a cop steps out of line, and it's your word against theirs, a lot of people will accept an officer's version of events. That's why video and photos can be such important and powerful evidence when police use excessive force or abuse their power.


Recording the police offers you some protection, but what if an officer stops or confiscates your recording or your device gets damaged?


With the Jujitio app, you can record the police with confidence, knowing only you can access your recordings and decide who sees them. 


And if the police step out of line, you know you can turn to a powerful online community committed to telling your story and getting justice for you.


It all starts with the Jujitio mobile app and the four R's of our patent pending process


Record

Jujitio Users record and photograph their interactions with police using our mobile app. Instead of getting stored on their device, the recording or photo streams directly to our servers, where it's securely stored and available only to the User and their Trusted Contacts.


Record the police and stream it directly to our cloud-based servers.

Review


After recording or photographing the police, the User will have up to 6 hours, depending on their settings, to log on to our website or through a password protected portal in the mobile app to review their recording or photo. 

At that time, the User will have the option to download, delete, or publish the recording or photo or report the incident to the civil rights authorities at the U.S. Department of Justice. They can also choose to add details such as the police unit, badge number, and names of any officers involved and written details about their recollection of the incident.


If the User does not delete the recording during this initial 6-hour period, an email alert will go out to the User's Trusted Contacts informing them about the recording and their opportunity to download, delete, or publish it at Jujitio.com or report it to the authorities.


Only the User, and later their Trusted Contacts, will have access to the recording. The idea is that if you are injured or arrested so that you cannot make a decision about the recording, your Trusted Contacts have your best interest at heart and will know whether you would want them to download, delete, or publish the recording or report the incident to authorities. 



Access to unpublished recordings is password protected so only the User and Trusted Contacts can get in. And if nobody does anything, the recording or photograph will automatically delete from our servers after 96 hours. 

Ridicule 


Publicizing and ridiculing police misconduct and excessive force will deter some officers from abusing their power in the first place and provide an opportunity to get some measure of accountability and justice for victims even when the law fails.

If a User reviews their recording or photo and decides it shows police misconduct or excessive force, the User may choose to publish the recording on our  website, allowing visitors to the site to view, share, rate, and comment on the recording. 

Recordings with higher ratings will be prioritized for other visitors to the site to view and review, and discussion boards on each recording's page will allow visitors to the website to comment on the conduct in the videos.


Report


Users and their Trusted Contacts will have an option to report an incident to the Office of Civil Rights at the Department of Justice if they believe their civil rights have been violated by a police officer. Before sending the recording or photo, Users will have an opportunity to add details about the incident that may help authorities investigate and prosecute the officers involved. We also provide an option for Users to include or exclude time and location information when they record with the Jujitio app, allowing them to decide how much documentation is available if they need to report an incident.


Privacy and Security


Privacy and security are essential to ensure a person's recording can't be destroyed by an officer or used to embarrass or even prosecute them. 
We protect Users' privacy in four important ways:

  1. Recordings and photos taken with the app are streamed directly to our servers, so there's nothing on the User's device if it gets taken away or lost.
  2. If a User isn't available to make a decision about whether to download, delete or publish their recording or report a violation of their rights to authorities, only the User’s Trusted Contacts get access to the recording to ensure someone the User trusts sees what happened and can make an informed decision on their behalf.
  3. If nobody does anything, recordings and photos are automatically deleted from our servers 96 hours after we receive them.
  4. Finally, Jujitio never gets any information about our Users other than their email address and password and email addresses for their Trusted Contacts. 


We Love Good Cops


The vast majority of complaints for excessive force are made against a very small number of officers and even many of these are unsubstantiated, because most police officers are great public servants. It is the very few who abuse their power to bully and injure citizens or steal their property who make it impossible for people in some communities to trust the police. At Jujitio, we hope to make it safer and easier for the great cops out there to do their job by making it harder for bad cops to get away with doing rotten things to the people they police and protect. 


Our Team


Mark O'Brien is a Senior Criminal Justice Policy Associate 

in Legal Action Center's Washington, D.C. office, where he works to reform the criminal justice system and promote health responses to drug use. He is  also the co-chair of the Justice Roundtable's Reentry Working Group.


Chris Lindsey brings over 7 years of marketing and advertising experience to the Jujitio team. Recently, he's been working at Facebook 

where he specializes in partnering with app developers to help them find users interested in their products.


Pace Putland is a Senior Designer for TJP Engineering in San Diego. Specializing in world class Zoo’s, Aquariums, and Marine parks, Pace coordinates and collaborates with a variety of disciplines on many aspects of design, bringing a unique ability to integrate visual appeal with practical functions. He recently completed work on the Baltimore Zoo's new penguin display.


Each of our team members has a proven track record of success in their respective field and a reputation for getting the job done. Friends since we were teenagers, we have always bonded over completing projects together, most recently focusing our energies on joint web development efforts.  We are passionate about this project, and we also genuinely enjoy the opportunity to work together.


What We Need From You


Through this Indiegogo campaign, we have two main goals we plan to achieve if we reach our minimum funding: 

  1. Complete the design and development of the Jujitio mobile app and website and support initial streaming software licensing
  2. Build a community of Jujitio Justices who are committed to ending police brutality and abuses of power


We know this is an issue a lot of people are passionate about, and we believe we have a great solution and a great team to launch it. If we are fortunate enough to receive your support and funding beyond our minimum goal, we plan to use these funds to:

  1. Support our first few months of operating costs, especially web hosting and software license fees, while we build the critical mass of Users to support the application once we turn it over to a non-profit group to operate (see $500 Perk)
  2. Recruit Users
  3. Raise awareness and blog about the prevalence of excessive force and other police misconduct and the rights and responsibilities of citizens in a free society to record police


If we don't reach our funding goal 


We've set this campaign to flexible funding, but we need to reach our minimum goal if we want to be able to build the Jujitio app and ensure we can deliver the high quality and reliable product people need to be able to count on in the often tense situation when they encounter an officer. 

At the same time, we want to make sure we are able to do something even in the event that we do not reach our goal to bring more attention to this problem. That's why, if we do not reach our goal, we will still use the funds we receive to develop a website dedicated to exposing police misconduct by disseminating video recordings and writing about the problem on our blog. You can see our first substantive blog post here to get an idea of what we have in mind.


The Impact


At Jujitio, we believe trust in law enforcement is critical to keeping communities safe and thriving. Every incident of excessive force and police misconduct erodes the trust necessary for police and communities to work together to achieve a better quality of life for all. Reducing the frequency of these events by holding the perpetrators accountable and informing the public about their behavior is the only way to restore the public confidence that is vital to successful law enforcement. 

By supporting us, you'll not only make possible the creation of a powerful tool for holding officers accountable, you will also make a statement that you are fed up with police misconduct and you aren't going to take it anymore.


Other Ways You Can Help


We understand that not everybody has the resources to contribute financially to this campaign. We want you to be a part of making Jujitio a reality and especially to be a part of the community of justice-minded people we want to create on our website. Here's how you can get involved.


  • Let your friends and family know about what we're doing and direct them to this campaign to learn more about Jujitio and possibly contribute.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools on this campaign page to get the word out.
  • Like us on Facebook so we can let you know when the app is ready for you to download and start recording the police.


Risks & Challenges


Our team has previously worked together on other projects, including bringing a web app from conception to reality, and we know there are challenges to any development project. 


Challenge: Finding the right people to work on the development of the website and app. We have a team of freelancers in place who we know meet deadlines and deliver quality work from previous projects we've worked on together. We are excited to work with them again on Jujitio.


Challenge: Getting potential Users to download and try the app and website. We will use social media and our blog (the Police Misconduct Blotter) to engage in the highlight this issue and our solution and also promote our idea with contacts we have who may be interested in using the app and sharing it with others. 


Challenge: Anticipating web hosting and licensing costs. Since we will be hosting a potentially large volume of recordings, we are prepared to deal with this challenge in two ways:

  1. Preparing for a large volume of initial hosting needs
  2. Making plans to transfer the app and website to an appropriate non-profit with the capacity to sustain it once it reaches a critical mass of Users.

The Impact 
At Jujitio, we believe trust in law enforcement is critical to keeping communities safe and thriving. Every incident of excessive force and police misconduct erodes the trust necessary for police and communities to work together to achieve a better quality of life for all. Reducing the frequency of these events by holding the perpetrators accountable and informing the public about their behavior is the only way to restore the public confidence that is vital to successful law enforcement. 
By supporting us, you'll not only make possible the creation of a powerful tool for holding officers accountable, you will also make a statement that you are fed up with police misconduct and you aren't going to take it anymore.
  
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everybody has the resources to contribute financially to this campaign. We want you to be a part of making Jujitio a reality and especially to be a part of the community of justice-minded people we want to create on our website. Here's how you can get involved.



Let your friends and family know about what we're doing and direct them to this campaign to learn more about Jujitio and possibly contribute.
Use the Indiegogo share tools on this campaign page to get the word out.

Like us on Facebook so we can let you know when the app is ready for you to download and start recording the police.


Risks & Challenges 
Our team has previously worked together on other projects, including bringing a web app from conception to reality, and we know there are challenges to any development project. 

Challenge: Finding the right people to work on the development of the website and app. We have a team of freelancers in place who we know meet deadlines and deliver quality work from previous projects we've worked on together. We are excited to work with them again on Jujitio.

Challenge: Getting potential Users to download and try the app and website. We will use social media and our blog (the Police Misconduct Blotter) to engage in the highlight this issue and our solution and also promote our idea with contacts we have who may be interested in using the app and sharing it with others. 

Challenge: Anticipating web hosting and licensing costs. Since we will be hosting a potentially large volume of recordings, we are prepared to deal with this challenge in two ways: 

Preparing for a large volume of initial hosting needs 

Making plans to transfer the app and website to an appropriate non-profit with the capacity to sustain it once it reaches a critical mass of Users.

story:
I cannot change my storyfrom year to year  becasue this iS my story~~ 

From the very first time I saw  homeless people (DC) It broke my heart. To see people sleeping on the ground, on benches, going thru garbage cans was simply heartbreaking.  Alot of them were homeless Vets and mentally Ill who were turned out on the street after the facility closed in Virginia.

After seeing this I gave away all the blankets and sheets I owned and started making sack lunches (bologna sandwiches, chips, 2 cookies, and a napkin) loaded 50 of them in my clothes basket and delievered them every sunday morning.

After awhile I actually became friends with many of them and they would be waiting for me each sunday. One Sunday so many were there .. I ran out of food. I quickly drove to Mcdonalds and bought enough sausage and biscuits to feed the remaining croud. That was the last Sunday I gave away my bags...I realized i couldn't afford to feed every hungry person each week. I had bigger plans.

Fast forward about 20 years and the less fortunate are still my passion. I do know the difference in the different stages of homelessness, the junkys, the alcholics..none of this matters to me..I like to feed them all!

 What started with fixing and giving away maybe 20 plates to the homeless  many years ago..has turned into 100-120 plates each Thanksgiving and another 100-120 plates at Christmas along with 20 boxes of food for families who would like to cook their own holiday dinner.

I have always funded this myself but  learned about indiegogo 2 years ago and launched a campaign! Thanks to my wonderful contributors last year i was able to make between 188-230 plates for thanksgiving and at christmas another 200+ plates, 35 boxes  of food  and clothing for 5 entire families and their children!!!, I am hoping i can raise enough to do even more this year.

I am hoping some of you may share this passion with me and help me  make this the biggest holiday to date!!! THis will be the 8th year I have done this! Each year, I'm happy to say, has been even more successful than the year before!

Also, I'm the one taking all the pics !!! Thats why i am not in them, lol..when i do this i love to be completely alone with music going..i do not want friends to help me because, sometimes, they do not put love into it..and i do!!! I do have to to have help with delivering them ;)

Help me make this the biggest year yet..and feed even more than last year!

I want to thank any of you, in advance, who share my passion and will help me!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
