story:
The Hajjah Province in Yemen

The Governorate of Hajjeh is one of the poorest in Yemen. It is composed of 30 districts , with no easy roads to access these areas. Almost 2 million people live there . They are too poor to buy seeds to cultivate, water is difficult to access, no NGO is working on the ground due to the war and the  difficulties to reach these remote villages. 2 or 3 hospitals with no medicine are not working properly. This Governorate  is 5 or 6 hours far away from the capital Sanaa.

In the first six months of this year, Hajjah province, where Aslam is located, recorded 17,000 cases of severe acute malnutrition, higher than in any full year on record.

Malnourished children, who were previously treated, returned to clinics in even worse condition — if they make it back at all. And deaths happen in remote villages where people can’t reach the health units.

Aslam is one of the poorest districts in the country, with hundreds of small villages, some isolated in the high mountains. Its population of 75,000 to 106,000 includes both local residents and accelerating numbers of displaced people who fled fighting elsewhere.

In terms of hunger, Aslam isn’t alone. As there are other districts closer to war zones which may not be getting food aid at all. But Aslam did see one of the province’s highest jumps in the number of reported children suffering from severe acute malnutrition: From 384 cases being treated in January, an additional 1,319 more came in over the next six months, according to local health records. That comes to around 15 percent of the district’s children.

 

The number of people nationwide who would starve if they didn’t receive aid grew by a quarter over the past year, now standing at 8.4 million of Yemen’s 29 million people, according to U.N. figures. That number is likely to soon jump by another 3.5 million because the currency is losing value, leaving growing numbers of people unable to afford food, the U.N. warned this month.

 

Aim of Mona Relief in Hajjah

Mona Relief Organization aims through this campaign to helping malnourished children along with their families in that area with food aid baskets in an attempt to alleviate the suffering of people there. Our donors through this campaign will be updated about what we have done in the field by posting pictures and videos that taken during the food aid distribution.

Yemen Organization for Humanitarian Relief and Development (Mona), is a national Independent, non-governmental and non-profitable organization based in the capital Sana'a, Yemen. Mona Relief was established in May 2015 by the journalist Fatik al-Rodaini in Yemen.

Mona Relief has been carried out over 200 projects in Yemen since the war started in 2015.

 

Food Distributions in Hajjah, October 2018

We went to Hajjah this October 2018 where we the Mona Relief team did a fantastic work, and we are planning to do so again as soon as the campaign ends.

Some pictures of our Food Distribution in Hajjah (17th of October, 2018)

 

A beautiful moment of a kid smiling to our team.

 

Previous Projects

Have a look at some of our projects during the last years.

 

 

What Is Happening to Yemen?

Saudi Arabia together with a coalition launched a bombing campaign in Yemen on 25 March 2015 and imposed a blockade on all Yemeni sea, land and airports which has restricted entry of all supplies into the country.

To get more information about the current situation in Yemen you have to read this

Yemen has become a failed and devastated state. Since March 2015, 9,245 people have been killed and 52,800 injured. Coalition air strikes are the leading cause of civilian casualties. According to the U.N. Human Rights Council, civilians have repeatedly been the victims of "unrelenting violations of international humanitarian law." About 75 percent of the population — 22.2 million people — needs humanitarian assistance. Some 17.8 million people do not know where their next meal is coming from, and 8.4 million are considered at risk of starvation. Severe acute malnutrition is threatening the lives of almost 400,000 children under the age of 5. Half of the country's 3,500 health facilities are functioning and at least 16.4 million people lack basic health care. Medics have struggled to cope with the world's largest cholera outbreak, with more than 1 million suspected cases and 2,248 associated deaths since April 2017. More than 3 million people have been forced to flee their homes, including 2 million who remain displaced.

Key Facts about Yemen

Three and a half years of conflict have left 22.2 million people in need of humanitarian assistance, 11.3 of which are in acute need. This increase is driven by a deterioration of the situation in key humanitarian sectors.

Food Security and Agriculture

17.8 million people in Yemen are food insecure. Out of this, approximately 8.4 million people are severely food insecure and at risk of starvation - a worrying increase of 24 per cent. The conflict has destroyed people’s livelihoods and reduced their purchasing power, making it difficult for many Yemenis to meet minimal food needs.

Health

With only 50 per cent of health facilities fully functional, and a disruption of salaries paid to health personnel, 16.4 million people in Yemen require assistance to ensure adequate access to healthcare – 9.3 million of whom are in acute need.

The overriding humanitarian need is access to minimum healthcare for people whose lives are at risk due to illness or injury. The latest cholera outbreak has underscored the impact of the failing health system.

Water, Sanitation and hygiene

An estimated 16 million Yemenis need humanitarian assistance to establish or maintain access to safe water, basic sanitation and hygiene facilities, out of which 11.6 million are in acute need. Collapsing urban water and sanitation systems, deteriorating water and sanitation conditions in rural areas, and lack of means to maintain personal hygiene and purchase safe drinking water all contributed to one of the worst cholera outbreaks.

Malnutrition

Some 1.8 million children and 1.1 million pregnant or lactating women are acutely malnourished, including 400,000 children under the age 5 who are suffering from severe acute malnutrition. An estimated 7.5 million people are in need of nutrition assistance, with 2.9 million people who will require treatment for acute malnutrition in 2017.

Shelter and essential items

An estimated 5.4 million people need emergency shelter or essential household items, including IDPs, host communities and initial returnees. Ongoing conflict-related displacements, as well as initial returns to some areas, are driving these needs. 2.6 million people are in acute need of assistance.

Protection

With the increasing conflict, Yemen is one of the world’s largest protection crises. About 12.9 million people need assistance to protect their safety, dignity or basic rights, from violations of IHL, grave violations of children’s rights and gender-based violence.

Displacement and conflict has impacted vulnerable households and persons with specific needs, resulting in negative coping mechanisms and mounting psychosocial support needs. 4.9 million people are living in acutely affected areas.

Education

The 2017/2018 school year started with a setback in the education process in 13 out of 22 governorates. This is due to the extended time of non-payment of salaries for teachers. Schools across the country are unfit for use due to conflict-related damage, hosting of IDPs, or occupation by armed groups. An estimated 4.1 million school-age children require assistance to continue their education.

Livelihoods and community resilience

Around 8 million conflict-affected individuals require livelihoods assistance to enhance their selfreliance to address basic needs and reduce dependency on relief assistance. Communities require support to promote resilience, including clearance of landmines and other explosives in up to 22 governorates.

 

SITUATION IN YEMEN IN NUMBERS

11.3 million
children in need of humanitarian assistance (estimated)

22.2 million
# of people in need (Periodic Monitoring Review HCT, Apr 2017)

1.6 million
# of children internally displaced (IDPs) and returnees out of

2.9 million
# of IDPs and returnees (Task Force on Population Movement 14th report, Protection Cluster, July 2017)

460,000
children under 5 suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)

16 million
People in need of WASH assistance

16.4 million
People in need of basic health care

12.9 million
People in need of protection

6.31 million
Women who need protection

More than one million suspected cholera cases

2.247+
people killed by cholera

59+
people killed by diphtheria

 

About Mona Relief Yemen

Mona Relief is a 100% Yemeni Organization based in Sanaa, Yemen. We are an internationally recognized by U.N. and other organizations. We carry out projects in accordance with Yemeni relative laws and regulations.

We are recognized by the many different communities across Yemen. All of our work is documented with pictures, videos and stories directly from within Yemen. We are completely independent and none of our work is politicized.

Mona Relief, a 100% Yemeni Organization based in Yemen took the initiative with this campaign. With as simple as 30 USD, you are able to feed a family for a whole month.

The organization activities are mainly focused in the field of humanitarian relief and development by motivating and organizing volunteer, charitable and humanitarian work.

We had great success with the campaign from 2016 (#20foryemen) , 2017 and 2018 (Ramadan Campaign), we hope for an even greater success for this campaign. Our activities during 2017 increased rapidly with many projects. Our fundraising campaign for Aslam area of Hajjeh sets to begin here, and we hope you will help the people of Yemen to achieve it.


We do all the work ON THE GROUND in Yemen.

With the help of great volunteers!

OUR MISSION:

To prevent and alleviate human suffering in the face of emergencies with the power of collaborative efforts and the generosity of donors.

OUR VISION:

To be the most effective humanitarian organization in Yemen, with a view to preventing and alleviating human suffering, and promoting human dignity.

OUR VALUES:

Our fundamental principles promote: Humanity, Impartiality, Neutrality, Independence, Voluntary Service, Unity, Transparency.

You can have more idea about Mona Relief through visiting our website at this link: www.monareliefye.org

Or through our accounts at social media

Twitter
Www.twitter.com/monarelief
Www.twitter.com/monareliefye

Facebook

Www.facebook.com/monareliefye
Www.facebook.com/monareliefarabic

Instagram
Www.instagram.com/monarelief

Flickr
Www.flickr.com/monareliefyemen

 

Cant Donate? That's Okay.. Raise Awareness!

Not everybody can donate, but everybody can make a difference - it doesn't always have to be money, you can raise awareness by using the twitter hashtag: #yemen #saveyemen #monarelief to raise awareness about this campaign.

Don’t forget to include a link to the campaign. Share it with family and friends and help spread the message!

 

Last Words

This concept comes to fruition with the aim that every human being should be able to live with dignity without having to worry about the very basic right of sustenance.

Please give generously because the only way to live a pleasant life is either in someone's heart or someone's prayer. And in this case you get both!

Mona Relief is nothing without donors, and therefore we hope you will keep making us strong.

Don’t forget to visit our website https://www.monareliefye.org our previous projects.

story:
PLEASE NOTE:  The timer is only ~$240 NZD ($215.99 AUD), but the minimum campaign value is $500.

We've all been sparring on the mats without a proper timer, and been exhausted with no round end in sight.

BEHOLD!

This wall-mounted round timer lets you know at a glance how many more seconds of suffering are left before you get a break.

Donate what you can, and I'll order it from Ebay.  This is the cheapest one I could find.

http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/Boxing-Crossfit-Round-Timer-Interval-Clock-Gym-Fitness-Exercise-Count-Down-Ring-/181819109027?var&hash=item2a55436ea3

story:
Campaign Wrap-up

THANK YOU everyone for your amazing support!!! We are blown away with generous contributions from 469 Founding Contributors!

Please watch this space - we will post an update here very shortly...
 

Our recent progress

Sept 20: EPISODE #2: NOTICE OF LIABILITY WALKTHROUGH released (free for subscribers)
Sept 9: Mercola.com free screening of InPower Episode #1
Aug 26: EPISODE #1: A MASS ACTION OF LIABILITY released (free)
Aug 23: InPowered Podcast #02 - An Interview with EMF Warriors
Aug 21: InPowered Podcast #01 - Debra Greene PhD
Aug 20: Round 2 document templates & guides posted: ROUND 2
Aug 17: Episode #1 Preview Clip released (YouTube)
Aug 16: Document templates & guides posted: Canada / ROUND 1
Aug 14: Liability Action - 1-Page Overview (PDF)
Aug 12: InPower Strategic Roadmap released
Aug 12: Document templates & guides posted: USA / ROUND 1
Aug 6: Website goes live: InPowerMovement.com
Aug 6: Mercola.com free screening of our Take Back Your Power 2017

Who we are

InPower is an open source and crowd-funded movement of, by, and for the people. We believe that the combination of independent media, truth, faith in our Creator or Source, and the effective enforcement of accountability upon those in positions of social leadership are keys to preserving and restoring human rights. We are devoted to this purpose.

What we are building

We have uncovered and refined a revolutionary new process: enforcing the individual commercial liability of corporate executives and government representatives who are causing egregious harm. Propaganda and legal loopholes will no longer work for those putting profits before people — because we've learned to speak their "language", playing by the very rules of their very own system.

We are in the latter stages of building a new website (view it at inpowermovement.com!) to simplify and support this process, and to provide an online community hub so that anyone who wants to see their individual or the collective situation improve for the better, can participate in a rewarding and cost-effective manner.

WATCH EP#1 PREVIEW CLIP: EARLY RESULTS FROM THE INPOWER LIABILITY ACTION:


Our intent

The difference is this: the InPower Movement is dedicated to lovingly serve the life of the people. We do not seek vengeance. We seek accountability, justice, peace, alignment with truth, preservation of individual rights and removal of artificial barriers to a better world. (The artificial barriers seem to always be about more control and more money.)

 

Where we are

Over the past two years we've been building and refining a process of commercial liability that can be used by anyone to help hold people in power accountable and financially liable for their actions. We've piloted three "seed" groups with significant positive results from only a limited number of participants. We are 80% of the way towards completion and launch of a website with an action center designed to simplify and support large numbers of participants throughout the US and Canada.

What is the Liability Action?

A great question! Please see our new Overview document (added 14 August 2017):


 

Does it work?

Our seed groups have positive results, summarized on the document and Preview Clip, both posted above ↑. These results indicate that yes, commercial liability is indeed a viable mechanism to restore balance and accountability, wherever harm is being done.
 

Problems we will help solve

Our launch focus is directed specifically towards the hazards surrounding 'smart' meters. The next phase is to advocate for safety and transparency around vaccinations and the planned roll-out of 5G technology.


 

What we need

We are seeking funding to finalize and deliver a safe and efficient catalyst that makes this process readily available to all, with step-by-step guides, support, and together with each other in community. At this critical hour we are disclosing the solution we've been building and preparing behind the scenes for the past two years. We need your help to make this happen.

How will the funds be spent?


Can my contribution be tax-deductible?

Yes! We do have a 501(c)3 fiscal sponsor: From The Heart Productions, Inc.

For a tax-deductible contribution and receipt, please donate by check:

Please make payable to:
From the Heart Productions, Inc.

and write in memo line:
InPower Movement

then mail to:
1455 Mandalay Beach Road,
Oxnard, CA 93035

 

A history of bringing light where it is dark

Our work started by making the internationally award-winning documentary Take Back Your Power - a film exposing the 'smart' meter agenda - which was released worldwide in 2013.

With approximately 500 public screenings internationally and a quarter million viewings, we shone the light on a sinister subject: how utilities have teamed with governments to deploy harmful technology to surveil and market the data of everything we do in our homes.

(NOTE: We've just completed Take Back Your Power: 2017 Final Cut, which ships on September 30, 2017. Own and share this ultra-inspiring new cut on DVD on our website here.)


With the InPower Movement, this film has now birthed a revolutionary kind of activism that will enable millions to truly take back their power.

Our new InPower Docu-Series is a deep dive into a new, game-changing method of activism: the world's first mass-action of liability.

 

It's time to take back our power.

We see millions rising up. They are standing peacefully yet firmly, with equal authority in the language of the "system" — which, by putting money before people, has lost its moral conscience.

Those standing are InPowered with the confident knowledge of how to finally protect their rights, health, and families. They know who they are. They feel the fringes of a new hope. And they won't be denied a future.

Campaign Wrap-up
THANK YOU everyone for your amazing support!!! We are blown away with generous contributions from 469 Founding Contributors! 
Please watch this space - we will post an update here very shortly... 
Our recent progress
Sept 20: EPISODE #2: NOTICE OF LIABILITY WALKTHROUGH released (free for subscribers)Sept 9: Mercola.com free screening of InPower Episode #1Aug 26: EPISODE #1: A MASS ACTION OF LIABILITY released (free)Aug 23: InPowered Podcast #02 - An Interview with EMF WarriorsAug 21: InPowered Podcast #01 - Debra Greene PhDAug 20: Round 2 document templates & guides posted: ROUND 2Aug 17: Episode #1 Preview Clip released (YouTube)Aug 16: Document templates & guides posted: Canada / ROUND 1Aug 14: Liability Action - 1-Page Overview (PDF)Aug 12: InPower Strategic Roadmap releasedAug 12: Document templates & guides posted: USA / ROUND 1Aug 6: Website goes live: InPowerMovement.comAug 6: Mercola.com free screening of our Take Back Your Power 2017
Who we are
InPower is an open source and crowd-funded movement of, by, and for the people. We believe that the combination of independent media, truth, faith in our Creator or Source, and the effective enforcement of accountability upon those in positions of social leadership are keys to preserving and restoring human rights. We are devoted to this purpose.
What we are building
We have uncovered and refined a revolutionary new process: enforcing the individual commercial liability of corporate executives and government representatives who are causing egregious harm. Propaganda and legal loopholes will no longer work for those putting profits before people — because we've learned to speak their "language", playing by the very rules of their very own system.
We are in the latter stages of building a new website (view it at inpowermovement.com!) to simplify and support this process, and to provide an online community hub so that anyone who wants to see their individual or the collective situation improve for the better, can participate in a rewarding and cost-effective manner.

story:
Camp Nejeda!

My name is Andrea Innis, and I'm a junior at Hofstra University. I am a Captain and Vice President of the Hofstra University Women's Rugby Football Club, HUWRFC for short. What our team is trying to accomplish here is to raise enough money for a deserving child to go to Camp Nejeda for one week. You're probably thinking, "Why should I give my money? This camp isn't any different from other summer camps," but Camp Nejeda is truly one-of-a-kind. 

Camp Nejeda is a summer camp for children with diabetes. It's a one or two week getaway where they can just have fun and live their lives without a care in the world. Camp Nejeda provides the necessary care for these children to attend camp without them or their parents having to worry. Their counselors, nurses, and other various staff are among the best to ensure the safety and total summer camp experience for these children. And I know this because of...

Therese Hilger

Before you donate, some of you may be wondering where we found out about this organization. Well, here it is. My aunt, Therese Hilger, worked at Camp Nejeda. During the year she worked as a school nurse, but once the summer came, she would pack up and spend her days and nights at Camp Nejeda. She always put others before herself; it was just in her nature. 

In December of 2013, my Aunt Therese was diagnosed with Pancreatic Cancer. After months of endless fighting and continuous displays of strength, her battle ended when she passed away in February 2014. I have to say that I was taken aback, but not at all surprised by how many people came out to offer condolences to our family, many of whom were her coworkers at Camp Nejeda.

The Team

After missing a week of school to travel home, I was shocked to come back to school and my team and see their willingness to help me fundraise for this project that was only an inkling of an idea at the time. They then helped develop this idea, and here we are. They had never even met my aunt, but it was almost like they felt the loss as deeply as I did. My Aunt Therese never got to see me play rugby, but I'm sure she would have loved my team, as they would her. We may play a rough sport, but if that's taught us anything it's that when you set out to accomplish a goal, you don't stop until you've done it. And we would love nothing more than to accomplish this for my aunt, Therese Hilger. 

Donate!

Although we are fundraising to send a child with diabetes to Camp Nejeda, the perks that we are offering are all in the name of Pancreatic Cancer Awareness. Please consider donating to our cause!

story:
On Sept. 6, 2012, I will be "Sent to Jail" and need to be bailed-out! All money raised will be donated to the Muscular Dystrophy Association (MDA) in order to help send more kids to camp. 

A few years ago I got the opportunity to volunteer at one of these summer camps. I was paired with a child (Matthew) for a week and got to spend every waking minute with him, trying my best to lift his spirits and make sure that week was the best of his year. I got to see first-hand the incredible smiles and life-changing days these children experience at this camp - and with a donation, you can help make that happen. 

All dollar amounts are accepted and will go directly to make life-changing event happen. 

As a better example of what your money goes to: 
$80 = One minute of research 
$100 = Support Group Session 
$800 = Sends one child to MDA Summer Camp 

On Sept. 6, I will be picked up by an MDA officer, hand-cuffed and taken to Mickey Mantle Steakhouse to get my mugshot and "booked" and only MDA bail money can get me out. That's where you come in. Please help with my "BAIL" and at the same time, help a child gain the memories of summer camp. 

Will you donate?

story:
You can still be part of our commitment to Justice!  See our new campaign at

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/justice-justice-1964-an-extra-measure-of-justice/x/6203944

Half-a-century ago, 16 Rabbis and one Reform Movement administrator came to St. Augustine at the request of Reverend Martin Luther King, Jr. On June 18, 1964 they were swept up in the largest mass arrest of Rabbis in US history. Justice Justice 1964 is part of the St. Augustine Jewish Historical Society, a group committed to the telling of the story of the roles played by Jews in the "Oldest City's" 450 year history. Let's all bring back to St. Augustine those among the 17 who are able so that they might retell their story, igniting a sense of national commitment to the ideals of the Prophet Amos (5:24), as often quoted by Dr. King,  וְיִגַּל כַּמַּיִם, מִשְׁפָּט; וּצְדָקָה, כְּנַחַל אֵיתָן  Let Justice well up as the waters and righteousness like a mighty stream! 

The task before us requires $8000 to provide airfare, ground transportation and accommodations for those heroes who are able to join us.  Donors at appropriate levels will have an opportunity to meet and speak with these heroes at a special luncheon, a wine and cheese reception, to hold reserved seats at the forum on the eve of the 50th anniversary ceremony, to have names included in the event program.  All funds, whether our goal is reached or not, will be used to the benefit of our visiting heroes. 

Donors are partners in the effort to let the world know that silence is not an acceptable response to injustice and inhumane behavior wherever and whenever it takes place. The darkness that fell across Europe from 1933 through 1945 helps explain why we can never stand "idly by the blood of our neighbors!" 

This story of the support for human dignity is one of the most "undertold" episodes in the ongoing history of  Jewish involvement in the struggle for Civil Rights.  It is equally "undertold" within the saga of the St. Augustine Movement that ultimately led to the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. 

As an Internal Revenue Code Section 501 c 3 organization, reports detailing income and expenditures are available for public inspection in the St. Augustine Jewish Historical Society's IRS Form 990 available on line.  Participation, at any level, in this campaign elevates us all.  Tell your family, friends and neighbors!


“Some of the funding for this program was provided through a grant from the Florida Humanities Council with funds from the National Endowment for the Humanities. Any views, findings, conclusions or recommendations expressed in this program do not necessarily represent those of the Florida Humanities Council or the National Endowment for the Humanities.

story:
Historia

GirlGov nació en USA como parte de Woman and Girls Foundation y buscaba enviar a adolescentes a la capital para aprender como funcionaba el gobierno. Gianina Marquez, activista de derechos de los derechos humanos de la mujer, tuvo la oportunidad de vivir de cerca este programa y quizo traerlo al Perú.  El lanzamiento de GirlGov Perú fue realizado el 11 de octubre del 2018 a las 6:30 p.m. y empezará a ser desarrollado en Marzo de este año.

El programa es gratuito y de realiza durante un año. La primera promoción estará formada por 70 niñas y adolescentes de Lima Metropolitana de entre 12 y 17 años de edad. En este año, se introducirán temas de gobierno, filantropía, participación ciudadana y liderazgo. No solo eso, se motivará a que se relacionen con representantes políticos y que planteen desde sus conocimientos campañas e iniciativas que contribuyan con el país.

 

Qué necesitamos y qué obtienes

GirlGov Perú necesita mucha ayuda, pero para comenzar es indispensable el financiamiento de movilidad y snacks para las 70 niñas con las que se iniciará el proyecto. Con US$ 54.00 al año, cada una de las niñas podrá movilizarse desde sus casas hasta el punto de los talleres; y más US$ 44.00, apróximadamente, estás podrán contar con un refrigerio básico de fruta, sandwich y agua todos los meses que dura el programa. Tu ayuda es muy importante, hará que esto se haga realidad.

¿Qué obtienes?

La satisfacción de ayudar a empoderar a futuras mujeres de nuestro país, que estarán listas para afrontar el futuro y hacer un cambio importante de la realidad social y política del país. !Te estas uniendo a la lucha por los derechos de las niñas e igualdad de oportunidades!
Lo último y no menos importante, obtienes el eterno agradecimiento de todos por haber sido agente del cambio.

 

El Impacto

Con solo iniciar este programa estamos seguros que se abrirá una oportunidad para que niñas y adolescentes enfrenten la toma de decisiones de manera positiva pues se les dará todas las herramientas posibles para afrontar el día a día y todo tipo de temas que aparezcan ya sean  cotidianos, sociales, culturales, entre otros. 

 

Riesgos y Retos

La única manera de lograr el objetivo y superar cualquier problema en el camino es recibir el apoyo que GirlGov Perú requiere. Solo TU ayuda superará obstáculos, resolverá retos y eliminará todo aquello que dificulte la llegada a la meta.

 

Otras maneras de ayudar

Si no puedes contribuir con nuestra campaña recuerda que "Sharing is Caring", si compartes nuestra campaña también estarás colaborando con la organización GirlGovPerú .

story:
THE DIFFERENCE WE CAN MAKE TOGETHER

"Climate change is an immediate and significant threat to our communities and our economy." - Justin Trudeau during the 2015 election.

"It's well known that one of the consequences of climate change will be a greater prevalence of extreme weather events around the planet."  - Justin Trudeau (May 4, 2016)

As of August 15th, 2018 there are 566 wildfires burning in BC, thousands of people are being evacuated from their homes and the province has declared a state of emergency.  

Since 1970, wildland fire management expenditures across Canada have been rising by about $120 million per decade - by 2040 the government expects this spending to double.

The Trudeau Liberals' solution? Spend $4.5 billion bailing out the Kinder Morgan pipeline. The climate impacts of that very pipeline are projected to cost us $2.1 to $8.7 billion in upfront costs, and at least $675 million a year, for as long as the pipeline operates. So that's stupid, but it's also why Trudeau doesn't want to connect wildfire costs to climate change - because it exposes the deadly idiocy of his big oil bailout. Together we can force him to do just that.

Your money is going to help people whose lives have been devastated by climate change. Furthermore, the more we help people the more attention this campaign will get. We'll execute a national and international media strategy to create headlines that will force the Trudeau government to face the disastrous impacts of their pro-fossil fuel policies.

Where's the money going?

50% of the money raised will go to support the Red Cross wildfire relief in Canada. The other 50% goes to support the impoverished Filipino community of Anibong, Leyte whose people are being displaced by stronger and stronger storms.

Want to help without donating? Join our e-mail list!


Who are we?

We're some of the same Canadian comedians and filmmakers who created ShitHarperDid.com. We've got a long history of using tactical media and creative confrontations to shift political culture in Canada. Together with our supporters across the country we've run numerous successful crowdfunding campaigns in the past. For instance, in 2014 we noticed that the Conservative government had failed to buy the URL EconomicActionPlan.ca for their multimillion dollar propaganda campaign. We bought the web address for $6.99 and then used it to crowdfund over $90,000 to air parody Conservative ads on national television including during the Stanley Cup Playoffs on CBC’s Hockey Night In Canada while simultaneously raising thousands of dollars for food banks in the nation's most impoverished communities.

Reactions to our past work:

"The viral phenomenon that captured the digital zeitgeist during the 2011 election... is back with a vengeance."
—Huffington Post

"Viral comedy site with the unprintable name turns to political activism"
—Globe & Mail

“Wreaking havoc on the Conservative party’s image.”
—Post Media

"Merry band of Vancouver pranksters relaunch ShitHarperDid with new focus on real activism"
—Vancouver Sun

“Winning the viral video war with a stealth campaign that’s been spreading like prairie wildfire.”
—Globe & Mail

“I rarely say things like H*ly Cr*p, but: Lookit this.” 
—Margaret Atwood

We'll execute a national and international media strategy to create headlines that will force the Trudeau government to face the disastrous impacts of their pro-fossil fuel policies.

Where's the money going?
50% of the money raised will go to support the Red Cross wildfire relief in Canada. The other 50% goes to support the impoverished Filipino community of Anibong, Leyte whose people are being displaced by stronger and stronger storms.

Want to help without donating? Join our e-mail list!

Who are we?We're some of the same Canadian comedians and filmmakers who created ShitHarperDid.com. We've got a long history of using tactical media and creative confrontations to shift political culture in Canada. Together with our supporters across the country we've run numerous successful crowdfunding campaigns in the past. For instance, in 2014 we noticed that the Conservative government had failed to buy the URL EconomicActionPlan.ca for their multimillion dollar propaganda campaign. We bought the web address for $6.99 and then used it to crowdfund over $90,000 to air parody Conservative ads on national television including during the Stanley Cup Playoffs on CBC’s Hockey Night In Canada while simultaneously raising thousands of dollars for food banks in the nation's most impoverished communities.Reactions to our past work:"The viral phenomenon that captured the digital zeitgeist during the 2011 election... is back with a vengeance."—Huffington Post"Viral comedy site with the unprintable name turns to political activism"—Globe & Mail“Wreaking havoc on the Conservative party’s image.”—Post Media"Merry band of Vancouver pranksters relaunch ShitHarperDid with new focus on real activism"—Vancouver Sun“Winning the viral video war with a stealth campaign that’s been spreading like prairie wildfire.”—Globe & Mail“I rarely say things like H*ly Cr*p, but: Lookit this.” —Margaret Atwood

story:
The Scoop

When a child enters foster care, it can take time to find a place where that child can stay while the case worker sets up a place for that child (or children) to go. Many times, siblings are not able to stay together due to a deficiently in homes that are available. 

What other city's around the country have found is that when given 72 hours, the success rate of finding an in-county home and the ability to keep siblings together greater increases. 

72 hours. That's all it takes to give the case worker time to find the best living situation.

But currently, they don't have 72 hours so children and youth can end up going to another county, being placed in a group home or in very extreme circumstances, can be placed out of state. 

How Can You Help?

Our non-profit, Faith, Hope & Love, has determined that we can provide those 72 hours. By opening a receiving home in Racine County, our facility will be able to house 8-10 children in a natural home environment, with toys, games, a kitchen, bedrooms and a living room. 

While the children are in our care, they will receive food, clothing, medical needs and most importantly, love. We will work hard to support the foster system and give them the time they need to find the best home for our children. 

These Are OUR Children

Society is a family. These are OUR children. They are our responsibility. As adult members of society, it is our responsibility to care for the vulnerable, impressionable and those in need. By taking care of our kids, we are investing in our community, in our future and most importantly, in the life of a child or youth that is unable to control the situations surrounding their lives. 

Every bit matters. If you can give $5, please do. If you can give more, please do :) 

Find Out More About Us

www.fhlforkids.org

www.unwantedthefilm.com 

http://racinecounty.com/government/human-servic...

story:
Reality:

Hawaii isn’t always the paradise it’s made out to be. It is home to nearly 8000 homeless, with over half of them living on the island of Oahu.

The situation has gotten so bad that in 2015 the governor declared the homeless situation to be a “State of emergency.”

The homelessness problem is very complex, with mental illness, poor education, rising cost of living all contributing to the recent steep rise in homeless. There is no simple fix.

Who we are:

Everyone is Ohana is a group of students making an effort to make a difference. We have seen the needs in the community first hand, and have decided to do something about it. Every project that we have led thus far has been focused on helping students and members of the community see the homeless as people.

What we believe:

We believe that everyone should be treated fairly and as a human being. We like to think of everyone as one big family. We believe that the needs of the homeless are far too varied to be able to be solved by one blanket solution. Because of this we are working with each of them on an individual level. We believe that as we see them as valuable parts of society, as we listen to them, and encourage them to do better, that they will then be empowered to rise to the level that we see them at. If all we ever expect from, and see is a drug addict, then that’s all they ever will be. But if you see them as a brother, a friend, a hard worker. Then it allows them to improve.

We believe that to help someone overcome their challenges and no longer be homeless they need 3 things.

1. Health

2. Shelter/security

3. Purpose

Most other organizations are only focusing on number 2, getting them into homeless shelters or affordable housing. However 80% of the homeless that stay in the shelters end up back on the street within a year. It is not a permanent solution. We are trying to address all three, as a more holistic approach.

What’s being done:

We have spent alot of time on the ground simply getting to know the homeless. We have passed out food, clothing, camping supplies. We have plans for service projects that will give them free haircuts, job training's, and even showers. But most importantly we have developed relationships with them, and they trust us.

We have the resources already to make a difference. We have volunteers, a continual supply of food donated from local restaurants (Kualoa ranch as well as the Polynesian culture center). As well as the surplus items from the student run thrift store (Give and take). We have been able to address some of their short term needs, and we are now hoping take the next step further and help address their more serious long term needs.  

Why we need you:

We are working with our partners to develop curriculum that can help rehabilitate the homeless so that they can overcome the barriers that are keeping them homeless. Programs that teach budgeting and financial accountability, addiction recovery programs, and trade school skills that can help them add value in the job market. We don’t claim to know the answer to help all of the homeless, but if we can teach someone something that will improve their lives, we feel it is our duty to try.

We also need cash donations to be able to buy the items that we have not been able to get donated. Things that they are in immediate need of, such as: Clean underwear, hygiene items, feminine supplies, water filters, over the counter medicine, and other things that we have not gotten donated.

What we need you to do:

Next time you see a homeless person, please, try talking to them. See what their story is before being so quick to judge them. They may just teach you something. We have come to realize that there is a “Pearl” inside of everyone including the homeless, and the longer you talk with someone and invest in your relationship, the more good that you are able to see in them. Please help us to bring out the good parts of these wonderful people. They are our Ohana.

In addition...

Please donate what you can.

80% of this fundraiser will go towards buying the items that the homeless have directly requested.

10% will go towards helping us start a government recognized non profit.

10% will be used for organization purposes. (Buying tables so we don’t have to pass out clothes on the floor, etc).

Mahalo!

Rewards Timeline:

All rewards will be redeemed the day after the campaign is finished (April 14th)

$1 Social Media shout out!

A post thanking you by name on our Facebook and Instagram account. -April 14th

$10 Sticker with custom logo

A sticker sporting our custom "Everyone is Ohana Logo." This will be mailed out on April 14th, expected delivery date is before April 20th.

$25 Ohana socks!

Custom designed socks in four colors. Dark blue, light blue, yellow and black. 

This will be mailed out on April 14th, expected delivery date is before April 20th.

$35 Everyone is Ohana T-Shirt

Custom made T-shirts sporting our "Everyone is Ohana" Logo. Orders will be shipped on April 14th, expected delivery date is before April 20th.

$250 Family Package

Social media shout out, 3 Ohana stickers, 3 Ohana socks, 3 Ohana T-Shirts. Will be shipped out April 14th, expected deliver date is before April 20th. 

Meet some of our friends:

This is Anna! She is originally from Maui, but lived in Washington state most of her life. She moved back to Hawaii 2 months ago and has been struggling to get a job ever since. When we asked her what she needed she told us "Nice clothes for a job interview." She told us that she had been applying for jobs and was getting read for some job interviews in town. We were able to find her some clothes for her from our thrift store, a gave them to her later that week. Then a week later we went back to see how the interview went, and we found out from our other homeless friends there that she got the job and moved closer to where her job is (they didn't know much details, just that she didn't live there anymore). While we wish we had kept in better contact with her, we're happy that we were able to play a small part in her getting back on her feet!

Roger moved here from the Philippines when he was 24. He came here with his father to work as a contractor on the military base. When that job was finished he took up landscaping, and has been a landscaper since 1983. His income has generally stayed the same, but with rising cost of living and rent he has no longer been able to afford an apartment. He is still working part time as landscaper and makes around $600 every two weeks. 6 months ago he lived in an apartment that costed $600 a month. He is no longer able to afford to pay rent as well as his medical bills from his recent sickness, so he was forced to leave and is now homeless in wahiawa. We're hoping to connect him with medical services as well as employment services that can help him get a higher paying job and lower his current medical bills. 

These are just two of many of our homeless friends on the island. Each Saturday we are going out and doing various service projects with the homeless. We hope to meet and learn about all of the homeless on the island, and then share their stories with others so that everyone can understand who these people are, and what kind of help they need. As we raise awareness we are also searching for resources that can help them overcome their individual challenges. 

Project timeline:

We are planning on becoming an official government recognized non-profit by summer of 2018, our goal is mid July. 

Our service projects go on fairly regularly on Saturdays, we plan to pass out the supplies financed from this fundraiser before the end of May. These supplies include: Clean underwear, medical supplies/first aid kits, camping gear, personal hygiene items, and other items that we find need for on an as need basis. 

Our team:

Bryce Coleman: Bryce is an intercultural peacebuilding major and is getting his minor in Entrepreneurship here at BYU Hawaii. He hopes to combine the skills he's learning in peacebuilding and entrepreneurship to become a social entrepreneur, and provide relief for those suffering around the world. He is passionate about helping the homeless and is the founder of the Everyone is Ohana campaign. 

Role: Team Leader, service project coordinator. 

Summer Knudsen

Video editor, runs the social media accounts

Karina Loeza

Coordinates activities between students and the local organizations.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name's Ivy. I'm a co-founder and the program director of a grassroots group called Gender Benders. Three years ago we started the first all inclusive trans* summer camp in South Carolina. 

Last year Camp GB hosted more than 50 attendees for 4 days of community, fellowship, free legal clinics and  training on how to pass equality measures locally and on college campuses. Camp GB is about equipping LGBT* people with the support and skills to be leaders every day as we seek both legal and lived equality. 

Our first two years we packed people in like sardines on air mattresses at a local campground that donated space for our lodging. We have finally outgrown borrowed air mattresses and free office space. So, that's why we're moving Camp GB to a larger campground with real dormitories, beds, and a kitchen staff. Our leadership team is especially excited about these changes, because it will provide us with the opportunity to focus more of our time on programing. 

Relationship building and support are of utmost importance for our segment of the population. 41% of trans* people have attempted suicide. This means our community's attempted suicide rate is nearly 10 times higher than the national average. We strive to increase connectivity among our members and provide them with coping skills, and most importantly, support. 

Trans* folks in South Carolina are chronically unemployed and underemployed as many of our people face discrimination and harassment in the workplace. We're working hard to make camp accessible for all of our members, but we can't do it without your help! 100% of what we are able to raise for Camp GB will go directly to our scholarship fund to increase accessibility for our members. Even a small donation will make a huge impact on the lives of camp attendees. 


What We Need & Where Your Money Is Going

We have a goal of raising $2,500 for Camp GB this year. The cost for camp registration is $85 per person and includes lodging, all meals, meetings, trainings, and legal clinics. If we are able to reach our fundraising goal we will be able to provide full and partial scholarships to more than 35 people!  The number of scholarships we are able to provide depends directly on the amount of money we are able to raise.

What will your donation buy?

  • A gift of $20 will cover the cost one night's lodging for a GB
  • A gift of $45 will provide one GB with a 50% scholarship 
  • A gift of $85 will provide one GB with a  full scholarship
  • A gift of $170 will provide two GBs with full scholarships
  • A gift of $250 will provide three GBs with full scholarships!
No donation is too small to make a BIG difference, and EVERY gift is appreciated! 


The Impact 


Many of our GBs don't get to live as their true selves when they are at school, work, with family, or even just at the grocery store. Those moments when our group is together is a small refuge is a sea of forces invisibility. The relationships that are forged over team building activities as camp are the relationships that carry people through on the bad days.

Two of our co-leaders just completed their Masters degrees. One is a Licensed Master of Social Work (who happens to be my beautiful fiancé) who leads a partner support group for many of our member's 'Better Halves' and  workshops on coping skills.  The other just completed his Masters in Divinity. He leads people who struggle with reconciling their identity with their faith in deep spiritual reconciliation work. This work has been freeing and life changing for many of our members. 

Last year we were proud to partner with  Campaign for Southern Equality in leading training on how to pass equality measures locally and on college campuses as well as providing two free legal clinics. They provided our members with thousands of dollars in free legal services offering help with name change paperwork and completing Health Care Powers of Attorney for many group members. 

It is difficult to put into words what camp means to us. It is one of the most important pieces of work we do. What happens is nothing short of magic when we get to live with people we are allowed to bring our full selves to the table with for a few days. We don't want any of our members to miss this opportunity because they can't afford the registration fee. Sadly we know the cost will prevent many people from being able to attend. That's why we really need your help. Every single dollar we raise will go directly to the attendees who can't come if we can't lower the expense. 


Ways You Can Help

If you can please consider making a donation to help us make Camp GB more accessible to attendees. Even if you can't make a donation you can still help. Please help us make noise about this campaign! Share this campaign through your Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, Tumblr, and email networks. Getting the word out to folks makes a huge difference!

We promise to post lots of camp pictures on Facebook. Thank you for all your continued support! We really couldn't do this work without people like you who keep this little volunteer ran organization going.

story:
MWRN's JUSTICE: KOH TAO MURDER CASE NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT FOR THE APPEALS PROCESS AGAINST KOH SAMUI COURT RULING OF GUILTY (WITH DEATH PENALTY IMPOSED) AGAINST ZAW LIN & WAI PHYO ON DEC 24th 2015 FOR ALLEGED INVOLVEMENT IN THE KOH TAO MURDERS. REGION 8 APPEALS COURT UPHELD THIS RULING ON 23RD FEBRUARY 2017 AND THE DEFENSE TEAM IS NOW CURRENTLY PREPARING ITS APPEAL ON THE CASE TO THAILAND'S FINAL SUPREME COURT. PLEASE CONTINUE TO SUPPORT OUR TEAM AS THE MORE FUNDS RAISED, MORE EFFECTIVE MWRN/THE ACCUSED'S DEFENSE TEAM CAN BE AND THE MORE HUMANITARIAN SUPPORT WE CAN PROVIDE TO THE ACCUSED. 

 

‘Thank you everyone who has supported us. We are innocent and we were not involved in this horrific crime, we didn't kill. We want freedom. We are confident the truth of this case will come out during the appeals process and we are confident we will eventually be released on appeal. With everyone's encouragement we will stay strong until the end and finally we will surely get our freedom after our appeals process. We will meditate every day and pray to Buddha for freedom but also for peace and happiness of all those in the world, including the Koh Tao victims.' Message from Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, Death Row, Nakhon Si Thammarat Prison, Dec. 28th 2015 

GUARDIAN - Thailand backpacker murders: Burmese workers sentenced to death Koh Tao: The Case That Put Thailand on Trial Why UK Role in Koh Tao Case Still Worries Rights Groups

AFP - Pair Convicted of Koh Tao Murders Have Lost Appeal Against the Death Penalty

BBC - Thai beach murders: Convicted men lose death sentence appeal​

The truth is we are not really involved in this case. We want you to help us. So we write this letter to you from our imprisonment… We do not want to be in jail anymore… We think it is injustice that we are in the jail. We want justice and equality.’ – Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo’s letter to Aung San Suu Kyi, Dec. 2014
 

BBC - Thailand beach murders verdict: A flawed and muddled investigation

TELEGRAPH - Koh Tao: Killings that put a country's justice system on trial Koh Tao Murders: Burmese Migrants Sentenced to Death

 

The Migrant Worker Rights Network (MWRN) represents all migrant workers in Thailand. The MWRN aims to support and raise funds, with your vital assistance, for the defense and humanitarian supporting during imprisonment of Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo (Win Zaw Htun), two 22 year old Myanmar workers prosecuted and convicted with a death penalty applied on 24th Dec 2015 for the rape and murder of Hannah Witheridge and murder of David Miller, both British tourists, which occurred on Koh Tao Island, Thailand in Sept 2014.

 

The guilty verdict was given on December 24th 2015 when both Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were both found guilty of rape and murder and given the death sentence. The accused are currently on death row at Bang Kwang high security prison in Nonthaburi Province of Thailand near to Bangkok. On 23rd February 2017, Region 8 Appeals Court upheld the conviction and death penalty sentence against the two accused and this judgement is currently pending appeal by the defense team to Thailand's Supreme Court.

The appeals process for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo against their verdict and sentencing is a long one. It was first to the Appeals Court (submitted in May 2016, 9-12 months was expected for verdict delivered in February 2017) and then on to the Supreme Court (2-5 years after original conviction expected for final verdict). The final appeal to the Supreme Court has now commenced with a team of lawyers from the Lawyers Council of Thailand working on the appeal alongside MWRN and a number of domestic and foreign criminal justice/crime scene/forensics experts. 

 

MWRN’s involvement in the Koh Tao murder case began in Oct 2014 amidst widespread allegations regarding:

  1. Arrest of ‘scapegoats’.
  2. Torture of Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo during detention prior to questioning by investigation officials.
  3. Improper collection of forensic evidence during crime scene investigations.
  4. Intimidation and abuse of witnesses and suspects

Guardian on Torture Allegations in Koh Tao Case

 

MWRN intends to contribute to a fair appeals process post conviction for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo to prevent a potential miscarriage of justice that would impact negatively on families, communities and everyone deeply affected by this case. MWRN also wants to ensure that migrants, who contribute much through their work and presence to the prosperity of Koh Tao and to Thailand, will feel justice is achieved from this case. In addition to families and friends of all those concerned, Thailand’s migrant community has been deeply impacted and moved by the tragic deaths of Hannah and David and the arrest and prosecution of Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, their fellow nationals, for the crime. The migrant community and those in Myanmar have rose up against the verdict and protests continue.

‘A fair appeals process for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo is essential to ensure, with more confidence, that those guilty of this crime are held accountable and that there is no punishment of the wrong people. It would be a double injustice if  the lack of a legal defense team to carry out defense work effectively for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, meant that the real killers went free whilst innocent people were jailed, even executed. If Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo are innocent, no-one wants such a situation to arise. That’s why MWRN has set up this fund, to support some significant defense related costs in this case.’ - Ko Sein Htay, MWRN President/Fund Administrator

 

 

Guardian on Concerns Over Koh Tao Fair Trial

Why Does MWRN Need YOU?

‘Now we have seen the light of hope for justice and truth as so many people have become involved in defending us and supporting our case.’ – Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo, Feb. 2015

In order to minimise risk of a miscarriage of justice, MWRN continues to publicly seek financial/other practical support to contribute our part of costs needed to cover all expenses, to ensure a fair trial through an effective appeals process for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo. Expenses MWRN seek to contribute to now include:

  1. Flights and travel costs for defense team members involved in attending meetings and planning sessions concerning the appeal of the convictions and sentencing and for visits to Bang Kwang Prison to meet with the accused during the appeals process
  2. Travel/accommodation costs for expert advisors during the appeals process 
  3. Prison support costs for Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo during continued detention in Bang Kwang Prison, including travel costs for prison visitors

It is important to note that all those working on the defense case (including lawyers, assistants, investigators, prison visitors, translators and campaigners) are doing so pro-bono or free of charge. Fundraising only seeks to cover expenses. The Lawyers Council of Thailand is also supporting some of the defense team by covering basic expenses for main practicing lawyers.

MWRN previously raised 812, 000 Thai Baht (around US$25, 000) to assist the defense of Wai Phyo and Zaw Lin in late 2014. These funds were exhausted during the emergency and initial stages of the defense engagement. Youcaring website unexpectedly, and without notice, withdrew MWRN's 'Justice: Koh Tao Case' fundraiser from its site in January 2015, claiming a sudden change of website regulations to disallow criminal defense fundraisers. This is why MWRN launched this an urgent trial preparation STAGE TWO two fundraiser with Indiegogo. Within 48 days of starting this 60 day campaign, MWRN met our £10,000 modest fundraising target and our campaign moved into InDemand to allow us to keep up the push for further donations to make our work more effective (for updates on the spending of all MWRN raised funds, please see the updates section of this site). MWRN has now raised a total of over 2 million baht for this case defence of which almost all funds have been exhausted during the trial and first instance appeals process, The fundraiser now moves into STAGE THREE for the Supreme Court appeals process and for continued humanitarian support to the 2 convicted men. 

 OUR Challenges

 

 

‘Before and during the case investigation we had no chance to speak out on our innocence or the truth. We are victims of influential people.' – Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo’s message written in court on 26th Dec. 2014

Our challenge is to achieve justice in this carefully monitored case, whilst working within the boundaries of the Thai judicial system, with its pride and reputation at stake. There is also the challenge of the on-going situation of powerlessness, discrimination and exploitation faced by migrant workers in Thailand. Genuine justice is obtained through ensuring the equality of resources for both the prosecution and defense teams. It is essential that the defense team has the resources to appeal their case and prepare and appeal to the best of their ability, to ensure that two innocent young men are not convicted and possibly executed for these murders. In this worse case scenario, there would be no justice for Hannah and David and those who loved them, but only two more innocent victims in this very disturbing and important trial.

Guardian on Complaints Against UK Government 

Guardian on UK Government Protest Koh Tao Case Investigation

 

The defense team, consisting of pro bono lawyers associated with the Lawyers Council of Thailand and assisted by rights activists, face an exceptional challenge. More than a hundred witnesses and a thousand pages of statements/forensic case related evidence was put forward in this case and had to be understood. 21 days of trial testimony by 34 witnesses and more than a thousand pages of a prosecution file needs to be reviewed again for the appeals process, as well as the new appeals court judgement and prosecution submissions made as part of this process, All appeals processes are conducted in the Thai language and must then be translated into the Burmese and English language. Even more financial and practical constraints are faced in working with experts outside of Thailand, to prevent a miscarriage of justice.
