The Migrant Workers Rights Network (MWRN) is a membership based organisation of workers from Myanmar working across the world. MWRN was founded in March 2009 by 9 Myanmar migrant leaders in Thailand who strongly believed empowerment of migrants was the best way to protect themselves in their vulnerable situation as migrant workers. The founders’ goal for MWRN is to promote and strengthen Myanmar migrant’s rights by raising awareness, promoting access to justice and negotiation with employers and officials and advocating for sustainable migration policy change.

 


--------------------
 

 

Koh Tao Case Background

 

 

 

In the early morning of 15th September 2014, two young British tourists Hannah Witheridge (23) and David Miller (24) were murdered on Koh Tao, a popular tourist destination in the Gulf of Thailand. The two victim’s bodies were reportedly found amongst rocks in a secluded area of the popular Sairee Beach.

Two weeks into the murder investigation, police had yet to charge anyone with the murders. Amidst conflicting statements regarding evidence and suspects, the investigation appeared increasingly disorganised.

Investigators of this case have been criticised for the alleged mishandling of forensic evidence, abuse of suspects and intimidation of witnesses, particularly migrant workers living on Koh Tao.

A huge shadow has been cast, not only over the safety of tourism, but also over the reliability of the criminal justice system in Thailand, to hold someone responsible for these high profile murders. 

Whilst under pressure to make an arrest, Thai officials suggested that migrant workers committed these murders. For many, these statements reflected the historical and systematic discrimination long faced by migrant workers in Thailand. Migrant workers are still frequent victims of abuse and extortion by Thai law enforcement officials. They are consistently treated like second-class citizens, with little access to effective justice, remedies or any complaint mechanisms.

Blanket DNA testing of the migrant community was then undertaken amidst fears that the migrant community would be persecuted as ‘scapegoats’ for these murders, as a result of their powerlessness to fight back. Shortly after the murders, migrant workers on Koh Tao began to petition MWRN with video and photographic evidence alleging physical and verbal abuse by investigation officials during questionings. Migrant communities throughout Thailand also communicated to MWRN their concerns that Thai authorities would unfairly scapegoat Myanmar migrant workers for these horrific murders.

 

Guardian on Koh Tao Murder Case Investigation Confusion

 

 

The Arrest of Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo

 

Thai police detained Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun (Wai Phyo), two young Myanmar migrant workers from the impoverished Rakhine State in the far West of Myanmar, on 2nd October 2014. Zaw Lin (21) worked at Brother Bar and Wai Phyo (21) worked at Safety Stop restaurant on Koh Tao at the time of the murders.

Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo’s purpose in Thailand was to send money home to support their parents and siblings living in poverty in Myanmar. Both had been working on Koh Tao for several years.

 

 

Guardian on Koh Tao Case Arrests

 

Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo’s Claims of Innocence

 

 

During the initial weeks of detention in Koh Samui prison, Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were permanently shackled and confined to a high security cell 24 hours a day, only being allowed out to meet with authorised visitors. Prison authorities justified this treatment based on suicide risks and the potential danger both supposedly posed to fellow prisoners. Following complaints by rights groups, Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were eventually unshackled and allowed to join other prisoners outside of their cell during daytime hours only.

Several days after being arrested, Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo told human rights monitors at Koh Samui prison that they were abused and tortured following detention, prior to being handed over to investigation officials. A week later, both pleaded innocence to rights lawyers organised for them. Both alleged their heads were covered with bags to imitate suffocation, while they were also threatened with electrocution, burning and execution to elicit confessions. Misconduct of translators assisting investigators was also alleged.

‘We are poor, so we came to Thailand to work and save money…In the beginning when we arrived in Thailand we suffered many difficulties, we do not want to be suffering like poor people and we tried to work hard and sent money back to our parents regularly, we were happy so much for that. But now our hopes are broken. We are worried about our parents, who will support them? And we miss our parents every day, when we miss them we are crying…’ – Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo’s letter to Aung San Suu Kyi, Dec. 2014

Guardian on Accused Appeal for Witnesses

 

 

Alleged Abuse of Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo

Several days after being arrested, Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo told human rights monitors at Koh Samui prison that they were tortured following detention, prior to being handed over to investigation officials. A week later, both pleaded innocent to rights lawyers organised for them. Both alleged their heads were covered with bags to imitate suffocation while they were threatened with electrocution, burning and execution to elicit confessions. Misconduct of translators assisting investigators was also alleged. The alleged abuse of the accused was outlined in detail at trial and included sexual assault also.

Guardian on Koh Tao Case Torture Allegations

 

The Formal Charges and Not Guilty Pleas

Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were officially arraigned on 4th and 8th December 2014 at Koh Samui Court by the Koh Samui prosecutor's office. The charges levied against them included: killing the two deceased intentionally; killing Hannah to cover up her rape and to avoid punishment; raping and assaulting Hannah with violent acts; being non-Thai nationals entering into Thailand irregularly and remaining in Thailand irregularly; and Wei Phyo is charged alone with theft of a mobile phone and a pair of sunglasses, both allegedly belonging to David Miller. Both Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo pleaded not guilty to all the charges filed against them.

Guardian on Formal Charges

‘We are not perfect and the best sons in our families, but we wish to remind everyone we did not commit this cunning and barbarian crime.’ – Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo, Feb 2015

 

UK Government Case Investigation

 

There followed intense media coverage and public concern which was expressed in the form of online campaigns regarding the reliability of the Thai police investigation and the arrest of Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo. UK Prime Minister David Cameron and UK authorities strongly engaged Thai officials. Officials from the UK sought to send a team of qualified British police to Thailand to investigate the murders and report back to the deceased’s families. Since this time, MWRN and Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo’s defense team have been working with Reprieve in London to explore the UK Government’s role in investigating this case. This led to disclosure of a Metropolitan Police letter dated 19th December 2014 that stated in summary:

  • The Metropolitan police did not conduct any investigations into these murders in Thailand. Instead, during a visit to Thailand in November 2014, three UK police officials were granted observer status only to limited parts of the Thai police investigation, they did not provide any advice or assistance, and relied on the translation services of a Thai police translator. During their visit these officials did not take possession of any evidence, physical or forensic, and did not collect exhibits, interviews or statements
  • The Metropolitan police were preparing a report on observations from their visit to Thailand, to be completed in January 2015. This report was to be for internal use only and would not be shared with the Thai authorities or other persons. Furthermore, the request from the defense team to review this report was denied as, relying on an exemption under the UK data protection law, it would ‘clearly prejudice’ the criminal prosecution in question and undermine prevention and detection of crime 
  • No other case information would be shared with Thai authorities or the defense team by UK authorities for use in a criminal process which lacks the necessary assurances regarding use of the death penalty

The validity of this Metropolitan Police response was under question after further investigations by MWRN and the defense team, which has uncovered an acknowledgement by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) that there may have been informal sharing of UK based witness statements by local police forces with Thai authorities despite concerns over whether necessary assurances regarding the death penalty were first obtained by the concerned authorities. There were also issues surrounding sharing information on the case related mobile phone. A High Court London challenge for the accused to get advance disclosure of the Metropolitan Police report on the UK investigation into their case, prosecuted by an expert team of UK Human Rights Lawyers and with assistance from Reprieve, was rejected by the court on the grounds of national security. 

 

 

Guardian on Complaints Against UK Government

 

 

Koh Tao Murder Case Trial

Prosecution witness hearings were set as 8th-10th Jul, 22nd-24th Jul, 18th-21st Aug and 27th-28th Aug. Defence witness hearings days were set as 1st-2nd Sept and 22nd-25th Sept. An extra day of witness testimony was allowed on 11th Sept. The verdict in the case was agreed on as 24th Dec 2015. 

 

Flaws in the Investigation Highlight During Trial

A 21-day trial eventually commenced on 8th July 2015, with 3 days extension granted in the hearings, involving 34 witnesses and thousands of pages of evidence has already been widely publicised by media.

The closing statement considered the testimony of the prosecution witnesses so as to compare the reliability of this witness testimony alongside that of the defence witnesses also for the court’s benefit in issuing a judgement on the case. The statement highlighted as follows:

1. The case questioning and charging of the accused prior to prosecution was unlawful. The accused questioning after arrest and the process of notifying them of the charges against them were incorrect. The accused were questioned without lawyers or trusted persons present. The accused were not read their rights as criminal suspects or explained the nature of offences they were charged with. Neither of the accused were provided with adequate translation and legal representation as required by law. The accused’s DNA samples were taken from them involuntarily and are hence inadmissible as evidence in court.

2. The accused’s original confessions during questioning cited by the prosecution in court came about involuntarily from torture or abuse that made them fear for their lives. These written confessions, even if they had been signed, should not be considered by the Court. Other documents that were also written for the accused and which they involuntarily signed without understanding them, likewise shouldn’t be considered by the court. The videoed or staged re-enactments undertaken by the accused and submitted by the prosecution to the Court were likewise involuntary, staged under threat of violence and shouldn’t be considered or should be inadmissible as evidence in court.

3. There is no link between the alleged murder weapon (a hoe) and the accused. DNA samples from the hoe don’t match the accused DNA profiles but instead match the DNA profiles of other individuals.

4. The DNA evidence allegedly matching the accused as well as all surrounding or circumstantial evidence in this case apparently showing the guilt of the accused is unreliable and should be inadmissible and not considered by the Court. All of this evidence was not collected, tested or analysed in accordance with internationally accepted standards such as ISO 17025. This evidence should not be considered as satisfying beyond reasonable doubt that the accused violently raped and murdered the female deceased or murdered the male deceased. This includes all evidence linking the accused to the alleged crime scene such as cigarette butts, theft of the male deceased’s mobile phone and sunglasses as well as a ‘running man’ caught on CCTV.

5. The prosecution case is marked by an absence of significant evidence needed to prove the guilt of the accused for crimes they are charged with. This absent evidence includes photographs of the crime scene, autopsy and DNA analysis processes, chain of custody documents for forensic evidence, certain forensic evidence documents as well as detailed DNA analysis laboratory case notes. In addition, the clothes and the body surface of the female deceased expected to contain significant traces of DNA of the perpetrators were either not tested at all or tested but not included in the prosecution file or case evidence list. CCTV footage provided by the prosecution seemed to be incomplete and no fingerprint or footprint evidence was presented as part of the prosecution case.

The conclusion of the closing statement was the opinion of the two accused in calling for the Court to issue a judgement on 24th December 2015 dismissing all the charges against them.

The Guilty Verdict

On the morning of December 24th Wai Phyo and Zaw Lin were found guilty of the murder of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge and sentenced to death. They each received additional 20 year sentences for the rape of Ms Witheridge and were also found guilty of seeking to cover up their crimes, for robbery and immigration offences .

Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were transferred to death row in Nakhon Si Thammarat high security prison on 26th December where they will remain confined to their cell 24/7 for the first month of incarceration and in shackles for four months. At night the small cell holds 61 prisoners. It is unclear whether these restraint mechanisms will be eased as officials suggested would be the case.

The Appeal

 

Koh Tao defence team and MWRN respectfully disagree that the case against the accused was not proven beyond reasonable doubt. We take the clear position that the collection, analysis & reporting of forensic case materials didn't meet international standards. Crucial DNA analysis in the case was poorly presented to the court, no evidence was available that this collection or analysis complied with ISO 17025 standards. No full chain of custody documents given to court which ruled out defence's trust in conducting re-testing of whatever samples provided for retesting. The fact the Court ruled that the prosecution case and investigation or analysis was of an international standard will be strongly challenged on appeal by the defence, as outlined above.

THE APPEALS PROCEDURE
The lengthy process begins of drafting, debating and finalising Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo's written appeal against both the judgement and sentencing verdict of the first instance Court to the Appeals Court and now the Region 8 Court of appeal.

The full Samui Court judgement is translated into English language by volunteers for sharing with the defence team's foreign advisors and forensic/CSI/DNA experts to get their important feedback on the judgement to support the defence team further in drafting the defendants appeal. The Region 8 Appeals Court verdict upholding this original conviction is currently being translated also.

Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo's written appeal to the First Instance Appeals Court was submitted in May 2016. The written appeal to the Supreme Court, following an upholding of their original conviction by the Appeals Court on 23rd February 2017, should be submitted within 30 days but appeal submission extension requests beyond 30 days can be requested by lawyers and are usually granted. In this case an extension request is likely by defence team lawyers given the significant amount of evidence amassed from a 21 day trial consisting of 34 witnesses testimony and 1000s of pages of submitted evidence and appeals documents, and given all the defence team are pro bono working on this case alongside other existing commitments.

Region 8 Appeals Court in Surat Thani Province considered the convicted men's written appeal in this case, together with the written response to the defendant’s appeal that the prosecution submitted to the appeals court in October 2016 before ruling on the case. The Supreme Court will now consider the convicted men's new appeal in this case, together with any response to the defendant's appeal that the prosecution choses to submit to the Court before ruling on the case.

The Supreme Court will also consider all other evidence before it in making its judgement on the appeal, which will usually consist of the original first instance court and appeals court judgements, all related original trial and appeal materials (including the defence and prosecution witness testimonies, cross examinations, closing statement submissions, appeals submissions and all other written evidence, documents, and materials presented to the court by the prosecution and the defence).

The Supreme Court, after considering all these materials, will write and issue it's judgement/verdict on the case and sentencing and this written judgement should be passed on to be read by Koh Samui Court in a full court appeal verdict hearing.

The appeals process in these kinds of cases generally only involves lawyers consideration of the original first instance and appeals court judgements alongside trial witness testimony, cross examination materials, closing statements, appeal materials and all other trial evidence. In all but very exceptional circumstances no new court hearings are held nor is additional witness testimony or case evidence presented.

An appeal to the Supreme Court in Thailand after an Appeals Court judgement is usually decided within 2-5 years. So a verdict of the Supreme Court on Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo's final appeal in this case could perhaps be expected no earlier than 2018 but perhaps much later.

Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo to be detained in a high security detention facility commensurate to the death penalty imposed on them in the near future. As their situation post verdict has been deemed satisfactory, no additional security measures have been imposed on them and indeed security measures were reduced and shackles or other restraints already removed.

If after an appeal has been made the outcome is not satisfactory to Supreme Court, an appeal can no longer be made within Thailand's criminal justice system but pardon's can be granted under the Thai Consitution to those convicted on appeal.

 

 

Summary Koh Tao Murder Case Timeline

·  12th Sept: Hannah Witheridge, David Miller and friends arrive on Koh Tao. Stay at Ocean View Bungalows, Sairee Beach 

 

·  14th Sept evening to 15th Sept: Hannah Witheridge and David Miller (the deceased) are captured on CCTV at Sairee Beach, both at Choppers Bar and entering separately into AC Bar. Zaw Lin, Wai Phyo (the accused) and one friend are captured on CCTV purchasing cigarettes on Sairee Beach, close to where the deceased bodies were found

·  15th Sept: Deceased’s bodies are found at rocks on Sairee Beach close to Ocean View Bungalows where both were staying

Crime Scene Investigation Process

·  15th Sept 630am: police officers formally record discovery of 2 bodies by rocks near Ocean View Bungalows on Sairee Beach

·  15th Sept 11am: investigation officials arrive at the crime scene

Case Investigation Process and Migrant Abuse Allegations

·  15th Sept to 2nd Oct: murder case investigations are conducted publicly in a chaotic manner. Conflicting disorganised police statements are given whereby key suspects change frequently from non-Thai friends of the deceased, Thai island based residents, speed boat drivers, influential Thai persons and Myanmar migrants. Police allege DNA testing on cigarettes found nearby the bodies of the deceased and semen found in the body of Hannah was crucial in finding those responsible. DNA samples taken from hundreds of persons, mostly migrants, living on Koh Tao or suspected of involvement in the murders.

·  18th Sept to 2nd Oct: migrant workers on Koh Tao Island petition MWRN alleging physical and verbal abuse at the hands of Koh Tao case investigation officials. Migrant communities alleged in fear that Thai authorities were seeking to scapegoat Myanmar migrant workers. Photographs and video evidence of this abuse is gathered by MWRN. 

Arrest, Detention and Prosecution of Defendants

·  2nd Oct: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo are arrested. Zaw Lin is arrested on Koh Tao and Wai Phyo at a ferry terminal in Muang district, Surat Thani province. Prior to formal investigation, both are allegedly held in an undisclosed location. Police then report that both accused confess to the murders and DNA forensic evidence links them to the crime scene and DNA on Hannah’s body  

·  3rd Oct: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo are made to publicly re-enact the crime scene on Sairee Beach

·  7th Oct: the National Human Rights Commission of Thailand (NHRC) visits Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo in Koh Samui prison. The NHRC reports to media that they both confessed to the crimes but alleged physical abuse/torture during interrogation. Rights groups protest against potentially prejudicial information or statements publicly being made by the NHRC Commissioner without an adequate investigation and without lawyers present  

·  14th Oct: KohSamui Court holds a preliminary witness hearing for 3 Myanmar prosecution witnesses at risk of disappearing. Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo attend, represented by lawyers from the Lawyers Council of Thailand (LCT). The witnesses testify: (1) Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were on Sairee Beach on 14th Sept. night close to the place where the bodies of Hannah and David were found; (2) Wai Phyo came across a mobile phone he said he found that may have belonged to David but passed it onto his friend. No other evidence presented at this hearing linked Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo to the murders.  

·  21st Oct: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo retract their confessions to lawyers from the Lawyers Council of Thailand (LCT) at Koh Samui prison. Both allege beatings and torture in order to elicit the confessions and assert innocence against all charges. Both allege that on the night of the killings, they were merely playing their guitar, singing, drinking and relaxing on Sairee beach. Wai Phyo reported that he simply came across possessions allegedly belonging to the deceased that. Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo petition Koh Samui Prosecutors Office and the Attorney General calling for reconsideration of their prosecution

·  6th Nov: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo retract their confessions to case investigation officials at Koh Samui prison, in presence of their lawyers, alleging beating and torture in order to elicit the confessions and asserting their innocence against all charges

·  26th Nov: Koh Samui Court rejects first bail application by Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo. The application was guaranteed by the Myanmar embassy

·  2nd Dec: a 6th detention extension request , for a 4th time contested by lawyers for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, is approved by Koh Samui Court. Zaw Lin andWai Phyo insist to the court judge that they are innocent of all the charges against them and have nothing to do with the murders.

·  8th Dec: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo are charged at Koh Samui Court by Koh Samui Prosecutors Office. Both maintain their innocence against all the charges. 

Court Proceedings Begin

·  26th Dec: at preliminary hearing, 18 full days witness testimony over 3 months agreed, starting from 8thJuly 2015. The court disallows this request but leaves open possibility of witness testimony given via video link from overseas or from Bangkok. When asked by the judge to again plead in relation to the charges, Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo insist they are innocent of all charges. When asked by the judge whether they know who was involved in the murders, both Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo say they know nothing about the murders and who was responsible as they were merely relaxing on Sairee beach that night and didn’t see or hear anything. The defence team presents to the court the valid passport of Zaw Lin to rebut charges of illegal entry into Thailand.

·  22nd April 2015: The defense team submits formal request to Koh Samui court for sending to Ministry of Justice for re-examination key forensics evidence and for independent testing of the DNA profiles of the two accused

·  30th Apr 2015: Koh Samui court holds preliminary hearing with lawyers to explain progress on preparation of case witnesses. Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo attend. The presiding court judge indicates to defence lawyers he would consider ordering case officials to allow re-examination of key forensics evidence by the Ministry of Justice. 

·  31st May 2015: accused’s legal team follows up Court order on re-examination of forensics evidence/additional DNA testing of accused but informed: (1) the court will only issue an order on these requests on first day of the trial; and (2) defense team can organise additional DNA testing of the accused.

·  8th-10th July 2015: Court delays ruleing against request by defence team for re-examination of key parts of the case's forensics evidence including crucial DNA materials. Prosecution witnesses called including prosecution crime scene/forensics experts. Police suggested at first no original forensics evidence remained from victim’s and only 3 items of forensic evidence to be retested by the defence, the hoe, a shoe and 5 sacks.

·  22nd-24th July & 18th-21st August 2015: Prosecution witnesses called to give evidence and then cross examined.

·  1st September 2015: Senior police officers give contradictory evidence. Final prosecution witness called.

·  2nd September 2015: Zaw Lin takes stand..

·  11th September 2015: Director of Thailand Ministry of Justice's Forensics Institute, Dr Pornthip, takes the stand.

·  22nd-25th September 2015. Defence points to flaws in probe of murders through their witnesses including forensic and crime scene experts, embassy officials and migrant workers. Mr Andy Hall testifies on gait analysis, autopsy and migrant community torture issues.

·  10th-11th October 2015: Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo testify. Discussion of investigation/questioning process and torture/procedural irregularity issues and forced confession.

·  24th December 2015:  Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo given the verdict of guilty and given the death sentence.

·  25th December 2015: Appeals process to Supreme Court begins

·  May 2016: Appeal submitted to Appeals Court by defense

·  October 2016: Appeal correction submitted to Appeals Court by prosecution

·  February 23rd 2017: Appeals Court dismisses defense appeal and upholds sentence and conviction

·  March 2017: Appeals process to Supreme Court begins

BBC: Koh Tao Defense Lawyers Deeply Concerned Over Forensics Re-Testing

Guardian on Capital Punishment Concerns in Koh Tao Case

Guardian: Thai Court says case forensics/DNA evidence must be independently examined after claims of tainted crime scene and Burmese suspects being tortured
story_txt:
MWRN's JUSTICE: KOH TAO MURDER CASE NEEDS YOUR SUPPORT FOR THE APPEALS PROCESS AGAINST KOH SAMUI COURT RULING OF GUILTY (WITH DEATH PENALTY IMPOSED) AGAINST ZAW LIN & WAI PHYO ON DEC 24th 2015 FOR ALLEGED INVOLVEMENT IN THE KOH TAO MURDERS. REGION 8 APPEALS COURT UPHELD THIS RULING ON 23RD FEBRUARY 2017 AND THE DEFENSE TEAM IS NOW CURRENTLY PREPARING ITS APPEAL ON THE CASE TO THAILAND'S FINAL SUPREME COURT. PLEASE CONTINUE TO SUPPORT OUR TEAM AS THE MORE FUNDS RAISED, MORE EFFECTIVE MWRN/THE ACCUSED'S DEFENSE TEAM CAN BE AND THE MORE HUMANITARIAN SUPPORT WE CAN PROVIDE TO THE ACCUSED.  ‘Thank you everyone who has supported us. We are innocent and we were not involved in this horrific crime, we didn't kill. We want freedom. We are confident the truth of this case will come out during the appeals process and we are confident we will eventually be released on appeal. With everyone's encouragement we will stay strong until the end and finally we will surely get our freedom after our appeals process. We will meditate every day and pray to Buddha for freedom but also for peace and happiness of all those in the world, including the Koh Tao victims.' Message from Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, Death Row, Nakhon Si Thammarat Prison, Dec. 28th 2015 GUARDIAN - Thailand backpacker murders: Burmese workers sentenced to death Koh Tao: The Case That Put Thailand on Trial Why UK Role in Koh Tao Case Still Worries Rights Groups
AFP - Pair Convicted of Koh Tao Murders Have Lost Appeal Against the Death Penalty
BBC - Thai beach murders: Convicted men lose death sentence appeal​

The truth is we are not really involved in this case. We want you to help us. So we write this letter to you from our imprisonment… We do not want to be in jail anymore… We think it is injustice that we are in the jail. We want justice and equality.’ – Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo’s letter to Aung San Suu Kyi, Dec. 2014 BBC - Thailand beach murders verdict: A flawed and muddled investigation

TELEGRAPH - Koh Tao: Killings that put a country's justice system on trial Koh Tao Murders: Burmese Migrants Sentenced to Death




 
The Migrant Worker Rights Network (MWRN) represents all migrant workers in Thailand. The MWRN aims to support and raise funds, with your vital assistance, for the defense and humanitarian supporting during imprisonment of Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo (Win Zaw Htun), two 22 year old Myanmar workers prosecuted and convicted with a death penalty applied on 24th Dec 2015 for the rape and murder of Hannah Witheridge and murder of David Miller, both British tourists, which occurred on Koh Tao Island, Thailand in Sept 2014.
 
The guilty verdict was given on December 24th 2015 when both Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were both found guilty of rape and murder and given the death sentence. The accused are currently on death row at Bang Kwang high security prison in Nonthaburi Province of Thailand near to Bangkok. On 23rd February 2017, Region 8 Appeals Court upheld the conviction and death penalty sentence against the two accused and this judgement is currently pending appeal by the defense team to Thailand's Supreme Court.
The appeals process for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo against their verdict and sentencing is a long one. It was first to the Appeals Court (submitted in May 2016, 9-12 months was expected for verdict delivered in February 2017) and then on to the Supreme Court (2-5 years after original conviction expected for final verdict). The final appeal to the Supreme Court has now commenced with a team of lawyers from the Lawyers Council of Thailand working on the appeal alongside MWRN and a number of domestic and foreign criminal justice/crime scene/forensics experts. 
 
MWRN’s involvement in the Koh Tao murder case began in Oct 2014 amidst widespread allegations regarding:

Arrest of ‘scapegoats’.
Torture of Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo during detention prior to questioning by investigation officials.
Improper collection of forensic evidence during crime scene investigations.
Intimidation and abuse of witnesses and suspects

Guardian on Torture Allegations in Koh Tao Case
 
MWRN intends to contribute to a fair appeals process post conviction for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo to prevent a potential miscarriage of justice that would impact negatively on families, communities and everyone deeply affected by this case. MWRN also wants to ensure that migrants, who contribute much through their work and presence to the prosperity of Koh Tao and to Thailand, will feel justice is achieved from this case. In addition to families and friends of all those concerned, Thailand’s migrant community has been deeply impacted and moved by the tragic deaths of Hannah and David and the arrest and prosecution of Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, their fellow nationals, for the crime. The migrant community and those in Myanmar have rose up against the verdict and protests continue.
‘A fair appeals process for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo is essential to ensure, with more confidence, that those guilty of this crime are held accountable and that there is no punishment of the wrong people. It would be a double injustice if  the lack of a legal defense team to carry out defense work effectively for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, meant that the real killers went free whilst innocent people were jailed, even executed. If Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo are innocent, no-one wants such a situation to arise. That’s why MWRN has set up this fund, to support some significant defense related costs in this case.’ - Ko Sein Htay, MWRN President/Fund Administrator
 
 Guardian on Concerns Over Koh Tao Fair Trial
Why Does MWRN Need YOU?
‘Now we have seen the light of hope for justice and truth as so many people have become involved in defending us and supporting our case.’ – Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo, Feb. 2015
In order to minimise risk of a miscarriage of justice, MWRN continues to publicly seek financial/other practical support to contribute our part of costs needed to cover all expenses, to ensure a fair trial through an effective appeals process for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo. Expenses MWRN seek to contribute to now include:

Flights and travel costs for defense team members involved in attending meetings and planning sessions concerning the appeal of the convictions and sentencing and for visits to Bang Kwang Prison to meet with the accused during the appeals process
Travel/accommodation costs for expert advisors during the appeals process 
Prison support costs for Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo during continued detention in Bang Kwang Prison, including travel costs for prison visitors

It is important to note that all those working on the defense case (including lawyers, assistants, investigators, prison visitors, translators and campaigners) are doing so pro-bono or free of charge. Fundraising only seeks to cover expenses. The Lawyers Council of Thailand is also supporting some of the defense team by covering basic expenses for main practicing lawyers.MWRN previously raised 812, 000 Thai Baht (around US$25, 000) to assist the defense of Wai Phyo and Zaw Lin in late 2014. These funds were exhausted during the emergency and initial stages of the defense engagement. Youcaring website unexpectedly, and without notice, withdrew MWRN's 'Justice: Koh Tao Case' fundraiser from its site in January 2015, claiming a sudden change of website regulations to disallow criminal defense fundraisers. This is why MWRN launched this an urgent trial preparation STAGE TWO two fundraiser with Indiegogo. Within 48 days of starting this 60 day campaign, MWRN met our £10,000 modest fundraising target and our campaign moved into InDemand to allow us to keep up the push for further donations to make our work more effective (for updates on the spending of all MWRN raised funds, please see the updates section of this site). MWRN has now raised a total of over 2 million baht for this case defence of which almost all funds have been exhausted during the trial and first instance appeals process, The fundraiser now moves into STAGE THREE for the Supreme Court appeals process and for continued humanitarian support to the 2 convicted men. 

 OUR Challenges  
 
‘Before and during the case investigation we had no chance to speak out on our innocence or the truth. We are victims of influential people.' – Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo’s message written in court on 26th Dec. 2014
Our challenge is to achieve justice in this carefully monitored case, whilst working within the boundaries of the Thai judicial system, with its pride and reputation at stake. There is also the challenge of the on-going situation of powerlessness, discrimination and exploitation faced by migrant workers in Thailand. Genuine justice is obtained through ensuring the equality of resources for both the prosecution and defense teams. It is essential that the defense team has the resources to appeal their case and prepare and appeal to the best of their ability, to ensure that two innocent young men are not convicted and possibly executed for these murders. In this worse case scenario, there would be no justice for Hannah and David and those who loved them, but only two more innocent victims in this very disturbing and important trial.
Guardian on Complaints Against UK Government 
Guardian on UK Government Protest Koh Tao Case Investigation
 

The defense team, consisting of pro bono lawyers associated with the Lawyers Council of Thailand and assisted by rights activists, face an exceptional challenge. More than a hundred witnesses and a thousand pages of statements/forensic case related evidence was put forward in this case and had to be understood. 21 days of trial testimony by 34 witnesses and more than a thousand pages of a prosecution file needs to be reviewed again for the appeals process, as well as the new appeals court judgement and prosecution submissions made as part of this process, All appeals processes are conducted in the Thai language and must then be translated into the Burmese and English language. Even more financial and practical constraints are faced in working with experts outside of Thailand, to prevent a miscarriage of justice.
 
  ------------------  For further enquiries on means to donate to MWRN’s fundraiser or any other information, please contact:   1.  Fund Administrator Ko Sein Htay - MWRN President mwrnorg@gmail.com +95(0)949278500/+66(0)946792478  2.  Fund Advisor Mr. Andy Hall - MWRN International Affairs Advisor andyjhall1979@gmail.com +66(0)846 119209  3.  Fund Advisor Mr. Nakhon Chompuchat - Head Koh Tao Case Defense Team Lawyer nakhonct@gmail.com +66(0)818 473086          --------------------  The Migrant Workers Rights Network (MWRN) is a membership based organisation of workers from Myanmar working across the world. MWRN was founded in March 2009 by 9 Myanmar migrant leaders in Thailand who strongly believed empowerment of migrants was the best way to protect themselves in their vulnerable situation as migrant workers. The founders’ goal for MWRN is to promote and strengthen Myanmar migrant’s rights by raising awareness, promoting access to justice and negotiation with employers and officials and advocating for sustainable migration policy change.       --------------------  
Koh Tao Case Background
 
   
 
In the early morning of 15th September 2014, two young British tourists Hannah Witheridge (23) and David Miller (24) were murdered on Koh Tao, a popular tourist destination in the Gulf of Thailand. The two victim’s bodies were reportedly found amongst rocks in a secluded area of the popular Sairee Beach.
Two weeks into the murder investigation, police had yet to charge anyone with the murders. Amidst conflicting statements regarding evidence and suspects, the investigation appeared increasingly disorganised.
Investigators of this case have been criticised for the alleged mishandling of forensic evidence, abuse of suspects and intimidation of witnesses, particularly migrant workers living on Koh Tao.
A huge shadow has been cast, not only over the safety of tourism, but also over the reliability of the criminal justice system in Thailand, to hold someone responsible for these high profile murders. 
Whilst under pressure to make an arrest, Thai officials suggested that migrant workers committed these murders. For many, these statements reflected the historical and systematic discrimination long faced by migrant workers in Thailand. Migrant workers are still frequent victims of abuse and extortion by Thai law enforcement officials. They are consistently treated like second-class citizens, with little access to effective justice, remedies or any complaint mechanisms.
Blanket DNA testing of the migrant community was then undertaken amidst fears that the migrant community would be persecuted as ‘scapegoats’ for these murders, as a result of their powerlessness to fight back. Shortly after the murders, migrant workers on Koh Tao began to petition MWRN with video and photographic evidence alleging physical and verbal abuse by investigation officials during questionings. Migrant communities throughout Thailand also communicated to MWRN their concerns that Thai authorities would unfairly scapegoat Myanmar migrant workers for these horrific murders.
 
Guardian on Koh Tao Murder Case Investigation Confusion
 
 The Arrest of Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo
 
Thai police detained Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun (Wai Phyo), two young Myanmar migrant workers from the impoverished Rakhine State in the far West of Myanmar, on 2nd October 2014. Zaw Lin (21) worked at Brother Bar and Wai Phyo (21) worked at Safety Stop restaurant on Koh Tao at the time of the murders.
Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo’s purpose in Thailand was to send money home to support their parents and siblings living in poverty in Myanmar. Both had been working on Koh Tao for several years.
 
 Guardian on Koh Tao Case Arrests
 
Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo’s Claims of Innocence 
 
 
During the initial weeks of detention in Koh Samui prison, Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were permanently shackled and confined to a high security cell 24 hours a day, only being allowed out to meet with authorised visitors. Prison authorities justified this treatment based on suicide risks and the potential danger both supposedly posed to fellow prisoners. Following complaints by rights groups, Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were eventually unshackled and allowed to join other prisoners outside of their cell during daytime hours only.
Several days after being arrested, Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo told human rights monitors at Koh Samui prison that they were abused and tortured following detention, prior to being handed over to investigation officials. A week later, both pleaded innocence to rights lawyers organised for them. Both alleged their heads were covered with bags to imitate suffocation, while they were also threatened with electrocution, burning and execution to elicit confessions. Misconduct of translators assisting investigators was also alleged.
‘We are poor, so we came to Thailand to work and save money…In the beginning when we arrived in Thailand we suffered many difficulties, we do not want to be suffering like poor people and we tried to work hard and sent money back to our parents regularly, we were happy so much for that. But now our hopes are broken. We are worried about our parents, who will support them? And we miss our parents every day, when we miss them we are crying…’ – Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo’s letter to Aung San Suu Kyi, Dec. 2014
Guardian on Accused Appeal for Witnesses
 
 Alleged Abuse of Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo
Several days after being arrested, Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo told human rights monitors at Koh Samui prison that they were tortured following detention, prior to being handed over to investigation officials. A week later, both pleaded innocent to rights lawyers organised for them. Both alleged their heads were covered with bags to imitate suffocation while they were threatened with electrocution, burning and execution to elicit confessions. Misconduct of translators assisting investigators was also alleged. The alleged abuse of the accused was outlined in detail at trial and included sexual assault also.
Guardian on Koh Tao Case Torture Allegations
 
The Formal Charges and Not Guilty Pleas
Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were officially arraigned on 4th and 8th December 2014 at Koh Samui Court by the Koh Samui prosecutor's office. The charges levied against them included: killing the two deceased intentionally; killing Hannah to cover up her rape and to avoid punishment; raping and assaulting Hannah with violent acts; being non-Thai nationals entering into Thailand irregularly and remaining in Thailand irregularly; and Wei Phyo is charged alone with theft of a mobile phone and a pair of sunglasses, both allegedly belonging to David Miller. Both Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo pleaded not guilty to all the charges filed against them.
Guardian on Formal Charges‘We are not perfect and the best sons in our families, but we wish to remind everyone we did not commit this cunning and barbarian crime.’ – Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo, Feb 2015 
UK Government Case Investigation
 
There followed intense media coverage and public concern which was expressed in the form of online campaigns regarding the reliability of the Thai police investigation and the arrest of Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo. UK Prime Minister David Cameron and UK authorities strongly engaged Thai officials. Officials from the UK sought to send a team of qualified British police to Thailand to investigate the murders and report back to the deceased’s families. Since this time, MWRN and Zaw Lin and Wei Phyo’s defense team have been working with Reprieve in London to explore the UK Government’s role in investigating this case. This led to disclosure of a Metropolitan Police letter dated 19th December 2014 that stated in summary:

The Metropolitan police did not conduct any investigations into these murders in Thailand. Instead, during a visit to Thailand in November 2014, three UK police officials were granted observer status only to limited parts of the Thai police investigation, they did not provide any advice or assistance, and relied on the translation services of a Thai police translator. During their visit these officials did not take possession of any evidence, physical or forensic, and did not collect exhibits, interviews or statements
The Metropolitan police were preparing a report on observations from their visit to Thailand, to be completed in January 2015. This report was to be for internal use only and would not be shared with the Thai authorities or other persons. Furthermore, the request from the defense team to review this report was denied as, relying on an exemption under the UK data protection law, it would ‘clearly prejudice’ the criminal prosecution in question and undermine prevention and detection of crime 
No other case information would be shared with Thai authorities or the defense team by UK authorities for use in a criminal process which lacks the necessary assurances regarding use of the death penalty

The validity of this Metropolitan Police response was under question after further investigations by MWRN and the defense team, which has uncovered an acknowledgement by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) that there may have been informal sharing of UK based witness statements by local police forces with Thai authorities despite concerns over whether necessary assurances regarding the death penalty were first obtained by the concerned authorities. There were also issues surrounding sharing information on the case related mobile phone. A High Court London challenge for the accused to get advance disclosure of the Metropolitan Police report on the UK investigation into their case, prosecuted by an expert team of UK Human Rights Lawyers and with assistance from Reprieve, was rejected by the court on the grounds of national security. 
 
 
Guardian on Complaints Against UK Government
 
 

Koh Tao Murder Case Trial
Prosecution witness hearings were set as 8th-10th Jul, 22nd-24th Jul, 18th-21st Aug and 27th-28th Aug. Defence witness hearings days were set as 1st-2nd Sept and 22nd-25th Sept. An extra day of witness testimony was allowed on 11th Sept. The verdict in the case was agreed on as 24th Dec 2015. 
 
Flaws in the Investigation Highlight During Trial
A 21-day trial eventually commenced on 8th July 2015, with 3 days extension granted in the hearings, involving 34 witnesses and thousands of pages of evidence has already been widely publicised by media.
The closing statement considered the testimony of the prosecution witnesses so as to compare the reliability of this witness testimony alongside that of the defence witnesses also for the court’s benefit in issuing a judgement on the case. The statement highlighted as follows:
1. The case questioning and charging of the accused prior to prosecution was unlawful. The accused questioning after arrest and the process of notifying them of the charges against them were incorrect. The accused were questioned without lawyers or trusted persons present. The accused were not read their rights as criminal suspects or explained the nature of offences they were charged with. Neither of the accused were provided with adequate translation and legal representation as required by law. The accused’s DNA samples were taken from them involuntarily and are hence inadmissible as evidence in court.
2. The accused’s original confessions during questioning cited by the prosecution in court came about involuntarily from torture or abuse that made them fear for their lives. These written confessions, even if they had been signed, should not be considered by the Court. Other documents that were also written for the accused and which they involuntarily signed without understanding them, likewise shouldn’t be considered by the court. The videoed or staged re-enactments undertaken by the accused and submitted by the prosecution to the Court were likewise involuntary, staged under threat of violence and shouldn’t be considered or should be inadmissible as evidence in court. 
3. There is no link between the alleged murder weapon (a hoe) and the accused. DNA samples from the hoe don’t match the accused DNA profiles but instead match the DNA profiles of other individuals. 
4. The DNA evidence allegedly matching the accused as well as all surrounding or circumstantial evidence in this case apparently showing the guilt of the accused is unreliable and should be inadmissible and not considered by the Court. All of this evidence was not collected, tested or analysed in accordance with internationally accepted standards such as ISO 17025. This evidence should not be considered as satisfying beyond reasonable doubt that the accused violently raped and murdered the female deceased or murdered the male deceased. This includes all evidence linking the accused to the alleged crime scene such as cigarette butts, theft of the male deceased’s mobile phone and sunglasses as well as a ‘running man’ caught on CCTV. 
5. The prosecution case is marked by an absence of significant evidence needed to prove the guilt of the accused for crimes they are charged with. This absent evidence includes photographs of the crime scene, autopsy and DNA analysis processes, chain of custody documents for forensic evidence, certain forensic evidence documents as well as detailed DNA analysis laboratory case notes. In addition, the clothes and the body surface of the female deceased expected to contain significant traces of DNA of the perpetrators were either not tested at all or tested but not included in the prosecution file or case evidence list. CCTV footage provided by the prosecution seemed to be incomplete and no fingerprint or footprint evidence was presented as part of the prosecution case.
The conclusion of the closing statement was the opinion of the two accused in calling for the Court to issue a judgement on 24th December 2015 dismissing all the charges against them.
The Guilty Verdict
On the morning of December 24th Wai Phyo and Zaw Lin were found guilty of the murder of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge and sentenced to death. They each received additional 20 year sentences for the rape of Ms Witheridge and were also found guilty of seeking to cover up their crimes, for robbery and immigration offences .
Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were transferred to death row in Nakhon Si Thammarat high security prison on 26th December where they will remain confined to their cell 24/7 for the first month of incarceration and in shackles for four months. At night the small cell holds 61 prisoners. It is unclear whether these restraint mechanisms will be eased as officials suggested would be the case.
The Appeal
 
Koh Tao defence team and MWRN respectfully disagree that the case against the accused was not proven beyond reasonable doubt. We take the clear position that the collection, analysis & reporting of forensic case materials didn't meet international standards. Crucial DNA analysis in the case was poorly presented to the court, no evidence was available that this collection or analysis complied with ISO 17025 standards. No full chain of custody documents given to court which ruled out defence's trust in conducting re-testing of whatever samples provided for retesting. The fact the Court ruled that the prosecution case and investigation or analysis was of an international standard will be strongly challenged on appeal by the defence, as outlined above.
THE APPEALS PROCEDUREThe lengthy process begins of drafting, debating and finalising Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo's written appeal against both the judgement and sentencing verdict of the first instance Court to the Appeals Court and now the Region 8 Court of appeal.
The full Samui Court judgement is translated into English language by volunteers for sharing with the defence team's foreign advisors and forensic/CSI/DNA experts to get their important feedback on the judgement to support the defence team further in drafting the defendants appeal. The Region 8 Appeals Court verdict upholding this original conviction is currently being translated also.
Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo's written appeal to the First Instance Appeals Court was submitted in May 2016. The written appeal to the Supreme Court, following an upholding of their original conviction by the Appeals Court on 23rd February 2017, should be submitted within 30 days but appeal submission extension requests beyond 30 days can be requested by lawyers and are usually granted. In this case an extension request is likely by defence team lawyers given the significant amount of evidence amassed from a 21 day trial consisting of 34 witnesses testimony and 1000s of pages of submitted evidence and appeals documents, and given all the defence team are pro bono working on this case alongside other existing commitments.
Region 8 Appeals Court in Surat Thani Province considered the convicted men's written appeal in this case, together with the written response to the defendant’s appeal that the prosecution submitted to the appeals court in October 2016 before ruling on the case. The Supreme Court will now consider the convicted men's new appeal in this case, together with any response to the defendant's appeal that the prosecution choses to submit to the Court before ruling on the case.
The Supreme Court will also consider all other evidence before it in making its judgement on the appeal, which will usually consist of the original first instance court and appeals court judgements, all related original trial and appeal materials (including the defence and prosecution witness testimonies, cross examinations, closing statement submissions, appeals submissions and all other written evidence, documents, and materials presented to the court by the prosecution and the defence).
The Supreme Court, after considering all these materials, will write and issue it's judgement/verdict on the case and sentencing and this written judgement should be passed on to be read by Koh Samui Court in a full court appeal verdict hearing.
The appeals process in these kinds of cases generally only involves lawyers consideration of the original first instance and appeals court judgements alongside trial witness testimony, cross examination materials, closing statements, appeal materials and all other trial evidence. In all but very exceptional circumstances no new court hearings are held nor is additional witness testimony or case evidence presented.
An appeal to the Supreme Court in Thailand after an Appeals Court judgement is usually decided within 2-5 years. So a verdict of the Supreme Court on Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo's final appeal in this case could perhaps be expected no earlier than 2018 but perhaps much later.
Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo to be detained in a high security detention facility commensurate to the death penalty imposed on them in the near future. As their situation post verdict has been deemed satisfactory, no additional security measures have been imposed on them and indeed security measures were reduced and shackles or other restraints already removed.
If after an appeal has been made the outcome is not satisfactory to Supreme Court, an appeal can no longer be made within Thailand's criminal justice system but pardon's can be granted under the Thai Consitution to those convicted on appeal.
 
 
Summary Koh Tao Murder Case Timeline
·  12th Sept: Hannah Witheridge, David Miller and friends arrive on Koh Tao. Stay at Ocean View Bungalows, Sairee Beach 
 
·  14th Sept evening to 15th Sept: Hannah Witheridge and David Miller (the deceased) are captured on CCTV at Sairee Beach, both at Choppers Bar and entering separately into AC Bar. Zaw Lin, Wai Phyo (the accused) and one friend are captured on CCTV purchasing cigarettes on Sairee Beach, close to where the deceased bodies were found
·  15th Sept: Deceased’s bodies are found at rocks on Sairee Beach close to Ocean View Bungalows where both were staying
Crime Scene Investigation Process
·  15th Sept 630am: police officers formally record discovery of 2 bodies by rocks near Ocean View Bungalows on Sairee Beach
·  15th Sept 11am: investigation officials arrive at the crime scene
Case Investigation Process and Migrant Abuse Allegations
·  15th Sept to 2nd Oct: murder case investigations are conducted publicly in a chaotic manner. Conflicting disorganised police statements are given whereby key suspects change frequently from non-Thai friends of the deceased, Thai island based residents, speed boat drivers, influential Thai persons and Myanmar migrants. Police allege DNA testing on cigarettes found nearby the bodies of the deceased and semen found in the body of Hannah was crucial in finding those responsible. DNA samples taken from hundreds of persons, mostly migrants, living on Koh Tao or suspected of involvement in the murders.
·  18th Sept to 2nd Oct: migrant workers on Koh Tao Island petition MWRN alleging physical and verbal abuse at the hands of Koh Tao case investigation officials. Migrant communities alleged in fear that Thai authorities were seeking to scapegoat Myanmar migrant workers. Photographs and video evidence of this abuse is gathered by MWRN. 
Arrest, Detention and Prosecution of Defendants
·  2nd Oct: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo are arrested. Zaw Lin is arrested on Koh Tao and Wai Phyo at a ferry terminal in Muang district, Surat Thani province. Prior to formal investigation, both are allegedly held in an undisclosed location. Police then report that both accused confess to the murders and DNA forensic evidence links them to the crime scene and DNA on Hannah’s body  
·  3rd Oct: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo are made to publicly re-enact the crime scene on Sairee Beach
·  7th Oct: the National Human Rights Commission of Thailand (NHRC) visits Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo in Koh Samui prison. The NHRC reports to media that they both confessed to the crimes but alleged physical abuse/torture during interrogation. Rights groups protest against potentially prejudicial information or statements publicly being made by the NHRC Commissioner without an adequate investigation and without lawyers present  
·  14th Oct: KohSamui Court holds a preliminary witness hearing for 3 Myanmar prosecution witnesses at risk of disappearing. Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo attend, represented by lawyers from the Lawyers Council of Thailand (LCT). The witnesses testify: (1) Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were on Sairee Beach on 14th Sept. night close to the place where the bodies of Hannah and David were found; (2) Wai Phyo came across a mobile phone he said he found that may have belonged to David but passed it onto his friend. No other evidence presented at this hearing linked Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo to the murders.  
·  21st Oct: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo retract their confessions to lawyers from the Lawyers Council of Thailand (LCT) at Koh Samui prison. Both allege beatings and torture in order to elicit the confessions and assert innocence against all charges. Both allege that on the night of the killings, they were merely playing their guitar, singing, drinking and relaxing on Sairee beach. Wai Phyo reported that he simply came across possessions allegedly belonging to the deceased that. Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo petition Koh Samui Prosecutors Office and the Attorney General calling for reconsideration of their prosecution
·  6th Nov: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo retract their confessions to case investigation officials at Koh Samui prison, in presence of their lawyers, alleging beating and torture in order to elicit the confessions and asserting their innocence against all charges
·  26th Nov: Koh Samui Court rejects first bail application by Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo. The application was guaranteed by the Myanmar embassy
·  2nd Dec: a 6th detention extension request , for a 4th time contested by lawyers for Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo, is approved by Koh Samui Court. Zaw Lin andWai Phyo insist to the court judge that they are innocent of all the charges against them and have nothing to do with the murders.
·  8th Dec: Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo are charged at Koh Samui Court by Koh Samui Prosecutors Office. Both maintain their innocence against all the charges. 
Court Proceedings Begin
·  26th Dec: at preliminary hearing, 18 full days witness testimony over 3 months agreed, starting from 8thJuly 2015. The court disallows this request but leaves open possibility of witness testimony given via video link from overseas or from Bangkok. When asked by the judge to again plead in relation to the charges, Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo insist they are innocent of all charges. When asked by the judge whether they know who was involved in the murders, both Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo say they know nothing about the murders and who was responsible as they were merely relaxing on Sairee beach that night and didn’t see or hear anything. The defence team presents to the court the valid passport of Zaw Lin to rebut charges of illegal entry into Thailand.
·  22nd April 2015: The defense team submits formal request to Koh Samui court for sending to Ministry of Justice for re-examination key forensics evidence and for independent testing of the DNA profiles of the two accused
·  30th Apr 2015: Koh Samui court holds preliminary hearing with lawyers to explain progress on preparation of case witnesses. Zaw Lin/Wai Phyo attend. The presiding court judge indicates to defence lawyers he would consider ordering case officials to allow re-examination of key forensics evidence by the Ministry of Justice. 
·  31st May 2015: accused’s legal team follows up Court order on re-examination of forensics evidence/additional DNA testing of accused but informed: (1) the court will only issue an order on these requests on first day of the trial; and (2) defense team can organise additional DNA testing of the accused.
·  8th-10th July 2015: Court delays ruleing against request by defence team for re-examination of key parts of the case's forensics evidence including crucial DNA materials. Prosecution witnesses called including prosecution crime scene/forensics experts. Police suggested at first no original forensics evidence remained from victim’s and only 3 items of forensic evidence to be retested by the defence, the hoe, a shoe and 5 sacks.
·  22nd-24th July & 18th-21st August 2015: Prosecution witnesses called to give evidence and then cross examined.
·  1st September 2015: Senior police officers give contradictory evidence. Final prosecution witness called.
·  2nd September 2015: Zaw Lin takes stand..
·  11th September 2015: Director of Thailand Ministry of Justice's Forensics Institute, Dr Pornthip, takes the stand.
·  22nd-25th September 2015. Defence points to flaws in probe of murders through their witnesses including forensic and crime scene experts, embassy officials and migrant workers. Mr Andy Hall testifies on gait analysis, autopsy and migrant community torture issues.
·  10th-11th October 2015: Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo testify. Discussion of investigation/questioning process and torture/procedural irregularity issues and forced confession.
·  24th December 2015:  Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo given the verdict of guilty and given the death sentence.
·  25th December 2015: Appeals process to Supreme Court begins
·  May 2016: Appeal submitted to Appeals Court by defense
·  October 2016: Appeal correction submitted to Appeals Court by prosecution
·  February 23rd 2017: Appeals Court dismisses defense appeal and upholds sentence and conviction
·  March 2017: Appeals process to Supreme Court begins
BBC: Koh Tao Defense Lawyers Deeply Concerned Over Forensics Re-Testing

Guardian on Capital Punishment Concerns in Koh Tao Case
Guardian: Thai Court says case forensics/DNA evidence must be independently examined after claims of tainted crime scene and Burmese suspects being tortured
campaign_city: Koh Samui, Surat Thani Province, Thailand

story:
Short Summary

We're a small grassroots group, made up of pro-indy Catalans and Scots living in both nations. We feel it is important to give a voice to those of us who support freedom for our nations, because we wish to see Scotland and Catalonia governed by the people who care most about our future. And that's why we need to spread the word and get more supporters! 

What We Need & What You Get

Being honest, this campaign says we need 500 euros because it is the minimum required by IndieGogo, but with just 10 euros we can  create ads about the posts of the page, so any donation will have a great impact...

The Impact

With your help we can reach thousands of people who probably don't know what's happening in Catalonia, and we will make them know the truth and know the repressive and fascist attitude of the Spanish Government.

Other Ways You Can Help

OK, so not everyone can afford to donate, but you can still help us:

· Get out the word about the Catalan cause. Spread the word, join our Facebook group, "like" our Facebook page, follow us on Twitter, etc.

· Contribute to the debate! If you're a proud supporter of the democratic pro-independence movement you can attend demonstrations, talk to your family, friends and neighbours - don't be afraid to get the word out.

story:
Question:  

Now that the campaign goal has been reached, what happens to the extra money? 


Answer:  

All further support will go towards purchasing propane tanks, grill accessories & and associated cost of maintaining and using the grill. Don't forget the hamburgers!


Join us in Supporting LGBT Homeless Youth in NYC!  

We can keep providing warm meals with YOUR help! 

Every week, New Alternatives serves HOT meals to 50 to 70 hungry LGBT Homeless Youth in New York City.  

  • Unfortunately, our kitchen does not ha

    ve air conditioning and is located in a basement. 
  • As Summer approaches, it becomes TOO HOT for our volunteers to cook for the youth in the kitchen.
  • In order to keep providing meals during the summer, we need to purchase an outdoor grill (the one shown in the "gallery" tab above).  
  • Every dollar you donate will go towards the purchase of a professional grill that will be used to feed hungry, LGBT homeless youth in NYC.  
  • Since this is a professional grill, your gift will continue to give and give over many years to come.  
  • Whether you are LGBT or a Straight Ally, this is an incredible opportunity to make a lasting impact and make the world just a little bit better, one burger at a time!  

You can help keep the meals coming - Donate Today!   (100% Tax Deductible) 

Be sure to check out our "perks" located to the right of your screen >>>

story:
Rainbow Honor Walk A Sidewalk Tribute

Mission Statement:  The Rainbow Honor Walk seeks to honor the heroes and heroines of the LGBT communities through a sidewalk tribute with bronze plaques in San Francisco’s historic Castro district.  

Legacy and Visibility:  This is an ongoing project, much like the Hollywood Walk of Fame, it will continue indefinitely (as long as the Castro District has sidewalks).  The area covered is approximately 2.5 miles of sidewalk and includes two blocks of 19th Street, two blocks of 18th Street, Castro Street from 19th to Market Streets, and Market Street from Castro Street to the LGBT Center at Market and Gough Street.  The Rainbow Honor Walk will become another icon of the City of San Francisco generating tourist traffic and breathing new life into the Castro District sidewalks.  Millions of people will be excited and inspired by the honorees.

Our Budget

The plaques are 3 feet by 3 feet and will be acid etched into bronze.  The cost of each plaque is approximately $5,000.  Installation of the first twenty plaques will be donated by the San Francisco Department of Public Works.  The Rainbow Honor Walk is an all volunteer board which meets in donated space by Zephyr Real Estate in the Castro.  Administrative and overhead costs are minimal.  

The First 20 Plaques

These are the first 20 Honorees.  There's room for a lot more.  The Rainbow Honor Walk will have plaques on both sides of Market street from Castro to Gough Streets.  So check back in to find your favorite LGBT hero or heroine.

Jane Addams (1860-1935)
James Baldwin (1924-1987)
George Choy (1960-1993)
Federico García Lorca (1898-1936)
Allen Ginsberg (1926-1997)
Keith Haring (1958-1990)
Harry Hay (1912-2002)
Sylvester James (1947-1988)
Christine Jorgensen (1926-1989)
Frida Kahlo (1907-1954)
Del Martin (1921-2008)
Yukio Mishima (1925-1970)
Bayard Rustin (1912-1987)
Randy Shilts (1951-1994)
Gertrude Stein (1874-1946)
Alan Turing (1912-1954)
Tom Waddell (1937-1987)
Oscar Wilde (1854-1900)
Tennessee Williams (1911-1983)
Virginia Woolf (1882-1941)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate at this time, but really want to see this project take off, there are other ways to help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this Indiegogo campaign
  • Like the Rainbow Honor Walk on Facebook
  • Watch for and attend exciting events in the Castro District

story:
Summary

Menstrual Hygiene management continues to be a critical issue for Young girls in farming, rural and peri urban communities in Zimbabwe.  Reports in media over the past four years and recently during the commemoration of menstrual hygiene day on May 28 2014, paint a very sad picture on what girls have to endure on a monthly basis.These reports indicate that at least 62 % of girls in Zimbabwe are using very unhygienic materials likes leaves, cow dung and dirty rags during their menstruation.  At least 20% of the girls miss school every month during their monthly menstruation period.

 Below are some excerpts from these media reports

Poor girls use newspapers, cow dung as pads during menstruation: http://www.thezimbabwean.co/news/36380/poor-girls-use-newspapers-cowdung-as-pads-during-menstruation.html  (19/12/2010)

“..due to lack of resources, some young girls in Zimbabwe are using pieces of cloth, newspapers, cow dung and tissues as sanitary ware during their monthly menstruation”.

  Menstruating rural girls using newspapers:http://www.thezimbabwean.co/news/zimbabwe/57907/menstruating-rural-girls-using-newspapers.html (25.04.2012)

“Government should seriously consider subsidising the cost of pads to stop a looming health hazard as menstruating rural girls have resorted to using newspapers, cow dung and maize cobs.”

 Dignity denied: The lost power of Zimbabwean girls and women:https://worldpulse.com/node/76251  19 August 2013

“In 2011 women set up a petition and marched to parliament calling upon leaders to hear their appeal for dignity. They wanted the 2012 National Budget to make provision for pads and tampons to be made available for free in schools and communities. To date nothing has surfaced “

  Cow dung used as sanitary pads: http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/africa/2014/05/29/cow-dung-used-as-sanitary-pads. May 29, 2014

“Due to high sanitary costs and lack of resources,  Zimbabwean women make do with pieces of cloth, newspapers, fresh grass and even cow dung to absorb the flow of their monthly menstruation.”

The Campaign

Moved by reports in the local media during the commemoration of Menstrual Hygiene Day on 28 May 2014 and before, Volunteer in Zimbabwe Trust launched the Sanitary Pads Campaign. The campaign seeks through volunteers to provide sanitary pads to school girls in rural, farming and peri-urban areas.  The project requires volunteers to purchase sanitary pads or to simply supply a girl child with sanitary pads on a month to month basis. Volunteer in Zimbabwe Trust appeals to individuals, groups or organizations to kindly donate cash or actual sanitary pads for these young girls to allow them to retain their dignity and enable them to remain in school.

Help us raise $25,000.00 to ensure that 2,230  school girls have access to sanitary pads for at least 6 months.

About Volunteer in Zimbabwe

Launched in 2009, Volunteer in Zimbabwe Trust is a Zimbabwean organisation working in Zimbabwe to promote and encourage volunteerism by both locals and internationals. The Trust is reaching out particularly to fellow Zimbabweans to use their time, influence and resources as volunteers in the communities they live and work in by taking part in simple activities that have a life changing impact on beneficiaries in Zimbabwe. Simple acts like collecting sanitary pads for use by poor girls can make such a huge difference to school children in Zimbabwe.  The Trust strives to connect volunteers with communities in need of services in Zimbabwe.

For more information  about Volunteer in Zimbabwe and how else you can help , visit www.volunteerinzimbabwe.com or contact

Barbara Hapazari; Projects Consultant
+263 778755265  
Skype:barbara.hapaz
info@volunteerinzimbabwe.com

story:
Conscience is an organisation that has been campaigning for a more peaceful world since 1979. We continually campaign for an increase in spending on peacebuilding and conflict prevention as an ethical and effective alternative to spending on military led solution.  

For a small team, we have a big amount of support for what we do. We regularly work with Parliament to try and work towards a more peaceful world and it seems like they are listening! Last November, Fabian Hamilton was given the position of Britain’s first Shadow Minister for Peace and Disarmament.

This is very exciting, not only for us but for the future of British foreign policy. However, we want to make sure that this is a full funded and supported role, not just a symbolic post.   

We are looking to answer three main questions;

  1. What powers will the new Minister have when creating foreign policy?
  2. How will the new department be funded?
  3. What will be the priorities of this new department?

We are looking to raise £2500 so we can create our well researched and fully comprehensive report into the role and responsibilities that the new minister will have. If we do reach our stretch target of £3000, we will use the extra £500 to send a copy to every MP in the UK.

For your support and donations, we will write to you thanking you from our office, as well as sending out pens and copies of the report. Our biggest donors will be invited to meet our team in our London office as well as having a guided tour of Parliament with one of our supporting MPs.

We truly believe that this report could help change the way our Government views the new Minister and his role in contributing to peaceful solutions. By supporting us, you not only help us but you also show our Government that you care about a strong Minister for Peace and Disarmament who is able to influence foreign policy for the better.

story:
2015 has been a really freezing cold winter this year. Help the homeless by donating money. We will use this money to help cloth as money homeless people as possible. They don't deserve to sleep in the freezing cold. The temperatures in NYC has hit temperatures as low as 0 degrees, Unfortunately some people have no choice but to live on these streets. Change will not come if we wait for some other person or some other time. We are the ones we've been waiting for. We are the change that we seek.

End Goal:

1. To clothe as many homeless people that are sleeping on the streets of NY during this freezing cold winter.

story:
The Mission :: Raise $8,000 to complete Kolimo Plant

Renew Communities is a missional church in Cleveland, OH that exists to see communities renewed by Jesus. One of the primary ways we do this is through church planting both locally and globally.

In December of 2011 we raised $7,000 to plant a church in Kolimo, Haiti in partnership with Haiti Bible Mission.  Kolimo is an hours drive from HBM's headquarters and a 35 minute hike up the side of a mountain. Because of the distance and terrain the cost of construction increases from $7,000 to $16,000.  

We feel passionate about finishing the job by raising the rest of the funds needed to complete construction by year end!

Reaching our goal would...

  • Increase the influence of the gospel in Kolimo
  • Provide a permenant place for worship and discipleship to take place
  • Set plans in motion for a school to educate children in the villiage 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $8,000 to finish this project. Every dollar up to $8,000 that is donated here will go to finalizing the construction of the church in Kolimo. When we exceed our goal every additional dollar will go to Haiti Bible Mission's efforts to train more indiginous church platners.

This is a partnership so if you give we have some gifts for you!

  • $25 - 2 HBM Stickers
  • $50 - HBM Shirt
  • $100 - Planting Renewal Shirt
  • $250 - Dinner w/ Mark Stockland - Executive Director of HBM
  • $5000 - Free Strategic Exposure Trip to Haiti 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give financially to this project that's ok - but you probably know someone who can. Help us get the word out!  Here's a few ideas of how...

  • Post this video on your blog/facebook
  • Tweet about our campaign with a link
  • E-mail our video and link to the campaign to your friends & family and a short explaination of why this matters to you.
  • Show our video to your small group/bible study/church and invite them to give.
  • Invent a creative way to raise funds (running fundraisers/bake sales/hunger strikes) 

AND PRAY!

  • for Haiti
  • for the Kolimo church plant
  • for Pastor Honre Gelem
  • for Mark Stockland, his family and all the HBM employees
  • for the funds to accomplish this task! 

Questions

If you have any questions about Renew Communities, Haiti Bible Mission or our Planting Renewal project please e-mail info@renewcommunities.com.
