story:
El 18 de Abril de 1975 en la ciudad de Monterrey, Nuevo León fue detenido-desaparecido por la Policía Judicial del Estado y la Dirección Federal de Seguridad (DFS, hoy conocido como CISEN: Centro de Investigación y Seguridad Nacional) Jesús Piedra Ibarra un joven estudiante de medicina de apenas 20 años de edad.  Desde entonces su familia, pero especialmente su madre, Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, se dio a la tarea de buscarlo y reclamarlo a las autoridades mexicanas. En esa búsqueda, Rosario  además de sufrir  el martirio angustiante de ignorar el paradero de su hijo tuvo que soportar largas antesalas en las dependencias gubernamentales encargadas de la impartición de justicia creyendo que cumplirían con el mandato constitucional   de salvaguardar los derechos ciudadanos;  pero al contrario, solo recibió respuestas evasivas negando la participación de sus policías en el secuestro de su hijo.  En estos recorridos agobiantes se encontró con otras mujeres  que también buscaban la presentación con vida de sus hijos o de algún familiar que fue detenido en forma similar y en circunstancias parecidas  por la policía política y/o las fuerzas armadas. Ante tanta complicidad e indolencia de las autoridades,  las familias vimos  que era necesario conformar un grupo organizado en cada estado del país donde  este crimen estaba sucediendo y con el cual pudiéramos emprender la lucha colectiva por la libertad de los nuestros y al mismo tiempo  defendernos de los embates represivos del gobierno, además de que las cárceles públicas ya se encontraban llenas de presos políticos, se habían girado innumerables órdenes de aprehensión para la disidencia y un buen número de hombres y mujeres habían tenido que abandonar el país y fue  entonces  que en abril de 1977 se constituyó en la ciudad de Monterrey el Comité Pro-Defensa de Presos, Perseguidos, Desaparecidos y Exiliados Políticos de México integrado sólo por las familias que en su mayoría eran las que buscaban a los desaparecidos; adquiriendo carácter nacional los días 7 y 8 de Agosto del mismo año. Hoy solo lo nombramos Comité ¡Eureka!.

Así se inició esta larga y difícil lucha que no ha sido en vano. A pesar de la desigualdad de la fuerza, cuando a nadie en México se le ocurría que era fundamental la lucha por los derechos humanos, cuando nadie se organizaba para su defensa, los familiares de los desaparecidos fuimos el motor de un gran movimiento, realizando marchas, mítines, huelgas de hambre, plantones, bloqueos y acciones de gran carga simbólica. Se logró que se aprobara una Ley de Amnistía en 1979 mediante la cual fueron liberados 1,500 presos políticos, 2,000 órdenes de aprehensión quedaron sin efecto, regresaron al país 57 exiliados y fue posible rescatar con vida a 148 personas que permanecían desaparecidas en cárceles clandestinas del mal gobierno.

Sin embargo, a la fecha, tenemos registrados 557 desapariciones forzadas en el periodo que comprende de 1969 hasta los últimos años de la década de los 90's.

 El Museo

Surgimos hace 4 años y medio. Nuestro objetivo es mantener en la conciencia de todos la existencia de los desaparecidos, es nuestra forma de seguir luchando por los seres queridos que nos fueron arrebatados  y llevados a las cárceles clandestinas en campos militares y bases navales porque  creyeron que con el aletazo de la represión y el encierro borrarían todo vestigio de su existencia y que quedarían para siempre en la sombra del olvido.

El Estado mexicano al fraguar su plan siniestro se olvidó de la memoria; ¡sí! esa que ha sido nuestra arma y el obstáculo para todos aquellos que no se cansan de justificar a los victimarios frente a las víctimas. Esa memoria que es la única que puede salvar a la historia devolviéndole su moral y dignidad.

Por eso en el Museo Casa de la Memoria Indómita queremos que las generaciones presentes y futuras conozcan lo que ha sido la lucha por la vida y la libertad. Que comprendan que este arduo trabajo no admite reposo porque si detuviéramos nuestros pasos nos envileceríamos... pero esperanzados, porque no perdemos la fe en la humanidad, deseamos que quienes nos visiten salgan de este recinto con la firme convicción de erradicar de la faz de la tierra este aterrador crimen.

El mal gobierno de México en un hecho terrible y vergonzoso, fue el primero en América Latina en utilizar la Desaparición Forzada. Por eso hoy le damos mayor valor a la memoria como patrimonio universal mediante los documentos y las imágenes de todos estos seres queridos víctimas de de este crimen que nos llaman a continuar en resistencia.  El trabajo expuesto en este Museo  ha emanado de nuestro archivo, con la profunda convicción de poner al descubierto, la impunidad, la simulación, la corrupción y la injusticia que siguen transitando por todo el territorio nacional como nuevos jinetes del apocalipsis.

En qué se utilizará el donativo:

Al Museo lo hemos mantenido funcionando sin depender de ninguna institución gubernamental o privada.

Tú donación permitirá al Museo un año más de existencia.

  • Podremos seguir avanzando en el rescate de nuestro archivo que representa un legado histórico, y que pondrá  a disposición los casos de desaparición forzada de las décadas de los 70's, 80's y 90's  y  las acciones de  la incansable lucha del Comité ¡Eureka! durante 42 años.
  • Continuar con todas nuestras actividades como exposiciones temporales, ponencias y conferencias, presentación de libros, mesas redondas, foros, proyecciones de películas y documentales, talleres de música, de teatro y de otra índole, obras de teatro, danza, etcétera... ¡es un Museo vivo! y un recinto para que los ciudadanos de cualquier parte del mundo expongan colaborando con nosotros en la defensa de los derechos humanos reemplazando la visión unilateral, por una amplia y plural fortaleciendo el sentido crítico.
  • Podremos darle mantenimiento al edificio , como  la eliminación de humedad en los muros sur y poniente; impermeabilización, habilitación e iluminación en cuarto de  azotea que se convertirá en el salón de uso múltiple; habilitación de lo que será la biblioteca especializada para casos de  violación a las garantías individuales y habilitación del salón de reuniones y trabajo. Por tratarse de una edificación histórica en el centro de la Ciudad de México se harán los trámites ante el Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes (INBA).

Riesgo de no llegar a la meta

No llegar a la meta sería dificultarnos la función principal del Museo que es la denuncia de la Desaparición Forzada y la Impunidad imperante hasta el día de hoy en todo México.

¡VIVOS LOS LLEVARON! ¡VIVOS LOS QUEREMOS!

 

Antecedent:

On April 18, 1975, in the city of Monterrey, Mexico, Jesús Piedra Ibarra, a young medicine student aged only 20, was kidnapped and vanished by the Policía Judicial del Estado (State Judicial Police) and the Dirección Federal de Seguridad, or DFS (Federal Security Directorate), now called Centro de Investigación y Seguridad Nacional, or CISEN (National Security and Investigation Centre).

Since then his family, but specially his mother, Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, have commited to the task of searching him and claiming for him to the Mexican authorities. In her search, Rosario, besides  suffering the anguish of ignoring her son's whereabouts, had to endure long waits in the governmental dependencies in charge of administering justice believing that they would accomplish their constitutional obligation of safeguarding citizens' rights; but instead, she only got elusive answers which denied police's involvement in her son's kidnapping. In these tiring routes she found other women who also demanded the releasing of their sons, daughters, or relatives who were detained in similar ways and circumstances by the political police and/or the Armed Forces. In the face of so much complicity and indolence of the authorities, we the families saw that it was necessary to conform an organized group in every state of the country where this crime was happening and with which we could start a collective struggle for the freedom of our loved ones, and at the same time to defend ourselves from the governmental repressive attacks.

Besides the fact that public prisons were already full of political prisoners, innumerable arrest orders were issued for the dissidence and a great number of men and women had to flee the country. It was then, when in April 1997 the Comité Pro-Defensa de Presos, Perseguidos, Desaparecidos y Exiliados Políticos de México (Political prisoners, persecuted, vanished, and exiled people pro-defense Committee) integrated only by the families that in their majority were the ones who searched for the vanished people. The committee acquired national character on the days 7 and 8 August of the same year. Today we only call it "Comité ¡Eureka!"

So it started this difficult struggle that has not been in vain. Despite the difference in power, when nobody in Mexico thought that the struggle for human rights was fundamental, when no ones organized themselves to defend them, the relatives of the desaparecidos (vanished people) were the spark that started a great movement, making marches, meetings, and hunger strikes, amongst other actions with enormous symbolical charge. In 1978 we achieved the approval of an Amnesty Law that through which 1,500 political prisoners were released, 2,000 arrest orders remained unimplemented, 57 exiled persons returned home, and it was possible to rescue alive 148 persons who remained vanished in clandestine prisons of the bad government.  

Nevertheless, until today we have registered 557 forced disappearances in the period that spans from 1969 up to the last years of the 1990s.

The Museum:

We started four and a half years ago. Our objective is to maintain the desaparecidos existence in everyone's conscience. It is our way to continue fighting for our loved ones who were taken from us and thrown into clandestine jails in navy bases and military fields, because they believed that with the use of repression and imprisonment they would erase all proof of their existence and would remain forever in the shadow of oblivion.   

Mexican State forgot about Memory when it forged it's evil plan. Yes! Memory has been our weapon and the obstacle for those who never get tired of justifying the offenders over the victims. That memory is the only thing that can save History by restoring it's moral and dignity.

That is why in the Museo Casa de la Memoria Indómita (House of the Indomitable Memory) we want that present and future generations know what the struggle for life and freedom has been. So that they understand that this hard work does not admit any rest because if we stop our steps we will vilify ourselves… But we also want them to leave this place full of hope, because we don't lose our faith in humanity; to emerge from this enclosure with the firm conviction of eradicating from earth this heinous crime.

The bad Mexican government, in a terrible and shameful deed, was the first in Latin America to use the Forced Disappearance. That's why today we give Memory a higher value as universal patrimony through the documents and images of our loved ones who are victims of this crime that compels us to continue resisting. The work exposed in this museum has emanated from our archives, with the profound conviction of unveiling the impunity, simulation, corruption and injustice that continue transiting throughout our nation's territory as the new riders of Apocalypse.

How will the collected funds be used:

The museum has been maintained in working order without depending of any governmental or private institution.

Your donation will allow the museum to exist a year more.

  • We can continue forward in the rescue of our archive, which represents historical legacy and which will put to disposition the forced disappearance cases from the 1970's, 1980's and 1990's and the actions of Comité ¡Eureka!'s 42 year tireless struggle.
  • Continue with all our activities such as temporary expositions, lectures and conferences, book presentations, study groups, forums, film and documentary screenings, music workshops, theatre, dance, et cetera… This is a living Museum! and an enclosure for citizens of all the world collaborate with us in the defense of human rights replacing the unilateral vision for a wide and diverse one that strengthens critical thinking.
  • We can work on the building's maintenance, such as the elimination of humidity in southern and western walls, waterproofing the roofs, habilitation and lighting of the upper room that will be converted in a multipurpose hall. We will open a library specializing in individual rights violations, and  a meeting and working hall. Because this is a historical building in Mexico City's downtown, the procedures will be made under the authority of the Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes, or INBA (National Institute of Fine Arts).

 

Risk of not achieving our goal

To achieve our goal will resolve several difficulties which impede us to fully accomplish our main function that is the permanent denunciation of Forced Disappearance and the impunity that prevails up to the day in all Mexico. Not achieving our goal would be another obstacle in this unequal fight, but there is no way that we will stop doing our labor.   

 

¡ALIVE THEY WERE TAKEN!  ¡ ALIVE WE WANT THEM BACK!
story_txt:
El 18 de Abril de 1975 en la ciudad de Monterrey, Nuevo León fue detenido-desaparecido por la Policía Judicial del Estado y la Dirección Federal de Seguridad (DFS, hoy conocido como CISEN: Centro de Investigación y Seguridad Nacional) Jesús Piedra Ibarra un joven estudiante de medicina de apenas 20 años de edad.  Desde entonces su familia, pero especialmente su madre, Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, se dio a la tarea de buscarlo y reclamarlo a las autoridades mexicanas. En esa búsqueda, Rosario  además de sufrir  el martirio angustiante de ignorar el paradero de su hijo tuvo que soportar largas antesalas en las dependencias gubernamentales encargadas de la impartición de justicia creyendo que cumplirían con el mandato constitucional   de salvaguardar los derechos ciudadanos;  pero al contrario, solo recibió respuestas evasivas negando la participación de sus policías en el secuestro de su hijo.  En estos recorridos agobiantes se encontró con otras mujeres  que también buscaban la presentación con vida de sus hijos o de algún familiar que fue detenido en forma similar y en circunstancias parecidas  por la policía política y/o las fuerzas armadas. Ante tanta complicidad e indolencia de las autoridades,  las familias vimos  que era necesario conformar un grupo organizado en cada estado del país donde  este crimen estaba sucediendo y con el cual pudiéramos emprender la lucha colectiva por la libertad de los nuestros y al mismo tiempo  defendernos de los embates represivos del gobierno, además de que las cárceles públicas ya se encontraban llenas de presos políticos, se habían girado innumerables órdenes de aprehensión para la disidencia y un buen número de hombres y mujeres habían tenido que abandonar el país y fue  entonces  que en abril de 1977 se constituyó en la ciudad de Monterrey el Comité Pro-Defensa de Presos, Perseguidos, Desaparecidos y Exiliados Políticos de México integrado sólo por las familias que en su mayoría eran las que buscaban a los desaparecidos; adquiriendo carácter nacional los días 7 y 8 de Agosto del mismo año. Hoy solo lo nombramos Comité ¡Eureka!.
Así se inició esta larga y difícil lucha que no ha sido en vano. A pesar de la desigualdad de la fuerza, cuando a nadie en México se le ocurría que era fundamental la lucha por los derechos humanos, cuando nadie se organizaba para su defensa, los familiares de los desaparecidos fuimos el motor de un gran movimiento, realizando marchas, mítines, huelgas de hambre, plantones, bloqueos y acciones de gran carga simbólica. Se logró que se aprobara una Ley de Amnistía en 1979 mediante la cual fueron liberados 1,500 presos políticos, 2,000 órdenes de aprehensión quedaron sin efecto, regresaron al país 57 exiliados y fue posible rescatar con vida a 148 personas que permanecían desaparecidas en cárceles clandestinas del mal gobierno.
Sin embargo, a la fecha, tenemos registrados 557 desapariciones forzadas en el periodo que comprende de 1969 hasta los últimos años de la década de los 90's.
 El Museo
Surgimos hace 4 años y medio. Nuestro objetivo es mantener en la conciencia de todos la existencia de los desaparecidos, es nuestra forma de seguir luchando por los seres queridos que nos fueron arrebatados  y llevados a las cárceles clandestinas en campos militares y bases navales porque  creyeron que con el aletazo de la represión y el encierro borrarían todo vestigio de su existencia y que quedarían para siempre en la sombra del olvido.
El Estado mexicano al fraguar su plan siniestro se olvidó de la memoria; ¡sí! esa que ha sido nuestra arma y el obstáculo para todos aquellos que no se cansan de justificar a los victimarios frente a las víctimas. Esa memoria que es la única que puede salvar a la historia devolviéndole su moral y dignidad.
Por eso en el Museo Casa de la Memoria Indómita queremos que las generaciones presentes y futuras conozcan lo que ha sido la lucha por la vida y la libertad. Que comprendan que este arduo trabajo no admite reposo porque si detuviéramos nuestros pasos nos envileceríamos... pero esperanzados, porque no perdemos la fe en la humanidad, deseamos que quienes nos visiten salgan de este recinto con la firme convicción de erradicar de la faz de la tierra este aterrador crimen.
El mal gobierno de México en un hecho terrible y vergonzoso, fue el primero en América Latina en utilizar la Desaparición Forzada. Por eso hoy le damos mayor valor a la memoria como patrimonio universal mediante los documentos y las imágenes de todos estos seres queridos víctimas de de este crimen que nos llaman a continuar en resistencia.  El trabajo expuesto en este Museo  ha emanado de nuestro archivo, con la profunda convicción de poner al descubierto, la impunidad, la simulación, la corrupción y la injusticia que siguen transitando por todo el territorio nacional como nuevos jinetes del apocalipsis.
En qué se utilizará el donativo:
Al Museo lo hemos mantenido funcionando sin depender de ninguna institución gubernamental o privada.
Tú donación permitirá al Museo un año más de existencia.

Podremos seguir avanzando en el rescate de nuestro archivo que representa un legado histórico, y que pondrá  a disposición los casos de desaparición forzada de las décadas de los 70's, 80's y 90's  y  las acciones de  la incansable lucha del Comité ¡Eureka! durante 42 años.
Continuar con todas nuestras actividades como exposiciones temporales, ponencias y conferencias, presentación de libros, mesas redondas, foros, proyecciones de películas y documentales, talleres de música, de teatro y de otra índole, obras de teatro, danza, etcétera... ¡es un Museo vivo! y un recinto para que los ciudadanos de cualquier parte del mundo expongan colaborando con nosotros en la defensa de los derechos humanos reemplazando la visión unilateral, por una amplia y plural fortaleciendo el sentido crítico.
Podremos darle mantenimiento al edificio , como  la eliminación de humedad en los muros sur y poniente; impermeabilización, habilitación e iluminación en cuarto de  azotea que se convertirá en el salón de uso múltiple; habilitación de lo que será la biblioteca especializada para casos de  violación a las garantías individuales y habilitación del salón de reuniones y trabajo. Por tratarse de una edificación histórica en el centro de la Ciudad de México se harán los trámites ante el Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes (INBA).

Riesgo de no llegar a la meta
No llegar a la meta sería dificultarnos la función principal del Museo que es la denuncia de la Desaparición Forzada y la Impunidad imperante hasta el día de hoy en todo México.
¡VIVOS LOS LLEVARON! ¡VIVOS LOS QUEREMOS!
 Antecedent:On April 18, 1975, in the city of Monterrey, Mexico, Jesús Piedra Ibarra, a young medicine student aged only 20, was kidnapped and vanished by the Policía Judicial del Estado (State Judicial Police) and the Dirección Federal de Seguridad, or DFS (Federal Security Directorate), now called Centro de Investigación y Seguridad Nacional, or CISEN (National Security and Investigation Centre).Since then his family, but specially his mother, Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, have commited to the task of searching him and claiming for him to the Mexican authorities. In her search, Rosario, besides  suffering the anguish of ignoring her son's whereabouts, had to endure long waits in the governmental dependencies in charge of administering justice believing that they would accomplish their constitutional obligation of safeguarding citizens' rights; but instead, she only got elusive answers which denied police's involvement in her son's kidnapping. In these tiring routes she found other women who also demanded the releasing of their sons, daughters, or relatives who were detained in similar ways and circumstances by the political police and/or the Armed Forces. In the face of so much complicity and indolence of the authorities, we the families saw that it was necessary to conform an organized group in every state of the country where this crime was happening and with which we could start a collective struggle for the freedom of our loved ones, and at the same time to defend ourselves from the governmental repressive attacks.Besides the fact that public prisons were already full of political prisoners, innumerable arrest orders were issued for the dissidence and a great number of men and women had to flee the country. It was then, when in April 1997 the Comité Pro-Defensa de Presos, Perseguidos, Desaparecidos y Exiliados Políticos de México (Political prisoners, persecuted, vanished, and exiled people pro-defense Committee) integrated only by the families that in their majority were the ones who searched for the vanished people. The committee acquired national character on the days 7 and 8 August of the same year. Today we only call it "Comité ¡Eureka!"So it started this difficult struggle that has not been in vain. Despite the difference in power, when nobody in Mexico thought that the struggle for human rights was fundamental, when no ones organized themselves to defend them, the relatives of the desaparecidos (vanished people) were the spark that started a great movement, making marches, meetings, and hunger strikes, amongst other actions with enormous symbolical charge. In 1978 we achieved the approval of an Amnesty Law that through which 1,500 political prisoners were released, 2,000 arrest orders remained unimplemented, 57 exiled persons returned home, and it was possible to rescue alive 148 persons who remained vanished in clandestine prisons of the bad government.  Nevertheless, until today we have registered 557 forced disappearances in the period that spans from 1969 up to the last years of the 1990s.The Museum:We started four and a half years ago. Our objective is to maintain the desaparecidos existence in everyone's conscience. It is our way to continue fighting for our loved ones who were taken from us and thrown into clandestine jails in navy bases and military fields, because they believed that with the use of repression and imprisonment they would erase all proof of their existence and would remain forever in the shadow of oblivion.   Mexican State forgot about Memory when it forged it's evil plan. Yes! Memory has been our weapon and the obstacle for those who never get tired of justifying the offenders over the victims. That memory is the only thing that can save History by restoring it's moral and dignity.That is why in the Museo Casa de la Memoria Indómita (House of the Indomitable Memory) we want that present and future generations know what the struggle for life and freedom has been. So that they understand that this hard work does not admit any rest because if we stop our steps we will vilify ourselves… But we also want them to leave this place full of hope, because we don't lose our faith in humanity; to emerge from this enclosure with the firm conviction of eradicating from earth this heinous crime.The bad Mexican government, in a terrible and shameful deed, was the first in Latin America to use the Forced Disappearance. That's why today we give Memory a higher value as universal patrimony through the documents and images of our loved ones who are victims of this crime that compels us to continue resisting. The work exposed in this museum has emanated from our archives, with the profound conviction of unveiling the impunity, simulation, corruption and injustice that continue transiting throughout our nation's territory as the new riders of Apocalypse.How will the collected funds be used:The museum has been maintained in working order without depending of any governmental or private institution.Your donation will allow the museum to exist a year more.
We can continue forward in the rescue of our archive, which represents historical legacy and which will put to disposition the forced disappearance cases from the 1970's, 1980's and 1990's and the actions of Comité ¡Eureka!'s 42 year tireless struggle.
Continue with all our activities such as temporary expositions, lectures and conferences, book presentations, study groups, forums, film and documentary screenings, music workshops, theatre, dance, et cetera… This is a living Museum! and an enclosure for citizens of all the world collaborate with us in the defense of human rights replacing the unilateral vision for a wide and diverse one that strengthens critical thinking.
We can work on the building's maintenance, such as the elimination of humidity in southern and western walls, waterproofing the roofs, habilitation and lighting of the upper room that will be converted in a multipurpose hall. We will open a library specializing in individual rights violations, and  a meeting and working hall. Because this is a historical building in Mexico City's downtown, the procedures will be made under the authority of the Instituto Nacional de Bellas Artes, or INBA (National Institute of Fine Arts).
 Risk of not achieving our goalTo achieve our goal will resolve several difficulties which impede us to fully accomplish our main function that is the permanent denunciation of Forced Disappearance and the impunity that prevails up to the day in all Mexico. Not achieving our goal would be another obstacle in this unequal fight, but there is no way that we will stop doing our labor.    ¡ALIVE THEY WERE TAKEN!  ¡ ALIVE WE WANT THEM BACK!

story:
Qui sommes-nous?

Nous sommes une organisation de solidarité fondée en 1976 qui travaille à la défense et à la promotion des droits humains en réciprocité avec les mouvements sociaux et les communautés d’Amérique latine dans la lutte en faveur d’une justice sociale, environnementale, économique et culturelle.

Les actions urgentes constituent le pilier du travail du CDHAL et c’est à travers celles-ci que nous entretenons des liens de réciprocité avec les mouvements sociaux et les groupes de base en Amérique latine. Nous effectuons un suivi de l’actualité d’Amérique latine et la diffusons au Québec et au Canada, recevons des demandes d’appuis des communautés et des mouvements sociaux, participons à de nombreuses campagnes de dénonciation, et rédigeons et traduisons des communiqués, déclarations et pétitions ayant pour objectif de faire pression pour des cas particuliers et de contribuer à l’éducation du public.

Les actions urgentes appuient nos allié.e.s d’Amérique latine en dénonçant auprès des gouvernements latino-américains et canadien des situations d’oppression, de répression et de violations des droits humains qui portent atteinte au droit à la vie et à un environnement sain, à l’autodétermination, à l’intégrité, à la sécurité et à la liberté des personnes ou groupes, au droit de se défendre, ainsi qu’à la criminalisation de la protestation sociale.

Cette campagne de sociofinancement vise à appuyer le programme des actions urgentes du CDHAL en permettant à l'équipe de poursuivre et d'étendre un suivi rigoureux des actions en cours. Le financement recueilli permettra aussi à l'équipe de se doter de moyens pour approfondir et alimenter la compréhension et l’analyse des enjeux sociaux, politiques et environnementaux auxquels nous nous intéressons à travers nos liens avec les mouvements sociaux latino-américains et les communautés affectées par les projets extractifs. 

Le CDHAL est en contact et appuie une quinzaine de mouvements sociaux et groupes de base en Amérique latine, notamment le Mexique, Guatemala, Honduras, Salvador, Colombie, Équateur, Brésil, Argentine et Chili. Nous sommes particulièrement interpellées par la situation de défenseur-e-s des droits humains. Nous avons récemment contribué à des actions urgentes en solidarité avec les communautés mapuches huilliche du Fundo Alto Gaboa, Chiloé, Chili; avec les communautés affectées par le barrage Hidroituango en Colombie, avec le collectif Brésil-Montréal pour dénoncer le contexte des élections brésiliennes, avec les prisonniers politiques au Honduras, entre autres.

Que faisons-nous concrètement?

L’équipe des actions urgentes, coordonnée par une responsable et composée de stagiaires de différents programmes universitaires et de militant.e.s, est mobilisée toute l’année afin de traduire de nombreux documents et des nouvelles des partenaires avec lesquels nous travaillons pour rendre ces informations accessibles pour le public québécois et canadien à travers le bulletin mensuel Solidared (écrit et audio), en français et en espagnol, et aussi via notre site Internet et notre page Facebook.

Depuis l’année dernière, l’équipe a cherché à innover et à diversifier ses outils de communications en élaborant une version audio du bulletin mensuel Solidared : voix de résistances dans les Amériques, grâce à la contribution de stagiaires provenant de l'Association latino-américaine d'éducation radiophonique (ALER). L’information partagée à travers ce bulletin provient de différents mouvements, organisations sociales et groupes de base qui travaillent pour la justice sociale et environnementale à travers le continent. Elle constitue donc des nouvelles de première source qui ne sont pas diffusées par les médias traditionnels.

Dans le cadre du volet des actions urgentes du CDHAL, des communautés d’apprentissage sont également organisées à raison d’une fois par mois afin d’approfondir notre compréhension sur différentes situations d’actualité et de renforcer  les capacités d’analyse, de réponse et d’action de l’équipe et des membres du CDHAL, ainsi que de collaborateur-trice-s. Au cours de la dernière année, des communautés d’apprentissage ont eu lieu sur les situations au Venezuela, en Bolivie, au Mexique et au Nicaragua, entre autres.

Pourquoi soutenir cette campagne?

Votre appui nous permettra de poursuivre notre travail quotidien de veille et de diffusion des violations des droits humains à travers les Amériques et de répondre de manière ponctuelle aux différents appels de solidarité. Les raisons sont nombreuses pour continuer à lutter et à dénoncer puisque à chaque jour, des populations des Amériques résistent devant un modèle qui privilégie les intérêts privés et transnationaux au détriment des communautés locales.

Concrètement, les fonds amassés contribueront au salaire de la responsable des actions urgentes et aux frais liés à la réalisation d'actions urgentes, ainsi qu'aux communications avec les mouvements sociaux.

Dans le cadre de cette campagne de financement, vous pourrez vous procurez, en contrepartie d'un don, un billet pour participer à notre soirée festive, qui aura lieu le 7 décembre prochain, à partir de 19h00, au Bar le Ritz à Montréal. Ce sera l’occasion de lancer la prochaine édition de notre revue annuelle Caminando qui porte cette année sur les luttes des femmes pour la défense des territoires. Un don au CDHAL pourrait aussi vous permettre d'obtenir en contrepartie une copie de la revue. Nous vous invitons à consulter la section des contreparties.

Merci à l'avance pour votre générosité! Tous les dons, même les plus petits font une réelle différence pour notre équipe et notre travail de solidarité avec les mouvements sociaux en Amérique latine.

Aidez-nous à diffuser largement la campagne dans vos réseaux!

story:
\ 


UP TO $2,500 WILL BE MATCHED BY EBAY!!!


WHAT ARE THE H.O.P.E. LOCKERS?

The H.O.P.E. Lockers are a day-use facility of safe and secure lockers for Salt Lake's homeless community to store their cherished belongings. They will include ADA access.

H.O.P.E. stands for “Helping Other People Evolve,” and the Lockers will do just this by providing not only a safe space for storage, but also the peace of mind that comes with that while they look for employment, attend appointments and clinics, and generally live their lives.


This project came from the homeless community itself. When you ask someone what they truly need to improve their lives, the answer is often surprising.


MUCH, MUCH MORE THAN "JUST LOCKERS" 

These Lockers provide not only a place to store things throughout the day, but the peace of mind that comes with knowing your worldly belongings, your resources, and your identity are protected.

Furthermore, these lockers will provide the homeless community the dignity to empower themselves and evolve their lives by obtaining and retaining employment, and other opportunities that come with the freedom of mobility.

ABOUT THE TEAM

This project is a product of the collective effort of two local 501(c)3 non-profit organizations: Revolution United and The Legacy Initiative. 
The H.O.P.E. Lockers are the first phase of a sustainable, self-governing village of tiny homes for the homeless of Salt Lake City, that will be called The Legacy Village SLC. 

REVOLUTION UNITED

Revolution United is a human centered nonprofit organization inciting a fundamental change in the way humans engage their communities in all sectors of life! Our mission is to develop open source projects utilizing inclusion, innovation, collective impact, and the desire for holistic well-being. We unify the  individuals, non-profits, and businesses to make it happen. 

THE LEGACY INITIATIVE

The Legacy Initiative's mission is to fight hunger, provide humanitarian aid, and educate people through community partnerships not just for today, but for our future.

The idea for the Lockers came from within the homeless community itself, out of a collective brainstorming session called an "Idea Silo."

HOW WILL FUNDS BE USED?

We aim to be  completely transparent in this project, every step of the way. Regular updates of expenses and income will be provided to the community via our webpages. 
  • Because we are verified non-profit organizations, Indiegogo will only take 4% of the funds we raise if we meet our goal, or 6.75% if we don't!
  • The design and engineering work is being done complimentary by a member of our team, so we are keeping (wo)manpower costs at nearly zero.


STRETCH GOALS!

+ If we raise $13,000 total we will add solar panels that power security cameras.
+ If we raise $14,000 total, we will incorporate Legacy Village as it's own 501(c)3 non-profit organization. 
+ If we raise $20,000 total, we will build our first Tiny House for the Legacy Village SLC project.

--------------------------------------------------->>>>>


Some Articles written about the Hope Lockers:

GOOD 4 UTAH - ABC 4http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=32771629

http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=32771629


SALT LAKE CITY WEEKLY
  SL CITY

FREQUENTLY ASKED CHALLENGES

There are a lot of potential issues that can arise from the lockers, here are some of the answers: 

  • Q- Who gets use of the lockers?
    A-Lockers are assigned on a first come first served basis
  • Q-How long can I store my property?
    A-Property is to be removed each day. 
  • Q-Can I keep my belongings in a locker for more than one day?
    A-No extensions are granted for lockers.
  • Q-What should I do if I forgot my access code or lost the key to my lock?
    A-You should contact us directly and to discuss what can be done.
  • Q-How big is an individual locker unit?
    A-The locker unit is a measures 1'-6" feet wide 2 feet deep and 3 feet high.
  • Q-What are the hours I am able to access my unit?
    A-Access hours will be determined due to the location where the Locker unit is set up.
  • Q-Where will the HOPE lockers be located?
    A-Desired locations have been selected in the downtown area, close to service providers.
  • Q-How will we prevent the storing of weapons/ illegal goods/ drugs, theft, and vandalism?
    A-The lockers will be monitored by our volunteers. Law enforcement will be able to monitor them as well. Security cameras will be mounted on the unit to deter illegal activities.
  • Q-How will insect/rodent infestation (bed bugs) be avoided?
    A-Adhesive traps will be placed to monitor for the presence of insects. Non toxic treatments such as diatomaceous earth will be used.
  • Q-How will you prevent the theft of facility/trailer unit?
    A-When set up, the unit will be placed on jack stands and the tires will be removed.
  • Q-What should I do if I lose password and need to gain access to my locker?
    A-You should contact us immediately and allow up to 24 hours for access into your locker.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN GET ENGAGED

If you can't contribute financially, that's okay! We have other ways:

  • Share this campaign on your social media streams.

  • Do the #HopeCallout! Go somewhere in public and begin recording, Call out 5 of your friends to take the challenge. The challenge is to either donate $10 to the campaign or shout "I HAVE A NAME!" as loud as you can.

WE CAN'T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!
story_txt:
\ 

UP TO $2,500 WILL BE MATCHED BY EBAY!!!WHAT ARE THE H.O.P.E. LOCKERS?
The H.O.P.E. Lockers are a day-use facility of safe and secure lockers for Salt Lake's homeless community to store their cherished belongings. They will include ADA access.
H.O.P.E. stands for “Helping Other
People Evolve,” and the Lockers will do just this by providing not only a safe space for storage, but also the peace of mind that comes with that while they look for employment, attend appointments and clinics, and generally
live their lives.

This project came from the homeless community itself. When you ask someone what they truly need to improve their lives, the answer is often surprising.


MUCH, MUCH MORE THAN "JUST LOCKERS" 
These Lockers provide not only a place to store things throughout the day, but the peace of mind that comes with knowing your worldly belongings, your resources, and your identity are protected.
Furthermore, these lockers will provide the homeless community the dignity to empower themselves and evolve their lives by obtaining and retaining employment, and other opportunities that come with the freedom of mobility.



ABOUT THE TEAM

This project is a product of the collective effort of two local 501(c)3 non-profit organizations: Revolution United and The Legacy Initiative. 
The H.O.P.E. Lockers are the first phase of a sustainable, self-governing village of tiny homes for the homeless of Salt Lake City, that will be called The Legacy Village SLC. 







REVOLUTION UNITED


Revolution United is a human centered nonprofit organization inciting a fundamental change in the way humans engage their communities in all sectors of life! Our mission is to develop open source projects utilizing inclusion, innovation, collective impact, and the desire for holistic well-being. We unify the  individuals, non-profits, and businesses to make it happen. THE LEGACY INITIATIVE
The Legacy Initiative's mission is to fight hunger, provide humanitarian aid, and educate people through community partnerships not just for today, but for our future.The
 idea for the Lockers came from within the homeless community itself, 
out of a collective brainstorming session called an "Idea Silo."


HOW WILL FUNDS BE USED?

We aim to be  completely transparent in this project, every step of the way. Regular updates of expenses and income will be provided to the community via our webpages. 

Because we are verified non-profit organizations, Indiegogo will only take 4% of the funds we raise if we meet our goal, or 6.75% if we don't!


The design and engineering work is being done complimentary by a member of our team, so we are keeping (wo)manpower costs at nearly zero.





STRETCH GOALS!
+ If we raise $13,000 total we will add solar panels that power security cameras.

+ If we raise $14,000 total, we will incorporate Legacy Village as it's own 501(c)3 non-profit organization. 
+ If we raise $20,000 total, we will build our first Tiny House for the Legacy Village SLC project.

--------------------------------------------------->>>>>





Some Articles written about the Hope Lockers:



GOOD 4 UTAH - ABC 4http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=32771629http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=32771629






SALT LAKE CITY WEEKLY


  SL CITY




FREQUENTLY ASKED CHALLENGES  There are a lot of potential issues that can arise from the lockers, here are some of the answers:   
Q- Who gets use of the lockers?A-Lockers are assigned on a first come first served basis 
Q-How long can I store my property?A-Property is to be removed each day. 

Q-Can I keep my belongings in a locker for more than one day?A-No extensions are granted for lockers.

Q-What should I do if I forgot my access code or lost the key to my lock?A-You should contact us directly and to discuss what can be done.


Q-How big is an individual locker unit?A-The locker unit is a measures 1'-6" feet wide 2 feet deep and 3 feet high.


Q-What are the hours I am able to access my unit?A-Access hours will be determined due to the location where the Locker unit is set up.


Q-Where will the HOPE lockers be located?A-Desired locations have been selected in the downtown area, close to service providers.


Q-How will we prevent the storing of weapons/ illegal goods/ drugs, theft, and vandalism?A-The lockers will be monitored by our volunteers. Law enforcement will be able to monitor them as well. Security cameras will be mounted on the unit to deter illegal activities.


Q-How will insect/rodent infestation (bed bugs) be avoided?A-Adhesive traps will be placed to monitor for the presence of insects. Non toxic treatments such as diatomaceous earth will be used.


Q-How will you prevent the theft of facility/trailer unit?A-When set up, the unit will be placed on jack stands and the tires will be removed.

Q-What should I do if I lose password and need to gain access to my locker?A-You should contact us immediately and allow up to 24 hours for access into your locker.





OTHER WAYS YOU CAN GET ENGAGED

 If you can't contribute financially, that's okay! We have other ways:  
Share this campaign on your social media streams.


Do the #HopeCallout! Go somewhere in public and begin recording, Call out 5 of your friends to take the challenge. The challenge is to either donate $10 to the campaign or shout "I HAVE A NAME!" as loud as you can.


WE CAN'T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!

story:
Kyla  is 11 years old and she has cerebral palsy and epilepsy she has a basic model from the NHS but it is a basic model and not suitable for her needs. I just want to make her life more comfortable and give a chair which she will be better in. 

I have also tested Kyla out in a walking frame and she did brilliant for a first attempt the NHS will not fund such a thing because they have given up hope that Kyla  will ever walk but I as her mum have not The walker will strengthen her legs and her core and give her more independence

story:
The Ms. Wheelchair California Foundation is an advocavy pageant for women 21+ that use wheelchairs and are leaders in the community. We are the official state pageant of The Ms. Wheelchair America Program and our titleholders continue to compete at the national level. A week ago, our very own Dr. Alette Coble-Temple (Ms. Wheelchair California 2015) was crowned Ms. Wheelchair America 2016 in Des Moines, Iowa!

The Ms. Wheelchair California Foundation operates solely on the kindness of others and by sponsorships of businesses. We use this money to benefit the following:
*Pageants: a large portion of the funds will go toward paying for annual pageants
*Operation Bills: website, phone bill, monthly bank account fee, advertisement and office supplies
*Titleholder Needs: Our titleholders work for free. If possible they're given a stipend for travel and meals.

The Ms. Wheelchair California Foundation currently has no sponsors. As you can imagine - this makes meeting ends meet tough. We have grown and will continue to do so with your help.

Thank you in advance for your contribution! We hope to see you at one of our future events.

*For more information on The Ms. Wheelchair California Foundation, please visit www.mswheelchaircaliforniafoundation.org, or MWA at www.mswheelchairamerica.org*

story:
STAND WITH MAGGIE'S AGAINST BILL C36.

This campaign has been endorsed by Belle Knox, Tasha Reign, Mia Isabella and Sarah Vandella:

"For too long, sex workers have been marginalized and deprived of basic human rights. We are entitled to equal representation under the law, safe work and conditions, and freedom of expression without censure. Most importantly, it must be recognized by society, religious and political institutions, and individuals that we are deserving of dignity and respect despite the taboo nature of our profession." 

- Belle Knox, Porn Performer, Activist


(Belle Knox, belleknox.com)

Who We Are

Toronto is home to Maggie’s Sex Worker Action Project, a non-profit organization that has spent years tirelessly fighting for the rights of Sex Workers across Canada. Maggie’s is run by and for current and former sex workers and is founded on the belief that in order for sex workers to improve their circumstances, sex workers must control their own lives and destinies. Maggie’s mission is to provide crucial services in education, advocacy, and support to assist sex workers to live and work with safety and dignity.

"I am so proud to be a part of a cause that supports Sex Workers in a sex-positive way! I hope my fans see how important our rights are and want to be a part of this project! I know they will! Have fun with the goodies, and I can't wait to make a video and go on a date with a lucky fan!"

- Tasha Reign, Porn Performer, Activist

(*Have a dinner date with Tasha Reign! Details below)


Why We Need You

Currently, Maggie’s is facing a budget crunch as we are already stretching our budget to maintain, expand and improve our vitally needed services, such as our weekly Lounge drop-in for sex workers and our street outreach; We want to be able to meet the needs of all of our community members while expanding our outreach and creating opportunities to reach people who are in need of our supports and services. We are seeking to further develop our programming, improve accessibility and increase our reach. To do so, we are undergoing a process of re-orientation to ensure our long-term sustainability, with our services reflecting the needs of workers in our community, including street-based workers.

(Mia Isabella, mia-isabella.com)

"I am thrilled to do my part for a wonderful organization like Maggie's, representing Trans Sex Workers not only in America and Canada, but all over the world. It's a wonderful thing to be able to use my celebrity to raise funds and awareness -- and I look forward to meeting the generous donor who wins the dinner date with me! For far too long, Trans Sex Workers have been hiding in the shadows or the punch line of tasteless jokes. It's time for some positive changes."

- Mia Isabella, T-Girl Adult Entertainer, Trans Activist, mia-isabella.com


The Difference You Can Make

As a non-profit, Maggie’s relies on government funding and donor contributions to keep their services running and their resources stocked. From educative programming, safety training, counseling and a safe place to hang out with other sex-workers, Maggie’s is a multi-faceted organization that is also active within many forums to fight for the rights and safety of sex workers.

We want to  be able to hit the streets and expand our  one-on-one work with our valued community members. Our members need supplies to ensure their health and safety, and our services to ensure that the supportive community is kept strong and our rights are continually being fought for.

Feminist porn, sex toys, workshops, OH MY!

What’s in it for you? Aside from good karma you have the chance to win some fabulous prizes from our community sponsors! Check out the full list below (and it’s constantly growing!)…

Our first round of PERKS include:

$30 – the June issue of the hottest new sex-positive, feminist digizine, FLURT mag in which Maggie’s is featured

$30 - Web membership to the T-Girl SuperStars' website, mia-isabella.com

$15 – One of three 1-month memberships to theartofblowjob.com

$40 - A special, signed DVD from Belle Knox!

$50 - A signed photographed of the lovely Belle Knox (limited to 8 - so get one NOW!)


$100 – One of two gift packages from Good For Her

$100 – One of three gift packages from Come As You Are

$150 - One of six pairs of Belle Knox's undergarments (sold on eBay for over $500)!

$150 - One of five pairs of Sarah Vandella panties!

$150 - One of five Tasha Reign swag bags! Including: a signed DVD, a Tasha t-shirt, a signed photo and Tasha sticker!

$150 – A ride on the world’s most powerful sex-toy, the Sybian! (must be located in Toronto)

$500 - Custom love from Tasha Reign -- grab one of three custom made videos 4U by the lovely Tasha Reign

$500 – Dinner with the Maggie’s Board and Staff in Toronto. Ever wanted to get the ear of the organization? Or just want to hang out with us? Here’s your chance to win a special dinner with select members of our board and staff!

$1000 – A Friend of Maggie’s. Your name engraved on a special plaque to be displayed at the Maggie’s office in recognition of your generous donation.

$1500 - One lucky fan and supporter will have the pleasure of a romantic evening with Tasha Reign on a dinner date (limited to one, must be in the LA area to claim this prize)!

$1500 - A Dream Date with Sarah Vandella! (limited to one, must be in the LA or Las Vegas area to claim this prize!)

$1500 - One lucky fan and supporter will have the pleasure of a romantic evening with Mia Isabella on a dinner date (limited to one, must be in the LA area to claim this prize)!


Donate to Maggie’s today for your chance to win some of the fabulous prizes listed above.


For media inquiries contact a.saundersm@gmail.com

Follow Maggie’s on twitter @MaggiesTO for campaign updates and shoutouts!

Maggie’s has been an advocate for Sex Workers Rights across Canada while servicing the Toronto community since 1986… Help us continue to do the vital work that we love to do.

Read about us in the news:

Huffington Post: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/09/belle-knox-maggies-tasha-reign_n_5474063.html

Daily Xtra: http://dailyxtra.com/toronto/news/porn-stars-belle-knox-and-tasha-reign-lend-support-maggie%E2%80%99s-toronto

AVN News: http://business.avn.com/company-news/Tasha-Reign-Supports-Maggie-s-Sex-Worker-Advocacy-Fundraiser-564122.html

 Sexdotcom: http://www.sex.com/news/blog/belle-knox-tasha-reign-donate-panties-sex-worker-advocacy/

Shedoesthecity: http://www.shedoesthecity.com/sex-work-is-work-maggies-toronto-needs-your-help

Sex In Words: http://sex-in-words.blogspot.ca/2014/05/help-maggies-rights-and-resources-for.html?spref=tw

A Note on Anonymity...

Your privacy and anonymity is just as important to us as it is to you... Should you wish to maintain your anonymity while donating to our cause, simply select the 'Don't Display My Name' option as prompted by the IndieGogo site. Your name, credit card, address and contact information is strictly used to administer perks should you select one of our lovely donated prizes. All personal information is kept private in line with IndieGogo's privacy policies, and within the knowledge of Campaign workers. Your anonymity is safe with us!

*All Perks will be sent out following the and of the campaign, beginning on July 1st. You should receive your packages in the following weeks, depending on your location.

story:
Short Summary

This is where my journey to bring national attention to the shameful plight of homeless veterans began: in a homeless encampment ironically named “Camp Hopeville”, along the banks of the Mississippi, just north of St. Louis’ downtown. Hopeville was where I first encountered Leroy and Lumberjack, two of the more than 200,000 veterans—male and female—who are homeless in this country.

 

My Cause: Igniting a National Conversation on the Plight of Homeless Veterans through Photography

My name is Jerry Tovo. I am a St. Louis photographer and artist. But once I was a soldier, a drill sergeant in the Army. I have never been able to reconcile the void between the adulation our nation displays for our warrior-heroes and the virtual neglect our society shows once they return home with problems. A couple of years ago, I began to research homelessness among veterans. I was staggered to learn the huge number of vets who wander our streets homeless: approximately 200,000 on any given night, with an additional 1.5 million at risk for homelessness.

Barbara

Homeless Air Force Veteran

1972 - 1982

 

 

Once upon a time, they  risked everything to protect our freedom. I remember them before they were faceless, forgotten heroes ravaged by the perils of life on the streets. They suffer from alcoholism, drug abuse, mental illness, poverty and traumatic memories of war. Honored and distinguished not so long ago, they have fallen from grace: victims of societal neglect and collective amnesia.

 

 

Lyov

82-year old Homeless Officer

Korean War

 

Last January, I founded an organization, They May Have Been Heroes, with the goal of igniting a national conversation on ending homelessness among our veterans. My hope is to travel across this country for the better part of a year, photographing homeless vets, with the  goal of showcasing their poignant images in every state.

 

Progress to Date and The Road Ahead

I have made some headway recently on this front. The Missouri History Museum, located in St. Louis, will be hosting a special six-month exhibit of my photographic work, beginning July 3, 2013, and running through December 1, 2013. While I am pleased to finally have a platform for elevating this issue, St. Louis represents only the first step in my journey to bring the plight of homeless veterans to the forefront of national attention. My hope—my highest aspiration—is to orchestrate a traveling exhibition that would traverse across the country, culminating in a major gala in Washington, D.C., where these photographs could draw sufficient interest and potentially motivate our policymakers to do something about this travesty. I want nothing less than to spark a national conversation igniting changes in national and state policies regarding treatment of our veterans, as well as greater funding for the services they need to permanently escape homelessness.

 

 

Phaero

Homeless Army Medic

PTSD

Vietnam and Korea

 

 

Why I Need Your Support and How I Plan to Use Funding

Up till now, I have been funding this initiative solely out of my own pocket; however, I need your support if I hope to continue. I need at least $20,000 to cover the cost of travel and some miscellaneous photographic equipment. I plan to direct any proceeds generated through gallery exhibits and associated fundraising activities in excess of expenses to a national not-for-profit group that effectively represents the voice of homeless veterans in promoting policy change and advocating for critically-needed health, education, vocational and social services. Furthermore, our organization will collaborate as much as possible with local charitable organizations working to address and prevent homelessness among our veterans, allowing them to leverage the publicity and excitement generated by the exhibit to promote their own good work.

 

We Must All Act Now to Prevent Another Generation of Soldiers from Becoming Homeless

Please help me to bring attention to the travesty of homelessness among our veterans! With thousands of soldiers returning from the frontlines of Iraq and Afghanistan, an unprecedented number of whom suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury, we must all act now in order to prevent a whole new generation of heroes from becoming homeless.

 

I once was a face in the crowd.

I stood up tall and was proud.

But then the war took me away

and when I came home I had

nowhere to stay. They spit on me

and pushed me around. I’d

become a faceless soldier

in my own hometown.

  

We once were rich

Now we are poor.

We fought for our freedom

Now we are no more.

 

- By Ronnie Hancher

Homeless Army Veteran

1975-78

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Jerry Tovo

Photographer and Artist

They May Have Been Heroes

While I am pleased to finally have a platform for elevating this issue, St. Louis represents only the first step in my journey to bring the plight of homeless veterans to the forefront of national attention. My hope—my highest aspiration—is to orchestrate a traveling exhibition that would traverse across the country, culminating in a major gala in Washington, D.C., where these photographs could draw sufficient interest and potentially motivate our policymakers to do something about this travesty. I want nothing less than to spark a national conversation igniting changes in national and state policies regarding treatment of our veterans, as well as greater funding for the services they need to permanently escape homelessness.
 
 
Phaero
Homeless Army Medic
PTSD
Vietnam and Korea
 
 
Why I Need Your Support and How I Plan to Use Funding
Up till now, I have been funding this initiative solely out of my own pocket; however, I need your support if I hope to continue. I need at least $20,000 to cover the cost of travel and some miscellaneous photographic equipment. I plan to direct any proceeds generated through gallery exhibits and associated fundraising activities in excess of expenses to a national not-for-profit group that effectively represents the voice of homeless veterans in promoting policy change and advocating for critically-needed health, education, vocational and social services. Furthermore, our organization will collaborate as much as possible with local charitable organizations working to address and prevent homelessness among our veterans, allowing them to leverage the publicity and excitement generated by the exhibit to promote their own good work.
 
We Must All Act Now to Prevent Another Generation of Soldiers from Becoming Homeless
Please help me to bring attention to the travesty of homelessness among our veterans! With thousands of soldiers returning from the frontlines of Iraq and Afghanistan, an unprecedented number of whom suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury, we must all act now in order to prevent a whole new generation of heroes from becoming homeless.
 
I once was a face in the crowd. 
I stood up tall and was proud.
But then the war took me away 
and when I came home I had 
nowhere to stay. They spit on me
and pushed me around. I’d 
become a faceless soldier 
in my own hometown.
  
We once were rich
Now we are poor.
We fought for our freedom
Now we are no more.
 
- By Ronnie Hancher
Homeless Army Veteran
1975-78
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
Jerry Tovo
Photographer and Artist
They May Have Been Heroes

story:
*** UPDATE: WE'RE REALLY DOING THIS!!! $93,000 AND COUNTING....***

What an achievement!! We've hit $93,000!! Give yourself a well-deserved high five. 

We really want to hit $100,000. To do that we need to raise $6k in last 4 days. $100,000 will cover travel expenses for the doctors who perform the abortion services and also one full time security guard for ONE WHOLE YEAR. That's a HUGE help.

How you can help?

1. We need you to SHARE the campaign ONE LAST TIME across your social networks.

2. We need you to email the project to your 3 best friends.

3. REFERRAL BONUS: If your friends contribute $500 or more through your referral link --> we'll send you a FREE WE'RE NOT GOING BACK Limited Edition Beanie. To collect your referral bonus make sure you're logged in to Indiegogo and share the link directly from our campaign page (see below). You can track your referrals in your Indiegogo profile.

Let's do this. It's now or never.

Much love,

Wildfang team xo

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

WE'RE NOT GOING BACK PROJECT

January 22 marks the 45th anniversary of Roe v Wade. Almost 50 years later, we are still fighting for those same rights. There are now SEVEN states which have just ONE remaining abortion clinic. Without these clinics we put millions of women’s health and their futures at risk. We refuse to stand by and do nothing.

Help us ensure access to abortion is a right for EVERY woman (not just those with money or those living in certain states). 

Why are we doing this?

Because WE’RE NOT GOING BACK. We refuse to stand by and watch as MILLIONS of women lose access to abortion services. 1 in 4 women in US will have an abortion in her life and without these clinics we put women's lives at risk. So, let's not post angry quotes on Instagram or Facebook. Let's take action. Let's put our money to work and create meaningful change for women in the states who need it most.

We are the leaders we have been waiting for.

Our Goal

The ‘WE’RE NOT GOING BACK’ Project funds will go directly to the Sioux Falls Planned Parenthood Clinic in South Dakota. If this project is funded, we can ensure hundreds of thousands of women have access to the health care they need in a state where that healthcare is most at risk.

  • $650 helps one women who needs financial aid meet the cost of their abortion care.
  • $5,000 allows doctors to travel to and from Sioux Falls for 1 month.
  • $50,000 covers the cost of a security guard for the clinic for 1 year.
  • $250,000 pays for medical staff to serve the clinic for 1 year.
  • $750,000 funds the clinic to stay open for a 1 year.

Why South Dakota?

  • Sioux Falls Planned Parenthood runs the ONLY REMAINING healthcare clinic offering abortion in the state of South Dakota.
  • Every branch of government in South Dakota is solidly opposed to abortion – the legislature, the Governor’s office, and the Attorney General.
  • Women who get an abortion in South Dakota must make two trips to the clinic – 72 hours apart – because state legislators think women need three days to “really think” about their decision. 
  • 35% of women who use this clinic travel more than 300 miles round trip.
  • Planned Parenthood doctors are forced to tell patients that they are at increased risk for suicide and that's a LIE.

​More crazy sh*t that happened in South Dakota:

  • Isaac Latterell, a state representative and majority whip for the South Dakota House, once penned a blog titled, “Planned Parenthood worse than ISIS and lying about it.”
  • In 2011, a bill was introduced in the South Dakota legislature that would have legalized the killing of any doctor who performs an abortion.
  • In 2015, The Institute for Women’s Policy Research named South Dakota the worst state in the nation for reproductive rights.

What your funding means?

  • Sioux Falls Planned Parenthood can serve every woman who seeks an abortion in South Dakota.
  • Sioux Falls Planned Parenthood will fight unconstitutional laws at the legislature and on the ballot.
  • Sioux Falls Planned Parenthood will continue to organize the resistance and train new leaders in South Dakota.

When we receive your funds, we will remove the fees for Indiegogo, the credit card processing fees, and the cost of the product -- EVERYTHING ELSE will go directly to Sioux Falls Planned Parenthood clinic. We expect those total fees to be about 20% of the funds, and the remaining 80% of funds will go directly to the clinic.

How else can you help?

If you can fund this project, please do.

If you can’t, please share it all over the internet.

Either way you’ll be helping women across the country access the healthcare they really need.

THANK YOU.

What the hell is Wildfang?

Wildfang is a lifestyle brand that was created to help empower women. To remind women that they can be whoever the hell they want and dress however the hell they want. You might even say we’re on a mission. And yes, we believe in a women’s right to choose. Last year we gave $75,000 to charities like Planned Parenthood, ACLU, Southern Poverty Law Center & Joyful Heart and this year we want to blow that number out of the water. We decided that the most important thing our little business could do is create positive and long-lasting change in the lives of the women who need it most.

Any risks?

There are always some risks and challenges involved in pulling off a project like this -- mostly anticipated from printing, production and shipping delays. The good news is, making rad products is what we do every day here at Wildfang, so we have amazing partners in place to pull this off.  

More information:

  • 1 in 4 women will have an abortion by age 45.
  • 60% women obtaining abortions are mothers.
  • Women are 14 times more likely to die during or after giving birth to a live baby than to die from complications of an abortion.

Get the facts on abortion here:

https://www.guttmacher.org/united-states/abortion

https://www.self.com/story/14-abortion-facts

https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/06/opinion/sund...

http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/04/health/planned-pa...

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-abortion-idU...

Find Planned Parenthood Health Center near you → https://www.plannedparenthood.org/health-center
